pros: Employees can be well compensated (depending on your manager). It is a collegiate place to work with nice people. It's an intellectual environment with focus on scientific investing and not much focus on leadership skills such as ability to effectively communicate, ability to challenge the norm to resolve issues and ability to manage people. The company has good medical, dental, family leave and vacation benefits compared to other US companies.
cons: The company has become very hierarchical and senior managers are improperly incented to protect their expense lines rather than to focus on overall company profitability.  The company culture is also very non-confrontational so managers are afraid to give direct feedback and employees are afraid to speak up or question authority.  There is a great deal of inconsistency in how employees are incented, compensated and treated which leads to different cultures depending on which group you are in. Senior management is very weak and unable to make tough decisions. They make layoff decisions, budget cuts and budget targets at a high level and then spread them evenly across all groups rather than taking into account true growth or non-growth areas. This leads to a tactical approach and disparate infrastructure.

review_title: Friendly people, heterogeneous culture, progression and pay driven by internal politics rather than performance
pros:
- Good chairs, great given the time you spend in them
- SeamlessWeb deliveries, for those late nights
- Friendly people, many colleagues genuinely sitting in the same sinking boat
- Good learning experience, depending on your team
cons:
- No reward for loyalty. Management would much rather pay large guaranteed bonuses (deferred from other banks) to "A-Team" recruits from other big banks, who often turn out to add limited value.
- Limited senior management knowledge. As a trader, I have to seek approvals from managers who are clueless about the product, market and risk being discussed. As it is easier to say "no", this leads to significant missed opportunities.
- No link between proposed culture and compensation. The "RISES" philosophy (Respect-Integrity-Service-Excellence-Stewardship) is a bit of a sideshow when it comes to rewarding performance, which is driven more by politics than by performance.
- Inefficient business set-up. Head-count often unduly high because risk is split across more desks/businesses than required, compared to other banks. Leads to (a) risk not being pooled together to be optimally managed, (b) more headcount with less responsibility and less potential for progression, as well as the wrong people being made redundant.
- Internal IT systems off-the-shelf and around 15 years outdated.

The benefts are comparable to other banks, however the New York office may feel a bit short changed compared to the London in regards to memberships, etc to cultural institutions. The company is doing well in a difficult market and has greatly expanded its exposure with the acquisition of Lehman Brothers North American operations.
cons: Many of the downsides to working at Barclays Capital relate to its recent and rapid growth over the past few years. The company grew in size in regards to staff and financial metrics and often the systems in place both technology and policy lag behind. Compared to more mature investment banks Barclays may appear a bit behind in some senses, although that is not to say there are not some very fine and very advanced systems at Barclays. The company has grown a bit more bureaucratic as of late seemingly in response to its much larger US presence after the Lehman acquisition.

review_title: Be weary at Barclays Capital - Don't get staffed in a group of legacy Barclays Capital management
pros: Due to thre recent acquisition of Lehman Brothers' NA operations, Barclays Capital can compete against the likes of Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.  In addition, the firm's balance sheet allows the group to lend on more favorable terms to deals that are identified as strong relationship clients.  The placement of Skip McGee (from Lehman) as the head of Investment Banking should position the group for future success.  In addition, given the lack of competition from the likes of pure investment banks, as they have all disappeared, Barclays Capital will be able to gain a strong market share in areas such as M&A, IPOs, etc.
cons: The senior management team lacks clarity, does not effectively communicate the group's direction and focus and are spineless.  I was let go in October 2008 as a result of the integration with Lehman Brothers; however, a majority of the people let go during this time were junior staff identified by their managers (and since I did not get along with manager, I was identified).  In addition, the Company's procedures were constantly changing and a process was never truly defined, as the policies were constantly revolving.  The biggest complaint from my manager was my lack of awareness of policies and procedures - it's hard to keep track when it constantly changes.

review_title: Well paid but they own you 24/7
pros: Money is good. Nice Office. They had a very good canteen at Canary Wharf in London.  Plenty of food & drink establishments close by.
cons: I can sum this up using the advice given to all staff 'Going home to your wife & family at the end of the day is a wasted business opportunity'  In my time there I saw people being dragged back from holidays half way round the world for ad-hoc meetings that were a waste of everyones time.  I saw a clerical junior being couriered a mobile phone so they could keep asking him stupid questions about unjamming the printer etc. while he was in his hospital bed (then made him redundant a month after he returned so they could save money)  I had to work almost all bank holidays even though there was rarely any work to do.  I soon learned to take my holidays in places with no phones or mobile signal and tell people all my weekends were being spent at the other end of the country.   When I finally left it took me three months to stop jumping every time the phone rang.   But I am probably describing every big merchant bank in London.  Just make sure you save or invest as much excess salary as you can so you can retire early.

review_title: Difficult to be an adviser at Barclays Wealth Americas
pros:
World class research.
Access to high quality investment professionals across Wall Street.
Strong relationships with other service providers. 
A well known brand.
Strong analytic work from internal teams.
Competitive levels of pay for top performers.
cons:
The management of Barclays Wealth Americas is run primarily through a culture of fear.  Employees are discouraged from presenting issues or opportunities to improve the firm.  There is no formal process with which to do so.  Employees who informally attempt to raise issues are penalized or disciplined, and hurt their chances of future career growth.

Benefits are skewed towards the top producers, which reduces the amount of collaboration between employees.

Investment recommendations are most often made on the basis of what will earn the firm the highest amount of revenue.   Products are pushed on advisers weekly.  The advisers that sell the most commission-based products are rewarded and recognized more so than others.   Management has a broker-dealer focus that adds conflicts of interest to the Wealth Management platform from succeeding.

Finally, the technology in place is older and slower than that of its competitors, putting everyone at a disadvantage.  Time is often wasted having to correct or re-enter data into various systems, making it harder to stay on top of your day-to-day tasks and goals.

They have a push towards training. You get out what you put in. If you truly have a desire to rise to the top and are willing to make personnel sacrifices then you will be able to. Fairly good benefits. the new CEO seems very values driven and is ethical.
cons: It is unstructured so many become disgruntled if they are used to a very precise and directive place. This is partly the culture. There is very high turnover, at least in NYC. I think this is due to the competition for top talent. You are only as good as your last months performance so you have to have an A game at all times. Like any place, it depends on who you are working for. I had a couple great managers who I reported to. A few others I would have been miserable. Competition on the street is fierce, layoffs always hang overhead but this is the same everywhere. Don't work at an investment bank if you expect to ride it out for 20 years on easy street.

review_title: Great place to work and progress your career.
pros:
The culture within the organization is excellent and I could honestly say that my current team is one of the best teams I have worked so far. I can always trust my colleagues and I case I have question they are always there to guide me to the answer I need.
 
Senior management are transparent and approachable when needed. Lots of communication about what is going on within the group and etc is distributed internally. 

Moreover, we really live with the Barclays values and as organization we do lots of charity. 

There is opportunity for career progress vertically (within the structure) and horizontally (within other structures) and middle and senior management are supporting it. Training is also provided, although that the process is quite slow and takes few months to arrange everything.
cons: The salary and non cash benefits are below the average for the industry, however I believe that when you consider all the Pros this could be discarded.

pros: IT Audit function covers entire bank portfolio, from payments to credit cards to retail and commercial banking, with locations centred in UK, Western Europe, and a growing hub in SE Asia.  The investment banking arm (Barcap) is effectively a separate entity.  Theoretically lots of opportunity for travel, and to get exposure across a number of business areas. cons:
Job areas are clearly demarcated, and it is difficult to move between, e.g. Barclaycard and Commercial Banking for structured development, and very hard to move to / from Barcap.
Management is very hierarchical, with little trust and interest in opinions and experience of staff in the 'rung below'.  Progress and innovation noted by their absence. Takes inordinate amount of time to initiate improvements, and they are generally not valued by management. A large QA team do nothing to streamline work processes.  For a regulated industry, the controls focus in operations is poor, and operational staff and junior management do not value Audit function.  Audit management style very traditional, and struggle to embrace modern working practices (such as remote working!)

review_title: Global Technology is a sinking ship - get out while you can!
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Salary isn't too bad if you're a good negotiator. You don't have to work particularly hard - in fact, most people don't. If you have a family it's great, because you can work from home all the time and never do any work - just leave it to other colleagues.
cons: Global Technology in Barclays, or JPBarclays as it is now, is a complete mess. I can't overstate how much of a disaster it is. There's barely any talent left - the current employees are either on visas so cannot leave, or are too stupid or lazy to find another position externally. Promotions are absolutely impossible to come by, hiring is frozen across high cost centers, and requests to replace staff who quit have to be vetted by the CEO's team. There's so much bureaucracy it's impossible to get any real work done - rebooting a development server takes around 4 hours and 3 phone calls. Nothing actually works properly, from the helpdesk to the infrastructure services, so when a process or task completes successfully it's a surprise and quite possibly accidental.

job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: Relatively colleagial culture for investment banking, though some groups better than others.
cons:
Compensation is well behind peers, and employees are nicked and dimed wherever possible, for example:

The firm defines your “salary” at a figure well below your annual fixed compensation so that the firm can pay your retirement and health benefits off a lower number. The firm is the only bank on the street that doesn’t make annual salary bumps effective January 1st, instead waiting until late March, meaning you lose a meaningful catchup bonus (~5-10k) every year. The firm requires you buy your own laptop and does not reimburse you for very normal expenses like holiday parties, recruiting lunches and dinners.

Barclays is also the only firm on the street that fires a meaningful portion of its staff right before bonuses every year, which is really an awful thing. I saw many colleagues, including fathers and mothers, completely shocked and devastated as they were escorted out of the building with half the comp they had been expecting to live on.

That said, it does appear decisions are taken at a much higher level at BlackRock than BGI, and it'll be interesting to see if at a corporate level we become more JFDI than consensual....

It is almost expected and normal for you to work outside your hours, there is no hesitation to amp up workload to unreasonable measures.

review_title: Work for Barclays Capital IT at your own peril.
job_title: Analyst Programmer in New York, NY
pros: The firm is very client focused and is not being run like a giant casino out to game the system. The senior management is very focused on keeping communication lines with employees open.
cons:
I am part of the IT Graduate Analyst program and my person experience has been awful - there are 3, 6-month rotations you have to complete - irrespective of the fact that you have Master's degree or not and then once you get a permanent placement, there is just no word on when you will get elevated to the next title. 
I have great finance, math and programming background and was hoping to look for a role that would require a good mix of these skills. Unfortunately, anyone with an IT background is considered a third-rate citizen of the bank. IT people have to fill in time-sheets which I think is a gross and uncomfortable experience.

review_title: Current employer @ BTCI  - Worst place to work
pros:
1) Flexible work timings
2) Good leave structure
3) Work from home (Looks like pros but in reality it is con :)
4) Competitive pay scale
cons:
1) Totally manager driven company. Your appraisal or bonus depends on yr relation with manager not on efforts you are putting. So if you don't work doesn't matter if you are good in .....( no need to specify :)
2) HR are worst--- You meet them only at induction and while leaving the company, I believe most of HR's are doing their interns as they themselves are not aware of Barclays policy.
3) Join company at B5 - PM level, not at B4(Tech lead) or B3 else your personal life is going to be miserable.
4) No Onsite - Racial discrimination.
5) Appraisal process is not well defined, it all depends on your relation with line manager.

review_title: Don't do it. You have been warned. No Excuse. Better to work at Target or Pizza Hut. Run away as fast as you can.
job_title: Customer Care Manager in Henderson, NV
pros: Nice people. People tried to do their best.
cons: It is what it is.. The repetition of the scripts will drive you insane.   You want to help the customer, but you can't unless they say the magic words.  The Customers will treat you like a pinata. I had one customer call and curse at me because we sent him an email that his payment was under the minimum amount.  Think about that...he took the time and effort out of his day to call and curse at a stranger because a computer generated email was sent to him so he wouldn't be charged a late fee.  Some Managers were just lazy and unhelpful. Saying "look in the P&Ps" is not helpful and makes you look like a joke.  Not just at Barclaycard, but Call Centers in general... you will be treated like child.  You will be fired if you have to many sick days, late to work, Dr. appointments, etc.  (Occurrences).

job_title: Digital Transformation Consultant in London, England
pros: Fairly decent folks to work with and pay is ok
cons: Really poor management. Bullying culture is rife.

review_title: Run for the hills and don't look back
pros: broken dreams and promises and a whole lot of lies
cons: need to clean house starting with management

review_title: Less Reward for no or little work
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
They tend to sugar coat everything and make everyone feel better
People are generally nice to work with and politics is not bad at all compared to other shops
There are a bunch of smart guys in Front office from whom you can learn a lot.
cons:
One the worst payers in the street ( especially if you stick with them for > 4 yrs or so in non front office functions). 
Reward for performance in areas such as product control, operations , risk and IT is not great. So eventually people either leave or do nothing and become part of the system.
Most projects tend to be delayed and systems are antiquated compared to other top banks.
Preach internal mobility but make is impossible to happen in reality even you get an internal offer
Most Directors in infrastructure are non technical and just people managers with fancy ties.
Traders keep all the money ( almost 75-80% of the pie is for them)

job_title: Principal in City of London, England
pros: Able to work with intelligent people who like to have fun.  The environment has changed over the years but a lot of what makes BGI a great place to work is the tolerance for a mixture of the past and the future.  In the main managers care about their teams and work hard to develop and reward them even in difficult years.  You can be yourself - conformity isnt necessary but you must be great at what you do.  Opportunities to develop knowledge, skill and your career are available if you perform well.
cons: Senior management struggle with providing enough communication at the right level.  They are working on this but more is needed.   We are in a transition to BlackRock and whilst we continue to work hard to keep the comany successful its difficult to keep focused when the end of BGI as an independent entity is so close.

review_title: Horrendous period - such a bad reputation that reputable agencies don't do business for fear of ruining careers.
pros: Household name obviously; huge multinational presence, kudos, also posh titles (for those obsessed by the VP title), and the IT systems were great - dead easy to be working from home as I did when working with remote teams.
cons: I worked with Barclays as a student back in the 90s.  I thought I was going back to a fantastic position doing delivery and stakeholder engagement.  What I suffered (along with other shortlived VPs and directors who voted with their feet), was truly horrendus.  Incompetent people came in, brought very junior like pals and gave them VPS and director positions, when they could not lead themselves out of a paper bag.  There is also a very strong feminist culture within Barclays Wealth, with the vast majority of senior roles going to women.  Change was managed in a chaotic manner, there was no strategy, and people were forced to use templates from another bank that the head of change decided to bring with her to Barclays - including the confidential details of staff being made redundant at RBS due to off shoring!

review_title: Stultifying and frustrating processes to get basic stuff done.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: The compensation was very good, and working hours really weren't bad for this type of a company.  I did have the opportunity to work on a pretty good project so there was some satisfaction there.
cons:
The level of talent there was very uneven. When staffing a project, I was under considerable pressure to hire "warm bodies" rather than find the right people for the job. Schedules were unrealistic (though to be fair it did not translate into a demand that employees work longer hours). Though I enjoyed the work and the challenge, it was in other respects just very stifling. 

The worst part was the unimaginably complex and unworkable system of requesting anything, or putting any change into the system. This made attempting to do your job efficiently very frustrating. They practically have to hire dedicated people just to operate a byzantine change management system designed by demons.

The company has a binge/purge mentality with respect to its employees.

review_title: The worst  experience I have ever had in my life
pros: The paid me on time and sometimes early if it was a weekend but the staff incentives for having accounts had been lowered over the years.
cons: Bullying managers at branch level.I almost had a breakdown due to the pressure put on me.Targets and profits is all they are interested in.Even when it was raised as high as I could go nothing changed.I met some great people who had suffered at the hand of this this "go to bank."variation management" is another word for measuring your sales targets. The new moral high ground which was supposed to change the whole bank has not changed a thing.My friends who still work there are the people I feel really bad for.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: There are a lot of very able, hard working people at the Firm who really know what they are doing.  It is such a shame that there is so much wasted talent.  Department management realizes that morale is at an all time low and does what they can to offer perks that they are permitted to offer.  Work life balance is decent.
cons: The employees who actually do know what they are doing at the firm are not promoted, paid or recognized for their hard work.  In fact there is no recognition for hard work or going above and beyond for any of the employees in infrastructure.  Compensation is poor.  Morale is the lowest it has ever been.  There is very little faith in the current company management and CEO.  Current employees often feel as if they are paying for mistakes others made in the past.  Management appears to be satisfied with status quo and affecting any change is very difficult.

review_title: Restructuring for the sake of it
pros: Areas such as Barclaycard are genuinely innovating and really interesting areas to be involved in and there is a genuine focus on diversity.
cons: I should have seen the writing on the wall when my manager "left" before I'd joined. 3 months later my new manager took redundancy, then Antony Jenkins departed as CEO and my area was no longer required. That is a personal experience in one team but on the whole I have greater issues with the way Barclays is run. They had a vision built on values and then a new chairman came in an it was all change. Everything that had been done for the last 3 years to change the bank into a socially responsible bank had to be undone. It just feels like change for the sake of change. Share price isn't going up so lets make a bunch of people redundant and see if that works. As for the values... they are printed on every wall but you only have to stand outside the lift bank at 1CP one morning at 8.45 to see that staff don't live the values. They're a statement of what Barclays wants the world to think they stand for.... not what really happens.

pros: People are extremely friendly and supportive. Lots of encouragement to progress and flexible working is brilliant; showing that they're an employer intune with the demands of a professional in the 21st century. I'm genuinely really enjoying my time with them and see many opportunities ahead for progression within my current department and elsewhere. They also do a very good job of enforcing their values, which deserves credit!
cons: Hours can be long and work demanding, but that's the nature of the beast with reference to my particular role and is not company specific. Communication of change could be better, but to be honest, in light of the sheer scale of the organisation, I appreciate the complexities involved in this and believe that management do try their best. Demand planning for workload could be improved in some departments as people are frequently overstretched; but I've every belief that efforts are made to reduce the stress.

review_title: Probably the worst company I have worked for!!!
pros:
Barclays Wealth brand - looks good on your CV 
Good work/life balance
time off - when requested 
people are friendly 
job progression - but only if you are like by management (all for the wrong reason)
cons:
management absolute joke !
No communication skills, more politics then the british government! 
unskilled people, there are too many people that are not skilled in their jobs (inclusive of management) 
salary is poor.....you are better off working in a retail store.....and lest not forget bonuses...absolute joke, wanted to give my bonus back to the bank.
Barclays wealth does not recieve the same benefits like the investment banking arm 
communication is poor (im sure I said that already) 
very stingy - we have to buy our own tea/coffe/sugar (guess i should be lucky that they provide the hot water)
too sales focus and not customer focused 
No training provided on systems
unfair personal development grading
......................an absolute shocker of a company...........!!!

review_title: Political; you have to shout about everything that you do. Most people perform to an excellent standard.
pros: Good project opportunities if you can get them. Great benefits. Really nice looking office and amazing views.
cons: Low salary. Political. You have to shout about everything you do. Lots of backstabbing. Rubbish PD system as the pot of money gets divided by team according to target hit; then again within the team. Even if everybody performs well at the same level; it still has to be split to reflect grades across the board. So really it comes down to how much your manager and your managers' manager knows and likes you!

review_title: Some smart people with great intentions but there's a mountain to climb...
pros: The talent (in the areas where you can find it) can rival that of the best banks in the City.  Those who are engaged are sincere and hard-working, and there is plenty to sink your teeth into if you like a challenge and can see your value-add.  Staff are friendly and want to help.  CEO has also made a good start with re-emphasising core professional values at every level.
cons: Staff who want to help don't know how, leaving a few people carrying a lot of the load.  Better investment in resources (salary, training and career development) is needed.  Although there are a lot of great ideas, there is seldom enough time given to implement; changing direction is fairly commonplace, leading to constant upheaval and a sense that management is reacting instead of planning.  IT systems need better cohesion.

review_title: Blocked from progress because of race
pros:
Good on your CV
Work life balance is fine in my area
cons:
Currently short-staffed. For the past month 2 of us doing what 5 people normally did. There have been instances where I have been the only person on the desk.
There is still a glass ceiling for blacks. People get blocked multiple times from promotions..not even allowed to interview, or have to watch less talented relatives of long-serving staff members move up above them.
Pay is very low in my area of corporate banking compared to the market...cases where people on graduate programme getting almost double what people with 20 yrs experience who train them get.
Bullying culture is allowed to thrive by a network of lifers determined to slow the progress of those around them in line with their whims and fancies. They have contacts everywhere (HR are not confidential) so you either have to make your mind up to go to tribunal or straight to the top, threatening publicity. I have seen at least a dozen people bullied out of the business in my time here.

pros: Easy work. As long as you do not try to shine too much and finish your work, you can stay safe for a very long time.
cons: Completely unprofessional when dealing with employee relations. I gave my resignation only to find out they will force me to stay for three months. When I begged and reasoned for over a month, they finally decided to reduce that sentence to 2.5 months. But after 2 months and with two weeks left, the management decided they don't need me any more and let me go while claiming I have been "disruptive" to the team environment because I only worked a few hours a day in the office all the while making sure there is absolutely no work for me to do. Even though the work itself was too simplistic and politically charged, I was treated fairly well until I gave that resignation letter. I believe a company's professionalism can be measured simply by watching how it treats its leavers. I have moved from companies to companies but never was I treated as poorly as Barcap did.

review_title: The best house in a bad neighborhood.
pros:
I worked in front office research, based in London.

Nice people. Not as bureaucratic or political as horror stories you hear at some investment banks.

Mixing socially was encouraged, and engendered loyalty / trust.

CEO Antony Jenkins is trying to create a more responsible culture across the firm.
cons:
Internally-developed technology not very good. Simple things like CRM and research publishing was either very manual, or had buggy internally-developed software.

Like most investment banks, a culture of obsession over bonuses, and suspicion (rightfully so) that management was trying to pay you as little as possible so they could afford to pay the next guy more. That being said, all investment bankers are really well paid in an absolute sense.

Work life balance is still a myth in front-office investment banking, apart from maybe Sales and Trading. The whole industry is still figuring out how to retain juniors when the allure of high pay is no longer realistic, yet the demands on your time have not adjusted commensurately. Barclays is no exception.

pros:
- You can work at 10% capacity and no one will notice. 
- Bank makes a lot of money with very little effort. Is not subjected to intense competition like ecommerce etc.  Therefore, if you want an easy job this place is great.
cons:
- Top down. Every decision is made by a decision committee and then handed down to the employees. Very hierarchical. Employees are not encouraged to make decisions or have a sense of ownership. 

- Managers surround themselves with "yes-mens".  Everyone is busy having an ego-trip. As long as you feed the egos, you are good.

- Very poor decision making by the decision committees. Decisions are not based on commercial gains but a host of ego centric factors. Decision committees are staffed by people who can "talk" but are not subject matter experts. These poor decisions are then handed down to the employees for execution who get blamed in the end when the project inevitably ends in failure

- Lot of talk about values but not practised. Be prepared to sacrifice your integrity everyday at this job. Honest and integrity are not encouraged. 

- A normal day consists of making tons and tons of power points, attending meetings and generally talking rubbish. Outdated processes, outdated technology.

job_title: Senior Digital Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: Working at Barclays has so many opportunities. You never really need to leave. It also has fantastic pension, annual leave, healthcare and the pay is pretty good. The bonuses are great. It is a very comfortable place to work. It is quite easy to network and move your way around. Its very 'PC' and friendly. Social scene can be varied. People are generally out of the office by 5.30pm and your work life balance is mostly respected.
cons: You have to play the game, rather than just be good at your job. There are so many people that you really have to work smart to stand out/avoid being a number. But everyone is kind and fair and so long as you work out how to play the game, the sky is the limit really. It can become quite stale with very little breadth to roles (i was there 6 years) but i enjoyed my time there and it has set my career up for the future - people really respect the name on your CV.

review_title: Great place to work, flexible, internal mobility
job_title: Senior Change Manager in London, England
pros:
-Open door policy in most departments, senior management is very accessible
-Employees are encouraged to seek internal mobility opportunities for new roles and growth 
-Great learning & development
-Many resources for career development 
-Flexible/remote working (though may be dependent on your manager’s preference)
-Great benefits & salaries (if coming from external) are competitive
cons:
-Technology investment does not seem to be a priority - it is siloed and not consistent across departments
-Company can be very bureaucratic and hierarchical 
-When moving internally or getting promoted salary changes are not competitive 
-Regular structural changes make it difficult to understand the company objectives
-People impact of changes is not given the appropriate amount of consideration and effort
-Best practices are siloed - no central repository for information exchange

pros:
* Chairs were comfortable (Herman Miller, Aeron)

* Nice offices in Tokyo and Hong Kong

* SeamlessWeb deliveries
cons:
* Bonus deferral schemes with very low cash caps. One of the lowest among banks in 2011/2012. 

*  Pointlessly bad IT infrastructure. 
       * 300mb email quota. Cumulatively spend days in a year deleting emails from a full inbox.
       * Slow, unresponsive PCs. 

* "Learning at Barclays" : randomly clicking on flash animations for 50 minutes every quarter.

* Culture: pretty minimal. No strong company identify. 'British'.

* "Additional fixed payment":  a trick to minimize pensionable salary. Increases as % of fixed comp as become more senior.

* People bloat:  a lot of Directors (being paid great bases) doing very little. Sales and IT particularly bloated with middle management. 

* Politics: rife and unavoidable. Probably just as bad as other investment banks. Politics drives everything.

* London Canary Wharf location. Pretty bleak, better to be in the City.

pros:
You work together with very talented people.

At least during my time a good name to have on your resume.
cons:
The company is extremely political. The one thing you need to know is you will only get promoted if you have a good relationship to your management. Performance of course is part of that, but unfortunately by far not the most important one. Far from the meritocracy they promote when hiring you.

Pay. Gets smaller by the year. And an increasing workload as they keep cutting people.

Culture and morale. The culture is far from cooperative. You have to be lucky to get into a good team. My management didn't care one bit about what I was doing. Morale is extremely low since from the very beginning that I've been there they like to have job cutting rounds twice a year. You just wait to see if you're part of the next one.

pros: Provide great learning, atleast till 2015, before the leadership changes. Good trainings, cool working environment, free meals, free cab pick and drop facility.
cons:
After recent changes in leadership during 2016, they gave fired tenured good leaders as well as work force and hiring absolute crap. So one can very well think of where they will be standing soon!
Squeezing bonuses and annual increaments no matter how good one has performed, they are religiously giving 15℅ efficiency by cutting  The work force since 2015 as managers have it as their KPI. No growth for a non political employee. Highly political environment and cut throat competition.

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Henderson, NV
pros: Reasonable salary, nice atmosphere, very nice colleagues
cons: Very poor training. Material handout as  null in preparation for the final exam, yet  described as "open book, open computer".  Condescending intermittently, moody, and monotone instructor. Some students security badges worked and some did not, without reason as advised by security and human resources.

pros: Nothing i could think of......
cons:
Worst place to work for. Importance will be given to the consultants. If you are full time or contractor  than you are your own. You have to work for the consultants, work for them while they are gone for long lunches or left for the day or working from on Fridays / Mondays. They will take all the credits and you will look like a full. You might think to talk to your manager or his/her manager but it won’t help as I did many times. There were 6 employees in my team and then 5 left in 4 months due to this consulting firm and then I end up leaving too. I have seen 12+ people left in 6 months (including contractors) and Barclays absolutely did nothing to improve the work environment but hiring more consultants from this firm :)

And yes don’t forget long hours, weekend work and lot of politics. 

Have you ever noticed that Barclays recruiters will call you/ email you for new jobs and you wondered why? Well no one wants to work there and more number of people leave Barclays. Don’t believe me then, you can ask anyone who already worked there and left :)

NEVER EVER JOIN THEM

review_title: I guess we're still bulge bracket
job_title: Assistant Vice President in London, England
pros: I actually do like what I do and like the people that I work with for the most part.  I think that the investment bank is generally decent at getting people exposure and experience, and giving people rotations, etc. It's obviously different team to team, but they do give people a chance to grow, step up, and advance their careers.
cons:
The direction of the company and lack of coordination among various levels of management / silos look like a chicken running around with its head cut off. 

The leadership in the investment bank has great ambitious, but then when it comes to actually implementing those ambitious, the bank completely hamstrings itself because IB management isn't actually coordinated between products, sectors, etc., or between IBD and markets, or between the IB management and Risk, or the Investment Bank and Wealth or Group, etc. 

The IT situation also feels pretty grim, but you hear everyone complain about. 

There seems to also be a trend of "upward delegation" with some levels of management passing the buck upwards when they don't want to make a decision or a call.

job_title: Senior Strategy Analyst in London, England
pros: Known brand, access to training within Barclays, lots of data, encourage your development (e.g. paid study leaves, supporting qualification financially), nice office in London
cons:
You are limited in almost everything: terribly designed policies, overly protective (blocked access to data or useful functions e.g. in SAS), slow computers (20 mins to boot), old square monitors, cost cuttings on vital things (e.g. there is a hiring freeze so they can hit budget targets even tough your team really need extra people, not updating 10+ years old system as it can cost £100k), you need to count pennies you spent (e.g. don't buy open return tickets because it is expensive, sometimes pay for your work-related travel), outdated technologies (make you waste hours during your week).

In certain groups, you often end up working with less than smart colleagues and see quite questionable practices. Also, low expectation on work quality, poor decision making based on gut-feelings and within 5 minutes. Slow promotions.

pros: Smart offices and some very good people mainly overhired and underemployed.  Ambitious growth plans to try to break in to the top tier of private banks.
cons: You are expected to run to stand still while the organisation continues to hire only "A players" and force ranks existing staff to meet the "vitality curve".  Roles tend to be execution focussed and staff seem to be afraid of not being in "back-to-back" meetings in case they are thought to have some slack.  Consequently challenge and debate is not welcome as everyone is hoping that they will end meetings early to get a breather in before the next.  Low morale and employee engagement - almost none of it emotional.  Long hours and presentee culture.  Consequently vulnerable to losing staff who to other FI's who will happily bid up the price for staff whose only real reason to stay is the money.

review_title: Worst company Ever if you are in Data management
pros: *Good pay master but you have to negotiate.
cons:
* Senior management is always lost, keeps experimenting for bad to worse, one day their strategy is something else and every other day they 
* Too many managers for you - One/two in UK, one in India, one may be in US
  and there is absolutely no coordination between them.
Every manager will assign you tasks with toughest deadline possible and if timeline missed even by a day it will be escalated to higher managements.
* Senseless managers sitting in between only to disrupt you, had they not been there I guess everyone would become more productive.
* No one cares about no one here, very unfriendly people.
* Too much power given to manager and no one would ask you for their feedback.
* Transport department could not be worse, make you wait and wait for drops , cabs provided like tata winger etc, changes the drop location without even informing you
* Food is free but it tastes like feet.

review_title: Reasonable if you know how to play the numbers game and talk the talk
pros: Decent wage compared to competitors, company benefits, lots of branches/offices so not that difficult to transfer if required. Such a big company, so many areas you can explore/specialise in if you want to. Shadowing other colleagues is available.
cons: Atmosphere varies office to office due to management and even within the same office over time due to "changing business needs".  Very bureaucratic. If you want to progress you have to move around to different branches/offices, if you stay in the same location it will take a long time for this to happen.

pros:
A steady employer with some very loyal staff
Lots of good sound knowledge of banking around the business. Geographically well placed branches and currently a good breadth of head office locations to pull in that good balance of staff.
cons: It’s been a stable employer of mine for some time and I always believed that if you cut me I’d bleed blue. However the last few years have seen more work with less people with less direction coming from above. It’s in danger of pushing its loyal staff to the edge and a bank needs people with a good understanding of the industry and customer needs. balanced and mixed in with innovation. Needs to be brave and advertise what it is - a Bank! We need to show customers we have strong propositions, a good and trusted branch network that is not obsessed with digitising to the point it’s frightening the less digitally savvy customers away. Let’s serve the customers and be a go to bank....

review_title: Pretty Average for the kind of big company it is and the good reputation it used to have
pros: Some really great colleagues
cons:
If you work in a department and are looking for management support to progress your career in something different you won't get that support

A lot of senior managers Directors and MD level are afraid of challenging their bosses such as CEO when they set ambiguous targets.

They sing a lot about the values I see it as another tick in the box for our leaders who are not living and breathing the values themselves.

Staff Moral is currently very poor in Barclays and the bonus each year is a joke! It's going from bad to worse. If you get a really good appraisal the salary increase you get doesn't add up no where near your good rating. Other Banks such as HSBC even TSB is not doing badly.

I wonder if manage to and HR have ever wondered why they are losing a lot of staff to HSBC.

pros: The salary and benefits attached to it are good
cons:
The people sitting in the management profile who has been in the organisation during the infancy period are still there.

These guys do not understand the IT industry or process which is gradually making the system hollow . 

Legacy IT infrastructure .
No Learning curve or career benefits .
Any lateral hire cannot stick to the culture for more than 6months. If they are sticking it is just because of personal commitment.
Attrition of lateral hires is high
No work life balance. 
No human emotions. People going through personal exigency are treated in a inhuman way. 
Even the state of mind during such exigencies are considered as lack of performance
Ideas or innovation are not welcomed unless it is given by senior management
Inhouse projects to create products without minimum understanding .

review_title: Too many chiefs, not enough indians
pros: Huge investment in Equities, chance to participate in building a business from scratch.
cons:
Over 2009, many people were brought from Lehman and UBS with inflated titles, salaries and guaranteed bonuses. This shrank the bonus pool and left no space for internal promotions. Moreover, many of the said people are making decisions which they are not equipped to make as they lack the experience and context, but they need to prove themselves. 

This leads to very tense political environment, where each requirement is rushed to implementation, then proclaimed buggy and reworked (again without proper analysis) ad nauseam. In the end, capable people on lower levels are withdrawing from decision making and not providing feedback as they tend to become scapegoats.

And yes, the hours are pointlessly long (but we do receive praise and free beers every now and then).

review_title: Great people but morale is down, and strategic direction unclear.
pros:
Friendly, intelligent people (depending on your team)
Decent internship and graduate training programme
Work/life balance reasonable/better than other places (at least in sales)
Brand name still good to have on the CV
cons:
- Low morale on trading floors due to constant cuts and voluntary departures. 
- Lack of communication from upper mgmt and no clear strategic direction
- Grads have no chance to try placements on different desks and are dropped onto a team that needs headcount with very little regard to his or her professional interests.  It is not easy to move teams. If you are a markets intern at Barclays, be very careful which desks you are courting and find out how things are really going for them. 
- Compliance and internal approval processes for anything and everything have become far more stringent and time consuming than they are at other banks (from what I've heard). Not a bad thing per se, but it makes the work very tedious.

review_title: Marketing Department - Hierarchical, Political, Old Fashioned, Command And Control Culture
pros: Lots of protection from HR if your a poor performer. Difficult to get sacked even if you physically threaten or harass people or go to the gym or shopping instead of actually working in the office. So great for useless people as long as you can con enough people to get hired in the first place.
cons:
Very top down structure with micromanagement from very top level. Patronage from the top more important than skill. Therefore it is very political. Job is more about sucking up to right people than doing right thing for customers. So talented people end up leaving and incompetent people are put in charge of areas they have no experience in. Department is laughing stock and subject of jokes from business areas.

Pay is below average and working hours are stupid. Calls and meetings often scheduled after normal working hours and can go on until 21:00 or 22:00. So-called commitment to work-life balance is a joke. No one believes anything senior management say about caring about work-life.

No connection between company values and the actual culture of Marketing Department.

job_title: Relationship Support Manager in London, England
pros: Barclays have a good brand and a global reach. Holiday entiltlement is good, 27 days. Other benfits are useful, healthcare and share plans.
cons: Very political atmosphere and always telling you to 'Raise your profile' - what does that really mean? It seems that once you are in a job, there is not path mapped out for progression and if you aren’t one of the favourites you don’t get much help. There is a minimum period in the role of 2 years. The RSM role is very difficult and very service focussed despite their attempts to tell you different. The wage structure for this role is poor and you have to do a lot more hours than you should for the wage you get paid. There is no way of getting from this role to Relationship Manager without taking a sideways move to either Credit or risk and then doing another 2 years there. I would NOT recommend this role.

review_title: No strategy: hire and fire, reactive fire drills and completely corrupt promotion process
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Very little positivity on the horizon as no plans are made clear to the teams
cons:
Plans continuously changing meaning time wasted hiring and firing
Repeated firedrills mean never able to work on improvement or strategic initiatives
Never able to right size teams meaning key man risk and overwork of good people
No bonuses even for high performers
Promotion is incredibly unjust and dependent on management whims
Extremely long hours and weekends, inappropriate staffing mean working 12-14 hours to cover the clock between regions
Completely ineffective risk assessment frameworks mean control gaps everywhere
Integrity doesnt exist, lack of funding means service and excellence are an after thought. There is no stewardship as there is a fixation on band aid solutions

review_title: Well looked after, but bored and under-utilised. Corporate culture cramps real innovation.
pros: Salaries are higher than necessary, good progression and earning potential, Annual leave is good around 30days p.a, flexible working is available, the office is very nice and great views over london, the budgets you're given to work with are large due to the size of the organisation, the commercial power means you will work with known partners, companies and the government
cons: Too bureaucratic, ever changing strategy and structure every year so can never actually get on with delivery, extremely political, lots of meetings about nothing, lots of money wasted on pet projects which do not come to fruition, do not get to add you own influence due to the highly rigid regulations and guidelines.

pros:
Relatively good salary in comparison with other retail banks in the city.
Brand name (in Russia is not very popular but when abroad you don't need to explain who you work for)
cons: Very bureaucratic,inflexible and slow in decision making. Every serious move should be approved by HQ in the UK. Hard to hire new people if hiring is not mentioned in the budget. Tons of internal documents, politics and other papers. In order to cover your back you have to save all emails + print them (just in case). People work not to satisfy the customer's demands but to satisfy the auditors requirements. Literally, atmosphere of fear inside the bank. Bank's employees are treated differently and divided into two groups:those who worked for Expobank before the acquisition in 2008 and those who came after 2008. People in the so called "Expobank" group are paid less.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, IT in New York, NY
pros: Managers maintain very professional demeanor. Mandatory training includes course that train managers not to yell at their subordinates. After Goldman you would feel like relaxing on (wild) resort.
cons: First year managemment promises good bonuses, promotions, in exchange to long hours of product development and sleepless nights of product support, but then delivers nothing at the end of the year. Next year you are extremely frustrated and don't deliver that fast. Some people jump, some wait hoping to get a package at the end of the quarter when layoffs happens. If you happen to stick for another year you will loose even more in your total comp. But there always be a story that it's not you, it's market situation that drives your comp down. Quality of people in IT distributed as AAA grade ~1%, B+ ~3% and D~96%. The phenomena are easily explained by a simple inability to pay.

pros: Valuable work experience if under unbiased manager
cons: Every thing else apart from work experience

pros: Barclays is a company that is focused on keeping up with the evolving world - that pace is really fast, so with this comes lots of change, it's interesting, diverse, and it's challenging.  There's always a project you can get involve with, so great to broaden your skill set and experience.  Internal mobility is very successful.
cons: It's a very big company and the pace of change is not for everyone.  It can be stressful so you need to take accountability on where you are at with that and ask for help when you need it.  Not all managers are good at helping there staff through this.  You need to voice and self promote (not necessarily a con but something to be aware of.  It's a big company so experience varies greatly based on the team your in.

pros: Well my hours are ok, the job is easy enough. Thats it.
cons: Angry rude customers, lots of gossiping and two faced behaviour, passive aggressive colleagues e.g eye rolling insults masked as jokes. Job is boring. The higher up staff just bark at the colleages and assume things not letting them stick up for themselves. Just assuming they are doing wrong. Literally i hear people gossiping  everyday and then being nice to those people. Its a very  fake environment. I don't feel part of the team. I've heard higher up staff say some awful things about other staff members and then be super friendly and jokey with them the next day.

review_title: Great company to work for freshers and experienced. It gives you a satisfactory employment and learning opportunities.
pros: Good package for experienced, 5 Days working culture, both side transportation (for non metro zone residents) , meals , spacious campus, better infrastructure.
cons:
Organisation has changed its name from BSS (barclays shares services) to Barclays global service center). With frequent changes in management and less focus on employees and working environment there are less opportunities for us in actual. Now everything is about show off. They invest more on advertising then investing in their employees.
The feel of working in captive unit has gone. It has become any other third party BPO company to work with.

review_title: Overall a good company to work for.
job_title: Design and Development Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of experienced professionals to learn from. I have a good manager who works very hard and understanding. I hardly go to many long meetings. Many employees have been around BGI for a long time, so they stuck around for a good reason.
cons:
Since I have only been with BGI for a few months, I have not experienced much downside except for the fact that management have told everyone that bonus will be cut significantly. This is 4 months after BGI's internal recruiter told me  how great the bonus program was. Can't really complain though considering what is going on with our economy. 

There are a lot of forms that needs to be filled (mostly online) just to do something. I have to fill up timesheets, project time trackers, change management, development plans, KTOs, etc etc. Not used to it comming from a startup.

Too many different development groups that some projects are done more than once

pros: I only worked for Barclays for a couple of month as I really didn't enjoy the job, but aside from that they're a fantastic company to work for and really value the employees. The salary increases with every years service and there is a fantastic bonus structure for all employees. The career prospects are fantastic and various benefits are offered such as a very competitive pension scheme, private healthcare, gym discounts, 25 days holiday plus bank holidays and many more which I can't remember.
cons: For me the only con was that I absolutely hated the job itself. I worked as a Premier Banker in the Call Centre and it was my first job within a call centre and can easily say it wasn't for me. Do not go into this kind of work if you don't take well to extremely rude, arrogant and nasty customers.

job_title: Product Control in New York, NY
pros: Hiring freeze creating internal opportunities, that were otherwise closed to internal mobility. Health Center, Gym, On-Site Bright Horizons Daycare at 745 7th Ave a big +.
cons: Hiring freeze negatively impacting morale. Cant fire, cant hire. Increasingly more people are talking about leaving, not staying. Very limited advancement beyond VP, queue for Director is "Pie in the Sky". Will never happen, unless you're one of the "Chosen ones". No differentiation between top performers and bottom of the barrel. Year-end comp is comparable.

pros: PM shift from  15.00-22.30.Recently company started being helpful in regards the flexibility at work . I am on temporary contract working from Adecco agency. they pay £11 p/hr. Free parking all the time. it is great as you can park on weekend as well when you come to visit Poole town.
cons:
late finish
to get permanent positions from temps contract and just to get place for interview you have to go through some useless tests if you don't pass it or pass with low results you can't expect an interview even thought you spent with the company so much time they rely on the test and decide if you good for this job role you already been in for years :) and they should now by now if you fit for this job role or not. I am not talking just about myself. And if you go on permanent contract you will get less money then you actually getting working for the agency in the same position in Barclays.

review_title: A great place to hang out during a recession.
job_title: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work life balance is highly valued at BGI.  Whereas many IT professionals sacrifice balance for career growth or financial rewards, at BGI this is not necessary.
cons: Career growth for an IT professional is limited. Even though BGI has a large IT organization, it is managed primarily by career managers who often have little experience in the areas they manage.  Worse yet, the product management presence at BGI is comprised primarily of MBA types with no experience in web products and who insist on a vertical top-down command style of product development.  There doesn't seem to be a good working relationship between technical and design professionals and their in-house clients and product managers.  I've witnessed BGI make many serious mistakes.  If you'd like to relive the mistakes of 1998, then you'll love web development and online product development at BGI.

review_title: Has the potential to be great
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Northampton, England
pros: Good bonuses, loyal staff, Strong brand, work-life balance is mainly good (within regional offices - Northampton / Teessidel etc - not so sure about London employees)
cons: People dont live the values - the company rewards people who make the money, not caring who they trample on in the process to do so! systems do not talk to each other, making what should be simple,  day to day tasks a laborious tough job. Lack of internal opportunities. Drastic shrinakge in some departments (attrition / redundancy) with the remaining staff expected to pick up the surplus.

pros: Great development, had no experience in training delivery but was given every chance to grow and improve my skills and abilities. My managers in this area were the best I've ever had and it is a meritocracy so hard work pays off. Development plans are clear and achievable. Very nice and well equipped training venues as well. The most tech focused bank and are way ahead of the competition in most of these areas.
cons: Overly complicated management structure where sometimes common sense cannot prevail as too many people need to be involved in a task. Although it is changing, the company is still very "Silo'd" - communication between departments is something that needs to be improved. Training department goes through many phases of displacements and restructures. Annual compensation not very good

review_title: Great flexibility, above average work-life Balance
pros:
- Great opportunity to contribute across functions.
- One can take on additional responsibilities beyond his current role. 
- Internal job moves a big positive. Chances of growth immense provided you can network well.
- Above average work-life balance, wfh is a big boon for some.
cons:
- Slightly unstructured - specifically the HR processes including hiring.
- Old Timers who are at VP level don't want to move anywhere. Their attitude towards firm and work is not something to be positive about.
- Slightly averse to risks. Lot of money waster by the bank because of such attitude at the senior level.
- Not for techies, this is the place for people who can make projects deliver, vendors do the low level work.
- Growth for few can be a problem. Not a very dynamic work environment.

review_title: Your job satisfaction will depend on your team
pros: Great benefits (typical of a corporate) - like healthcare, insurance, etc. Great name on CV. A lot of programmes and events to support employees. Although depends on whether you'll actually have the time to take advantage of them.
cons: Legacy systems slow down your efficiency quite a bit, typical corporate bureaucracy, need to be seen and heard to get promotions (so if you're quiet/introvert, prepare to stay in the same position for a very long time regardless of how hard you work). A lot of job openings but most are only advertised to meet the policy - the suitable person would've already been identified/decided on - mostly someone the hiring manager already knows. This is a public secret and widely accepted by most. Not saying it doesn't happen in other companies, but just because it happens elsewhere doesn't make it okay.

pros:
Has a desire to be successful
A lot of fantastic people at or below VP level
Good (but getting worse) reputation in the marketplace when looking to move on. Still resume-friendly
A lot going on at the moment
cons:
Not everywhere, but definitely a lot of managing upwards and not so much leading at the upper-mid levels (VP/Director). 
A lot of buck passing and not so much team building and development. Step one seems to be first find someone to blame.
Personality-based decisions/favoritism
Unclear and shifting priorities. Difficult to get a decision to stick

review_title: The highs were great but the lows were dreadful.
pros:
The people I worked with were great, we had fantastic laughs, and supported each other through the tough times both personal and business related. 
If you wanted to move your career forward there  were many opportunities, however you 'face had to fit' a lot of the time.
cons:
The demands that were put on you were often unrealistic. The focus on sales rather than service was the biggest problem. You often felt like middle and high level management had no idea what it was like to actually work in a branch and speak to real customers. 
While they went through the motions when there were people with health issues they were in fact very unaccommodating when it came down to actually helping people with disabilities (in my personal experience).

pros:
Only if u are  under the wings of a humane manager else  you are gone for a toss

Good training period again if u get good trainers
cons:
1. There is no RISES for employees in customer service
2. High attrition leads to high work load
3. Pathetic HR that only approach employees while begging for refferals.
4. A mini east india company
5. Be ready to face racist customers over a span of 8 hours.
6. Only bootlickers reach the peak.
7. Full of biharis and bengalis who spoil the ambience at work.
8. People will try to armwrestle specially hr and managers , just break their fake ego.
9. OT money coming in arrears but if you take leaves incentives deducted immediately in the subsequent salary slip.
10. Transport dept is poor n clumsy.
11. Typical slave like mindset.
12. Ready to concede every demand of customer. 
13. Pathetic food in cafeteria and in pantry,
14. So called managers and VP get paycheck just to make mundane reports and shooting cliches on the mail.

review_title: Could be good but highly dependent on what group you are placed in
pros: You get to work in financial capital of the world and there were are lot of activities outside of work to get involved with. You do learn things, that could be of use.
cons: You are at the mercy of the group you are placed in which will either make or break your experience here. As much as HR will try, you will not always be placed in teams that will be of benefit to you or allow you to learn. This was really apparent as half of the interns on my intake were practically doing nothing and were stuck in limbo whilst the other half were actually given the opportunity to get on with things. This is primarily down to the way the bank is set up and operates.

review_title: This is a great place to start your software development career with. Fantastic workplace !
pros:
Pros from a fresher software developer's point of view at BTCI (Pune technology center India):
1. You'll get to learn a lot.
2. Opportunities to work for very critical and real-time projects that one cannot expect in other IT companies.
3. You can interact with some of the great minds in industry as it's a FLAT organisation.
4. One can get huge domain knowledge of BFSI sector if interested.
5. Satisfactory work life balance.
6. The `Barclays` brand obviously.
7. And they pay you well :)
cons:
Many times simpler processes turn into sluggish requests and approvals game which may slow down your actual work. But it's understandable as BTCI is a part of a huge organisation.

P.S. I won't be able to comment on software testing or support profiles.

pros:
Have worked for 10yrs+ in different roles and teams.
Benefits - Health, vacation, etc, all above average.
People - sharp minds in many roles. International & multicultural.
Progression - were brilliant at it 10yrs ago, then struck some rough patches, but getting back to a good place now with focus on retention and internal mobility.
Desire to change - ExCo understood the need to restructure to ensure relevance, have made bold moves, staff generally very supportive and optimistic.
cons: Experience really depends on which function you're in - "management discretion" can be great, but also not as great if your boss is not progressive. Pay attention to your interviewers - if they are consistently projecting a genuinely positive culture, your team is probably a good place. But if not, beware.

review_title: After 2.5 years with the company I’ve learnt a lot but have also seen a decline in the way employees are treated.
job_title: Finance Business Partner in London, England
pros:
You will learn a lot in a very short space of time, with intelligent and helpful colleagues as well as a lot of challenges hitting the industry. 

Flexible working is also strongly sponsored, however in many ways this has become forced as a cost cutting exercise, at which point I question whether it is truly being done for the benefit of the employee.
cons:
Despite a “pro internal mobility” culture, there has been a hiring freeze for 50% of my 2.5 years here which limits career progression. There have also been significant cuts to former staff perks, e.g.
- employees required to work dynamically 2 days a week
- little/no budget for staff socialisation (self funded Christmas party)

The organisation is also incredibly bureaucratic, with many of the processes being followed not following appropriate lean/agile methodologies.

job_title: International Support Assistant in Northampton, England
pros: Being a large organisation means there was a lot of scope to move within the business and get involved in different projects. Getting 1.5 hours of breaks during the working day is unheard of amongst most companies now, while the facilities were exceptional. The cycle scheme also helped me to afford my first bike.
cons:
The management bias was unbelievable in my department. The employees felt very much divided into two categories - those that fit, and those that did not. 

Being in the latter group meant that I was passed over for promotion against a less-qualified and less-experienced colleague, and that I was amongst a sizeable group of staff denied any bonus for completely arbitrary reasons. It was this last point that drove me to leave as it became clear that the personal development scheme and reaching improvement targets meant nothing in the face of a pre-determined outcome.

review_title: Frustrating place to work as an IT professional, but other divisions may be better
job_title: Network Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Salaries are in line with industry standards, and benefits are good, though somewhat more expensive than plans at comparable employers.
cons: non communicative management  - they go through the motions, but not for important issues, such as outsourcing (200 people were outsourced to CGI, on the ides of March no less, and there are still no official announcements).  Poor work/life balance, Rigid and unrealistic appraisal system.

job_title: Collateral, Liquidity, and Funding Analyst in Newark, DE
pros:
Young optimistic environment - this is the only Barclays Capital location that is growing
Fun
Friendly
Relaxed
Ping Pong Table, Fussball Table - after you've been working for 5-6 hours a game or two really helps get you going again. It makes you more alert, and promotes a friendly workplace environment.
Full of long time IB veterans that are completely open to mentor the young
Lots of growth opportunity
cons:
Hours are a bit long but that is to be expected working for an Ibank
When your parent is in the UK it creates all sorts of issues surrounding communication etc..
Parking is a complete mess. Though there is a parking garage and Ibanking employees always get a spot (since they are in so early).
Cafeteria food isnt the best and there are almost no food options within walking distance, awesome food trucks every other day, though

review_title: Management plan is disjointed with limited staff over worked.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Work location and the knowledge to build your understanding of subject matter.
cons:
Managers manage up and not down. The volume of work with limited staff support and expectation of execution of that work is unrealistic.  Changing priorities everyday without focus, then to have the work that was said to be priority put aside after spending time and shifting current work load to execute. 

Found that most mid-level management are YES people without questioning the rationale for the reason why, for fear of not being part of the niche crowd. Line managers adhoc requests are vague and unclear but you are expected to figure it out with no support. 

Work-Life balance is stated but not practiced.

review_title: Real Life at Barclays - I Quit
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
1) Good health care benefits 
2) Looks good on your resume
3) Gym and Clinic in the building
4) Good technology 
5) Very demanding and competitive but you will learn a lot. Stressful; however, it builds create tolerance for stressful and challenging environment.
cons:
- Favoritism is king also a lot of harassment 
- Depending on the department crap salary (mediocre bonus)
- Women make significantly less than men.  I know this from years at Barclays and speaking to colleagues)
- Very long hours. 
- Power struggles within senior management 
- No room for mistakes. 
- Extremely hard to get promoted 
- Little to no support for internal moves
- Your social media will be checked (this is common sense)
- Horrible HR. Do not ever make the mistake of thinking anything you say is confidential

review_title: Good Benefits and well looked after but a lot of 'It's Who You Know not What You Know'
pros:
Good Benefits - Share save scheme, Annual Leave Entitlement and Staff discount etc
Good group of people to work with.
Canteen on site.
Advocates of charity and support fundraising.
Supportive of staff's external commitments.
cons:
Office politics - hard work doesn't always get noticed and often promotions based on who you are friends with. 
Managers have favourites who are selected for the best opportunities.
Stressful with a heavy unmanageable workload.
Absent managers that are awful team leaders and do nothing to address concerns. Dont really listen to you, There is a staff opinion survey but concerns raised are brushed under carpet - shut up and put up.

job_title: Vice President, Compliance in New York, NY
pros: Work/Life balance is good. At certain levels (depending on relationship with managers), you are allowed to manage your own work very freely. Non front office positions allow great possibility for flexible working arrangements. There are some great people in all divisions, but you're lucky if you work with them. Because of the constant upheavals, there are chances to quickly progress if you are in the right place/time or know the right people.
cons: Constant change. If you have been with the firm long term at all, you've likely seen several different heads of your group/department (and the CEO too). Management that stays long term usually are due to their own short comings. Certain areas, atmosphere is ridiculously political and almost soap opera like. Expect many more changes to come, once it's over, I think the firm will be a great place, but who knows when.

pros: They pay you well but there is a cost to it.
cons: It’s not a office . It is a school with a lot of rules and restrictions. If you are in a calling process, you will be treated like robots expecting you to take back to back calls for 9 hours. They don’t even have simple facilities like mute . They are not at all performance oriented . They just care about their policies like not eating at desk. They claim to provide meals but your break timings might not align with their cafeteria timings and you are expected to work on empty stomach. Performance is not a parameter here for growth . You need to offer everything to your boss to get promotions (if you know what I mean). The managers will treat you like kids thinking that you don’t understand anything. Management keeps changing within months. I worked for 8 months and my manager was changed twice . They keep on moving managers from one process to another wasting money on their trainings . All the decisions made by Barclays are unreasonable . Pathetic place to work .

review_title: It pays to be with one of the biggest
pros:
An established Institution of the Banking World.
A great example of a 20th/21st century company who provide their employees with a range of benefits. These come in the form of security, bonuses, pensions etc and opportunity to keep up-to-date with the relevant industry knowledge. Giving that little bit more,, where you may take less.
Offered in-house communication avenues for staff, at all levels, in every sectors to give their own input into the overall running of a particular product or the company in general.
cons:
I worked at a time where around the World the industry or 'Financial Sector', was generally seen in a very negative light.
In order to avoid stagnation, I felt there was a need to further enhance the development programmes for those 'wanting' to climb up the career ladder.

pros: free membership of pluralsight .
cons:
I have been working in API Team since last few months now n overall for 3years. 
1) we are forced to come on weekends and on top of that we are not given any compensation.
2) NO HIKE AND BONUS this financial year, not just me but many of my colleagues.
4) Boot licking and politics is encouraged.
5) MD walks in and bashes us all in very unprofessional and rude manner as if we are dogs.
6) The requirement list changes every other day and you keep refactoring and updating your code. Too much chaos and mismanagement.
7) No Onsite at all! 
8) Salary structure is such that you get nothing but peanuts at the end of financial year.
Before you join, ask which team they are hiring you for. BarclayCard is pathetic. Not sure about others.

review_title: Awful IT. Avoid this company if you're passionate about software.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in City of London, England
pros: Good colleagues to work with.
cons:
If you consider yourself to be a good software developer, heed this warning: avoid BGI like the plague. BGI has major problems recruiting good software engineers, but it's track record of keeping them is far worse. In many parts of BGI - although not all - there is no difference between what a support engineer does and what a software engineer does. Work does not follow any sort of process and is not project based, and you would be lucky if you had a project manager, and even luckier if you have any BA or QA resources. Considering the amount of money this company manages on behalf of clients, this lack of quality assurance is disrespectful to clients at best or criminal at worst.

I used to call that random, unmanaged way of developing software "the bad old days", but trust me, it's carrying on live and well at BGI! 

There is also an ethic of cutting corners in IT wherever possible, even if it means that quality will be lower or costs higher in the long run.

review_title: It's ok until the recession lifts
pros: Somewhat stable, investing in technology (depending what division your in) and they did not take any UK bailout money.
cons:
British Bank... "I am BarCap hear me roar" !!  Seriously, as an ex-Lehman employee,  working at a British Bank kind of blows. All culture is driven out of the UK, and the Brit's , well...... 

I have also found the merger to be confusing and somewhat difficult to adjust to. I can see the inventive and creative personalities of the Lehman employees smashing up against the thier terse British counter parts.  I think as the dust settles, it will eventually smooth out but not sure in who's favor it is headed. Lehman wa a great shop that made some foolish (Fuld) investments and now we all pay the price for the incompetance of a few.

job_title: Business Support Manager in Northwich, England
pros:
Barclays compensation package is good especially compared to available jobs in the area.
Opportunities to get involved in fund-raising and charity events.
cons:
This may be the particular location but there is a 'small town mentality'.  Team leaders have an inflated sense of their own importance, and pick their favourites in a team.
Often people will be asked to 'act up' which basically means they get more work out of you than you are paid for - this is not rewarded with the promotions promised.
