Team leaders pick their favourites and judge staff on how well they flatter them, not how competent they are at the job.
Bullies are not dealt with, despite numerous reports from many people.

review_title: BTCI as a unit not valued much
pros:
Flexible work culture
Pay on par with most IT companies
Constant employee feedback measuring at company level
Encourages employee participation at all levels
Lot of internal openings for movement/promotion
Yearly Leave Allowance
cons:
Specific to business unit I worked with especially about onshore stakeholders:
Racially motivated, treats Indian counterparts as low grade people
Concentrating core development work onshore
Too much interference in local management
Your major time is lost in meetings rather than focusing on actual work

Company level:
No focus on location strategy in Pune
Most processes marred with bureaucracy 
Lack of standard processes across business units
Senior staff within company not open to change in work culture
Appraisal process is murky and lacks clarity and direction at site level
No involvement of HR in handling employee grievance/issues after induction
Internal movements not flexible, leads to career stagnation

review_title: If only the business leaders were serious about their roles and the impact these have
pros:
• Colleagues - they make the place and are passionate about their work
• Good for learning about internal politics and over-inflated egos - once you leave Barclays you will work faster and demand more from your next roles thanks to these learnings
• If you like to hide in the woodworks and do little work without any accountability, this place will work to your advantage!
cons:
• Lazy and incompetent managers / upper management
• no accountability
• hardly any interest in employee wellbeing, be ready to take your own tea bags, milk and bottled water!

pros: Great atmosphere, people are excellent and fun to be with. I really enjoy working with people with the advanced technology that we have.  Great location as well in New York, around all the best places to eat for lunch and dinner if you stay in the office late once or twice.  Management is strong and the direction of the company can been viewed with confidence.  Respect is also valued a lot and they do not mistreat people there.  Some of the friendships I built at Barclays I will keep for the rest of my life, so keep a watch on this company!
cons: Management has a hard time giving time off for people.  Snide comments are sometime present.  It is helpful to be nice and build relationships - the environment really fosters that.

review_title: Poorly managed firm will have trouble capitalizing on its opportunity
pros: Plenty of opportunity to grow the brand/business in the USA. Money being spent on the Barclays Wealth business. Firm will write big checks to attract top producers. High payouts. Small investment management group with a lot of access to key decision makers and senior resources. A few very smart and impressive people if you are willing to look for them.
cons: Borderline incompetent management hired from ML making very retail decisions. Investment platform is incomplete and incredibly slow to develop. Technology systems are antiquated. The internal culture is poisonous and much of the support staff is non-responsive or diligent. Those with the opportunity to go elsewhere almost always do.

job_title: Assistant Vice President IT in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Company has a lot of good people working internally.  Great skillsets and good personalities, talented as well.  Great place to hang out at if you don't like doing much work or accomplishing much of anything.  Pay is decent, but below market rate for location.
cons: Lack of ability to get anything done.  Everything is rule by committee and unless you're Director level or above, no one listens to nor cares for your opinion, no matter your level of expertise.  Dual-headed teams engenders competition and lack of clear direction inhibits progress.  Promotion is done via good ole boys network and grading for reviews is done on a curve; one person must receive a poor grade even when undeserved.  If you're not in the UK, your opinion does not matter.

review_title: Complete dysfunction at the senior management level
pros: Those professionals left standing are, for the most part, hard working, intelligent and consciencious. They do attempt to provide quality service to their clients across the full spectrum of financial products. They have a massive footprint in almost every market globally and their aren't many things they cannot transact as a bank.
cons: Senior management is terrified of public perception. It almost felt as if they'd rather have happy headlines than happy employees and stock holders. Morale is awful. Barclays did not grow organically in the United States post the Lehman acquisition. The result of that has been 6 years of purges and downsizes and business realignments. Barclays wants to be the biggest and has lost sight of the fact that its more important to be the best at a few things than very mediocre in everything. Compensation, by all acounts, is 20-30% lower than counterparts at other similar shops.

pros: Quarterly incentive measured on both personal contribution and team performance - can be very substantial if you put the work in and lead your team effectively. Well supported by direct line management (but I can only speak for my specific business area). Good approach to flexible and dynamic working - enables you to manage work/life balance more effectively. Values culture.
cons: Usual middle management issues - take crap from below and above. Can often feel dehumanised. Procedures can often be implemented by senior level without considering the logistics and impact on you and your team, with you left to pick up the pieces. A lot of focus on Roles outside of London are extremely limited and unless you want to progress further down the management route you can be left feeling very stuck.

review_title: Lovely place to work but has morale issues
pros:
Great benefits package
Flexible working
Big brand
Stringent training plans
Mobility is great should you want to uproot, very straightforward
Looks good on resume
cons:
Progression is down to politics, it's not what you know, it's who you know
Branches are regularly understaffed
Staff are bound to make mistakes due to the stress of regularly dealing with an understaffed branch
Morale cannot remain high as main cause of customer dissatisfaction will always be staff attitude but the branches need to be under closer inspection to identify key issues
Staying back until late hours daily due to lack of staff available to close the branch

pros: Relatively high salaries, bonuses and decent benefits, in terms of travel (mostly business over 4 hours), health insurance, maternity/paternity leave, pension. Compared to another European investment bank I worked at, there was a surprisingly flat management structure
cons: From 2012-2016, the company had too many management changes, which also led to drastic changes in the company's strategy, especially in Asian IBD and global markets/equities. While the benefits were quite good, the flipside was the company lost focused on costs. Quite amazing that employees were still flying business class, staying at top notch hotels with relatively decent bonuses, right before business divisions were closed down.

review_title: Overall, it was challenging and fast-paced environment, full of ambitious and hard-working people.
pros: I worked on the trading floor in a sales support capacity and finally in a sales seat.  I was never bored or wanting for a challenge.  The people around me were energetic and entrepreneurial in nature.  I was always surrounded by a stimulating buzz of activity.
cons: You have to enjoy working with aggressive, hard-charging people.  Work-life balance can be out of whack unless you are extremely talented at your role and managing yourself and those around you.

review_title: Pathetic company. Worst decision of my career
pros:
Good salary
Normal working hours
nothing else to say
cons:
In BTCI, Barclays testing services is the worst department. Don't ever join specially if you are fresher.
They will hire you and put u in a team managed by developers and their manager. in this way you will be controlled by not only your manager, but also by developers manager and even by developer.
and developer give no respect to testers.
And the notice period oh my GOD it is 3 months and they will never leave u early even if no work (i have seen those dark days).
And the manager in testing department knows nothing just to pull the data from its resource about testing , they can't even talk straight with development management.
People will help just in the start (for boys) and for girls they will always help (Pathetic)
Development mgt have their parties and all that and testing mgt have their own and no one invite each other, in this way resource like us hangs in between and can't do anything.

pros: This is a place where careers go to die. If you want a place to park your career and come into work and do nothing this is the perfect place for doing that
cons:
In my ten years career, I have never worked with such a bunch of talentLESS, stupid people. Most of the people in Barclays have no expertise in their respective fields. Most people are unaware of the latest technologies, the latest best practices and are still stuck in the year 2000. 

Meeting after meetings about the most trivial thing, meetings to decide meetings, meetings to prepare power points, meeting to decide everything. In one of the meetings I was in, it took 26 members of the leadership team 1 hour to decide to add an additional column in an excel spreadsheet. (I am not joking) 

Most of my colleagues and managers are unfit for jobs outside of Barclays. Their skill sets are out dated and most of them are just plain stupid. No wonder some employees review Barclays as a "great place to work" and "fast paced".

pros:
Free one time food in Noida location.
Free Transport 
Rest I'm yet to discover
cons:
Certain AVP's have no idea of handling a team.  They just try to finish the task without getting into details of how much effort it will take, they just want to shine in front of their director/VP.  So this make the life of his subordinates living hell. So much work pressure, daily on the receiving end of yelling. Certain days I feels like if I'm really good at anything or not.

People are not good or bad, but they are not experienced enough to handle the situation. So try to train them well before loading them with so much work load so that they take out their fear of disappointing their seniors on their teams.
All power lies with AVP+ level. Don't think that HR is of any help. 

If you have any concerns then talk to your manager or his manager but No HR.  So I'm just absorbing all their negative energy currently in hope of a better team in my next project.

pros: Good for starters. The BFSS department is worthwhile. RT is great for starters. The class of people working is good. Academy coaches are cool bunch. BAU managers are typical managers. Salary is paid on the dot by 8PM on 28th of the month. The set of beliefs are foundation for any good personality. Overall a good experience until you are happy.
cons: RT is monotonous. Over time nothing is left to learn. Tedious trainings for the process but no certified training. Transport department is inefficient and seldom annoying. Negligible global exposure. Just a part of Barclays, not completely Barclays UK standard. Food at Noida 2 is pathetic(you'll agree from day one).   Never employee centric. Just a cost center. Don't expect huge exposure or package.

review_title: Very good personal experience in small team but overall organization needs a great deal of work.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: DIrect managers are extremely caring and a joy to work for. Flexibility, boss is extremely understanding of all outside factors. Work/Life Balance provides opportunity to focus on family life. Down to earth colleagues make for a collegial environment. Independence  to build, own and manage processes lets you make what you want of your role.
cons:
Very bureaucratic, it takes forever to get an answer or an approval due to countless layers and endless mixed messaging. Extremely slow pace for anything.
Compensation was flat out bad and promotion process is inconsistent. No focus improving, just a focus on cutting costs. Very volatile organization with no stability due to lots of layoffs and a revolving door of employees. Communication is lacking as folks make decisions in isolation. Directors sit with their doors closed and many colleagues ignore emails and do not return voicemails.

job_title: Project & Change Management in London, England
pros:
I worked in the Head Office in Canary Wharf
Good name
Large organisation meaning if you're fortunate enough you can scour for and find fresh internal opportunities
Lots going on -different networks and communities
cons:
Values and morals not embedded - it really is dog eat dog. It's not clear what the organisation stands for 
No leaders, lots of managers - very hard to find sponsors/support
Poor progression - you can easily stay at the same level and pay grade for years and years and I met many who time and time again were denied promotions and pay rises despite being excellent
Multiple layers of management doing the same or very similar things -very hierarchical
Lack of meritocracy - it's not clear what promotion criteria is
Very traditional - poor evidence of racial and gender diversity in top leadership positions

review_title: Given the present financial climate, I'd rate them a 'Good' employer
job_title: Community Banker in Kingston upon Hull, England
pros: Values, exposure to hands-on experience, training materials, theoretically, nearly everything is splendid, but when you work in a customer facing role, taking calls back to back, nothing works out as they ought to be
cons: I work for the Retail branch, so my viewpoint is constricted within this ambit only, Barclays is a huge, huge, enormously large group, so it would be unwise to set an impression based on my review alone, I'd say the work environment is 99.99% gynocentric (please pardon, I'm not a sexist, ever), so you're recruited to fill out the quota only to show to the Gov't that you respect equal opportunities, & that's it, if you're not a huge fan of this 'gynocentric supremacy', then my friend, you're going to your grave with the same designation & nearly the same salary that you had originally been recruited

review_title: Good company and culture, right idea, needs more top level drive
pros:
Good company values and beliefs 

Have the right idea to change 

Building exciting experiences and cool stuff 

Have generally good and intelligent people 

Good energy and friendliness 

People and company want to do the right things and be the best 

Stable and interesting
cons:
Not driving changes from the top enough 

Too much focus on delivery not enough on improvement

Disconnect between product and technology 

Old habits and delivery mechanisms 

Resistance to change from some parts 

Yo-yo decisions at mid level 

empire building not in line with actual business agenda 

Teams not fully supported

pros: It could be great if they deal with the cons and issues outlined in the advice to senior management.
cons: Prepared to be burnt out. "There are more people out there to stoke the fires!" Get a sponsor - being great at your job is not enough! Watch out for bad managers - grievances and staff turnover is high!

pros: The health insurance plans, benefits, and 401k are the best aspects of working for this this company. There is also the benefit of working around some very intelligent individuals.
cons:
applicable to operations teams at the company:

Poor pay
High stress
Low employee morale
Culture is very poor
Lack of gratitude from management
No positive reinforcement
Only acknowledgement when there are problems
High level of scrutiny
Promotion process and salary increase is poor …ex: very possible that you will make less than the team you manage bc you lose overtime and the adjustment for that loss is terrible
Inconsistent and unfair tuition reimbursement policy (discriminatory)
No company holiday parties
No group holiday parties
Poor management at most levels* (there are a handful of good managers who want you to succeed, and who are willing to take time and offer advice, however, these are the minority and you must generally seek them out)
Not somewhere to have a long career

review_title: Great culture, but not quite a top-tier bank yet
job_title: Investment Banking Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Barcap is a great place to work. While I was there, I met a lot of senior people who became very invested in my professional development and reached out to me throughout my time at the firm, even though I was only a summer analyst. Also, some of the groups are top on the street in their industry, including Natural Resources, Power, Communications & Media, and Retail.
cons: Depending on which group you're in, you may get limited deal experience compared to some of the better banks, including MS/GS.

job_title: Banking Office Executive in Glasgow, Scotland
pros: Colleagues and bosses were all very nice, they also allowed me to reduce my hours to accomodate my husbands shift hours.
cons: Position was not suitable due to a shift pattern which I was not required to do unless I remained as a permanent member of staff.  The job I had to do was very boring and tedious, however it was a means to an end and allowed me to look for other positions more suitable.  I found the department to be very unflexible with permanent staff members with regards to working hours which caused them to look elsewhere for jobs.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Reimbursed cabs, private cars; free meals; salary + bonus
cons: Hours; everyone was miserable; encourages culture of "drones"; After redesigning outdated systems/mechanisms that are used to provide support to my entire team with huge time saving enhancements as well as learning how to be a better analyst with regard to products/industries/financial valuation methodologies outside my direct scope, I was told that was a waste of time and just to focus on my little niche. Company is very outdated and old school with lots of hazing techniques embedded in the various groups. All the investment banks probably have this to some degree, but at least the others know how to pay employees and keep them from going to hedge funds / private equity.

job_title: IT Engineer in New York, NY
pros:
- Good work/life balance
- Supportive of activities outside of work (I was able to complete a graduate program while working full time)
- Generally nice people
cons:
- A lot of the smart, “go-getter” types of people have left; somehow the place is now full of people who are around to just collect a paycheck
- Lack of strategic direction, constant turnover of leadership and each new leader comes up with a strategy that is radically different from the previous one and basically teams have to abandon previous projects because there is a new pet technology to convert to; projects are constantly being decommissioned or converted to the new tech stack but never fully completed before a new leader comes along
- No opportunities for growth 
- Zero investment for training

pros: The cards business continues to grow. Base compensation is fair compared to the market.
cons: The culture within cards & payments is very toxic. The CIO reports into the COO, which means Technology is run like Ops. Senior management seems to think technology people  are exchangeable like people in  a call center. The focus is on people being in the office from 9-5, instead of looking at true outcomes. No flexibility for remote work. Although the cards business is doing well and growing, bonuses are down year after year after year. New management In Cards & Payments is looking for opportunities to move positions to India.

review_title: Used to be a good place to work.
job_title: Senior Associate in New York, NY
pros: Used to be Lehman and when it was Lehman, it was a much better place to work for. It hasn't had much layoff yet, which is a great thing, and your experience highly depend on which group you work.
cons: Some managers are downright nasty, mean and that is one of the reasons some people left the firm, most other mangers are fine. The compensation structure for associate is too fair, or unfair to put in another way. Every incoming associates are paid pretty much the same in the first two years, giving us no incentives to work hard as long as you don't worry about layoff. There is no difference between PhD and other associates in terms of promotion although they have called senior associates.

review_title: before the Lehman acquisition, it was great. Now it sucks
job_title: Vice President, IT in New York, NY
pros: Resume building. One of few companies to offer a pension
cons: The want to be bulge bracket but pay the minimum they can. They offer salary + "addition fixed pay" + tiny bonus. The effect of this is that they avoid UK taxes on bonuses, but do not need to commit to raising actual base pay and benefits based on it. Salaries have not be raised in IT for 3 years. Also by giving everyone "addition fixed pay" it reduces the abillity to differentiate between A and C employees. Raises in total comp to top employees was less than 2% for some departments -- not much different than C employees; Why work hard if there is no possibility of reward?

review_title: Badly run, too political, frequent turnover
pros:
Still in business (after 300 years)
Still hiring (occasionally)
Still has loyal clients (despite service and reputation issues)
Loads of compliance and "business management" jobs
cons:
Poor reputation due to recent revelations
Deaf & blind middle and senior management
Middle management churn (every 6 months)
Generally high staff turnover (due to employees leaving, not redundancies)
Too many generals, too few soldiers
Obsessed with internal meetings
Poor official communication - grapevine is primary source of information on everything
Senior management - seem allergic to direct interaction with rank and file

job_title: Senior Change Manager in Northampton, England
pros: Salaries are good as are benefits, which tend to be "golden handcuffs" when considering leaving
cons:
It has to be the most toxic culture I have ever worked in ever, senior management are too many levels away from the workface to understand that the functional processes are unusably complicated and ineffective.
Being politically correct is more important than being good at your work. It is a sad force fed culture that drives values that the company itself will disregard with impunity. A recent redundancy project at Barclaycard has been the most dire, shambolic and poorly executed process ever conceived and oh so poorly executed.
It is trying to transform itself but will have to shed layers of institutional stupidity to achieve the turn around envisioned

pros: Barclays definitely hire a 'type' for the branches- bubbly, friendly etc so you always find someone you can get along with
cons:
The self service machines have made a cashier's life hell. One till for ALL business customers and transactions over 750.00 is a joke. I worked in a self service bench for 5 days before handing in my notice. Customers (rightly) hate the new style and therefore set about making a cashiers life hell because they're miserable. 
Also- giving cashiers a 4% max pay rise for this is laughable. I'm going to a job which will increase my salary by 20%, better hours and paid overtime.
Overtime-a paid working day in Barclays is 9-5 with 1 hour lunch.Fine on paper but you are required to be at branch by 8.30am latest and are never paid overtime despite rarely leaving before 5.30PM.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: BREXIT aside, Barclays seems to have been ahead of other UK and European banks in adapting to the new normal of lack luster markets and regulatory overkill.    This should situate the company well while some its rivals have waited until now to go through the painful process of shedding non-core businesses and letting good people go
cons: The amount of turnover among senior managers over the past four years has made it confusing for staff.     Not only is there uncertainty about the direction of the firm, but often, it was hard to figure out who your business line reported up to.    Also, too many silly and wasteful directives from senior management which have almost nothing to do with the actual business at hand, but seem to justify the company's fees paid to consulting companies

pros: Large scale, always busy,  call center, 14 to 18 hour pay
cons: Accomodated school initially then stated they woukd not accomodate school any more.  Ultimately left work and decided to focus on school. You must fight harder then you ever have to get promoted, politics and from the inside to out, it looks like they judge you off personal lifr style  as part of the process.  2 well qualified candidates litterly tried 4 times within a year and got no wherr in management.  As for agents, you can move to different departments but moves are lateral in pay, hence you  feel great when you move on but in positions of greater responsibilty and pay its very rare.

pros:
Employees with various backgrounds all around
Very open to increasing self-awareness and enhancing team collaboration skills
Great culture
Incentivizes volunteering
People generally want to help others
Mistakes are forgiven 
Flexible work from home ability
On site health center 
Can easily shine because the department is smaller
Barclays pays less than competitors. May be for the better reputation you’re working for
cons:
Long hours on certain teams/lack of work life balance
Every changing methodology and addition of micromanaging tasks
Senior management tough on deadlines
Culture is not as great at the top
Bureaucracy 
US employees can feel like the disowned step child 
Impossible to get promoted on some teams since management looks for heavily seasoned individuals 
Too consumed with ad hoc work to take on meaningful projects that will actually get you recognized

review_title: Good place to work if interested in financial services in San Francisco
pros: Strong, profitable company that has opportunity to really grow admist troubled investment management industry.  There are also excellent benefits.  The salaries are average at best but the bonuses tend to make up for it and are above average for similar positions at other companies.  The new building is very nice and the company is very supportive of continuing education.
cons: Long work hours and flat organizational structure meaning few opportunities for advancement.  The company has grown faster than could be managed effectively and is now going through some growing pains.  There are a lot of fiefdoms which are all treated differently.  Think carefully about which division to join.

review_title: HR is terrible. Try to avoid the Graduate Program.
job_title: Associate On Graduate Program in London, England
pros: Great if you can land in a nice team; fairly good pay. Friendly people. Flat. Hours are manageable; there is a work life balance.
cons:
HR is bad. That's an understatement: they're terrible. Generally insensitive, stingy, and they make mistakes. See the rest of reviews for similar comments. 

Initial training program was horrendous. Classes sitting playing solitaire and minesweeper for a whole month. To save costs, HR outsourced the whole program to several different companies, hosted at a external training venue away from the offices. The trainers were sufficiently incompetent for whole classes to complain. Pointless make-work activities for filling the time. HR refused to pay travel costs for grads from foreign offices (!), such as airport to office transportation.

The whole experience was highly off-putting; and as a first experience to Barcap, terrible for morale.

review_title: Very profit driven company with some bad UK managers who dont deserve to be there
pros: Nice atmosphere, nice colleagues and independent work and responsibility
cons:
Top down communication is poor. Usually news are held back until the last minute which affects staff morale and lots of rumours are created
Lots of infighting between teams and country divisions. Favouritism is a problem

review_title: London office great, New York office not so great
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: The London office is full of outstanding professionals, creative thinkers who all adopt a collaborative approach to resolving clients needs. There is no concept of pushing sales through, the bottom line in the London office is to serve the needs of clients.
cons: The New York office, needs a lot of work. There is a consistent battle of client coverage and hard sales. Many people are unhappy and the environment is cut throat.

review_title: Going downhill fast, has potential if it turns around quickly.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: *Some* good work if you find yourself in one of the very few areas the organization is prepared to fund.
cons: Organization is going downhill. Qualified and knowledgeable staff are leaving, senior management are focusing in cost over any other metric. Obsessive outsourcing to low-cost centers and refusal to hire in high-cost locations are ripping apart teams and severely impacting ability to deliver. The business can't rely on IT to deliver solutions and major incidents happen on an almost daily basis. Firm is about as anti-meritocratic as you can get, promoting those in minority groups over ability.

pros: Good work/life balance with working form home and dynamic hours actively encouraged. Staff are nice people and respectful to each other. The push to ingrain the 5 values has had a positive impact.
cons: Below average pay for industry with the lack of financial success used as the justification, whether or not it had anything to do with you. The IT systems are poor following a prolonged period of under investment, although this is gradually improving. There is a suffocating level of bureaucracy, with whole cottage industries producing little of value for the firm except headcount problems. Senior management are often out of their depth and excessively deferential to regulators. Whilst staff may be individually pleasant there is frequent avoidance of responsibility, 'not my problem' is a phrase you will hear day in day out.

pros:
- Good salary, specially if you do overtime.
- Good work environment (depending on the team).
- It is easy to outperform peers if you put in the work. Many people are smart and good professionals but lack the motivation to put in the effort.

I was happy in my time in Barclays, moved on to role elsewhere.
cons:
- No training
- Some IT service operation teams are a joke (Unix, AD, Windows Server specially). Others such as SQL and Networks are pretty good.
- Some managers do quite a bit of micro managing attempting to climb the corporate ladder on your back. It is very obvious. 
- CEO lacks focus, has taken decisions which proved to be wrong, specially with regards to non-core disinvestment.

pros: Good name to put on a resume (maybe).
cons:
Every year people are supposed to have reviews with their managers and they are supposed to receive their salary increases and bonuses. NO SALARY INCREASES whatsoever, regardless of the long nights, constant pressure and stress, and increasing chaos. To add salt to the wound, BONUSES WERE INSULTING. It does not matter how efficient you are and how much you improve the processes and how well you work with others. Nothing matters because in the end YOU WILL NOT GET REWARDED FOR ANY HARD WORK. 

All management cares about is staying late, falsely assuming that more hours will result in more work being done. People are tired of this, which is why they are flying out of this firm. Morale is low. Compensation is worse than any other bank. Talent is moving on to better firms, that's for sure. 

If you want to love your job, don't come here. You will not only hate your job here, you will also hate your life.

review_title: Overall not a bad place to work
pros:
Never a dull moment - some of the antics I have witnessed during my time here have been second to none.  Both by management and colleagues. 

Good name to have on the CV  - have found this has opened up many doors to move to other banking institutions and start ups.

Some areas of the bank are really at the forefront of innovation.  If you are lucky enough to work in one of these areas, you can have a very fulfilling career.
cons:
Too much change - the bank as a whole never appears to be in a steady state.  Strategy, goal, direction and people constantly seem to be changing.  This creates a constant state of fear amongst some colleagues.

Compensation could be better and the policy could be more transparent.  Difficult to determine the link between workplace performance and compensation.

job_title: Human Resources in New York, NY
pros: It's a great company to have on your resume.  You are exposed to a range of personalities and are really prepared to deal with cut throat atmospheres.
cons: Unfortunately, incomplete employees were easily elevated to VP and even SVP status just because they sucked up to the right people.  I literally was spoon feeding my VP information on how to do her job and it was absolutely frustrating.  Whenever I thought I would be next in line for more responsibility or a better title, I was passed on by the cheekier and talkative alternative that had no idea what they were doing.

review_title: Great Place for Technology (Technology Center in McKinney, TX)
pros: Competitive salaries (sort of - you can always find better salaries in technology elsewhere). Great benefits, including medical, dental, matching 401K. Very talented technology workers. These are some of the smartest techies you will ever work with. Very laid back open office, collaborative culture.
cons: Barclays, as one of the big banks who have been fined continuously by regulators, have had to make some cuts. Tech workers are being re-located to Delaware, the UK and India. Sad, but when the company loses its technology visionaries to other companies, and things get financially challenging for the board, cuts easily find its tech areas. Wrong focus, in my opinion. Also, so much politics with an old UK financial institution.

pros: Family leave (maternity/paternity) is good offering 4 months to mothers and 1 month to fathers. Worklife balance is decent.
cons: Relocating thousands of people to Whippany, NJ because upper management couldn’t fulfill this request at their prior bank. Would have employees travel for 3 hours just to keep their jobs.

review_title: Most unprofessional firm I have ever worked at
pros: Free cab transport service, Free 1 time food, Infrastructure is good, Work life balance is above average.
cons:
Not sure where to start. Almost everything about this company is bad.

1. Very unprofessional - Most of the employees and therefore the culture are unprofessional. They hire just anyone and everyone. Hiring of relatives is common.
2. The current senior leadership (Indian) are average joe (without good background) and therefore the culture has worsened a lot.
3. Favoritism and partiality is very visible. You need to have much more than good work ethics to move up the ladder.
4. In the name of diversity and women-power, many undeserving and incapable women employees have been elevated to senior position.

It is no surprise that good senior leaders have already left (and are leaving) this company.

pros: Learned alot of the ongoings and processes involved with credit cards, had potential to move to new departments early on. Management was great and you were punished harshly for mistakes,  but rather corrected and educated.
cons: The cons come from the silence of corporate.  They promote this idea of togetherness and hippy garbage but remain silent to it's own people when  times seem troubled. A hiring freeze for over a year with no ability to relocate to another position,  being told we are not closing and then watching, without warning, 5 or so managers get walked out. I know its business and these thing happen. But do not lie and stay silent to your people.  Allow us the time needed to start preparing  for the future if in fact the location is to close.

pros: Decent salary, fun colleagues, casual dress, satisfactory benefits (tho not as such as two years ago as now my contribution is twice what it was).
cons: No advancement opportunities, the "Agile" environment is a pressure cooker of chaos and finger pointing, work / life balance WAS superior - but now becoming another hoop to jump through so that you understand that if you want time off or need to work from home for a day, you should feel properly guilty about it.

pros: Barclays has some really great people that come to work and give it their all and want to do good job.  The company is generally supportive of flexible work arrangements and a lot of emphasis is placed on giving back to the community.  Internal mobility is encouraged and people do move internally fairly easily.
cons: The organization is very convoluted and very often there is a lack of clear ownership and accountability which make decision making difficult.  Advancement to the Director and Managing Director levels is very subjective and based on who you know and who likes you rather than accomplishments.  Internal systems are antiquated and need upgrading.  Finally, depending on what area of the bank you join eventually your team may be transferred to Whippany, NJ.

review_title: One of the worst experiences of my life.
job_title: Credit Risk Associate in Coventry, England
pros:
Parking was available.
There was a pension scheme.
cons:
I was based in Coventry Westwood business park personal risk. This was my first job after leaving University.
It was just a really horrible place to work. I think you would call it a culture of 'passive aggressive' bullying now.
Memories of this was an office whereby nobody spoke to anyone. Silence was the norm for the whole day.
My job was to in effect understudy a contractor with the intention of taking over her job! She who didn't want to lose her job. This put me in a very awkward position.
She reported to the head of the department that I couldn't  do my job with my inevitable dismissal due to incompetence. It took me a while to get my confidence and career back on track. I don't think I will ever truly recover from it.

pros:
- Conveniently located near New York city
- Opportunities for international travel (if you are lucky)
- Good work life balance
- Some teams/managers are good to work with
cons:
- No clear path for career advancement and growth
- Management doesn't care for employee development and training
- Some managers are good number crunchers, but extremely immature when it comes to people management
- Out of the box thinking is extremely limited
- Back-office feel, bit disconnected from day-to-day business action overseas
- Performance evaluation process is not very transparent, and big time faviouratism exists. Brown nosing is your biggest asset, team players are not recognized.
- Extremely vertical management structure, where senior management is not very approachable

job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Most of the people I have met are very helpful. Great health benefits, 401k match.
cons: Promotion process is unclear and completely different depending on the area of the bank you work in. There are seemingly people with titles who shouldn't have them as they don't do anything, or know what you would expect them to know for having that title. Executive management does not appear to have a pulse on all the negative sentiment that exists internally. Not a fun place to work. Direct mgmt seemingly doesn't care about it's staff. It's not a growing company, it's a shrinking one.  No raises for years. Seemingly impossible to get an interview internally without knowing someone. HR is the worst. They are slow to respond: to queries, job submissions, etc. completely unhelpful.

pros:
Salary and benefits
Flexible working
People - very bright, work well under pressure, consistently positive can-do attitudes, teamwork 
Leadership - some are inspiring and the team has a strong desire to remove obstacles for people and embed values, there are actions in progress to improve things and visible actions being taken to make it happen.
cons:
Very inefficient I.T. that doesn't keep up with the pace and volume of work
Hugely hierarchical approach leading to things being harder to get done than they should be (leadership are working on this though)
Lack of opportunity for progression (again being worked on), can feel like promotion is based on how successfully you massage egos over ability.
Lots of middle management and too many people doing the same thing.
The amount of Senior stakeholders involved in decisions teams beneath them slows things up and can cause inefficiency.

review_title: Find an alternate if you are young and bright
pros:
1. Work culture : Most of the people in the firm are nice and friendly. They will help you if needed.
2.  Work/life balance: Its a great place if you have a growing family or have lot of commitments outside work. Although, you will be busy most of the time, the work wont kill you and should have enough time for personal life
cons:
1. SHrinking industry: Finance and Barclays overall are shrinking and its not a good place to be if you have just started your career.
2. It's probably still a good place for investment bankers but not so much for technology graduates.  Top IT candidates usually find another job in a year.
3. No career opportunities since the senior guys wont leave and no new opportunities to grow.

review_title: Barclays Capital is a great environment for those who want to work hard and progress their careers
pros: Barclays Capital offers a professional and friendly working environment, good opportunities for career progression and internal mobility.  I have worked for them 4 times longer than at any other employer in my career and this is entirely due to the variety of roles I have performed during this time and the opportunities offered to me.
cons: As with most investment banks, the hours can be hard.  However, that's pretty much a matter of personal choice.  Also, they can be pretty ruthless when it comes to "poor" performance.  It's a fairly regular occurrence for the bottom 10 per cent to be cleared out

review_title: Good pay, rising prestige, poor industry outlook, non-existant culture.
pros: The company is getting more prestigious, especially after its acquisition of Lehman Brothers. Pay is pretty good as well. There will be good exit opportunities.  The people are also generally nice - management has a no jerk policy.
cons: The firm still has not found its culture. It really depends group to group due to the small size of each group. Job security is also at an all time low - they recently laid off 3000 jobs. Hours are extremely rough although they vary from group to group, which is to be expected in the investment banking industry.  Hours for banking probably average 85 hours a week.

pros: I joined not so long ago, and from my perspective the goods sides so far were: a very decent grad program, good sign on bonus and base salary. Currently this is one of few banks that are hiring, so hopefully we willl have a bit more employment stability in the nearest future. The bank was not as severely  hit as others, and some traditionally strong desks in IR, FX are making lots of money. The perks for those still employed as i know are in line with all I-banks, though the workload is somewhat less.
cons: Some desks encounter annoyingly large ammount of IT issues, and sometimes tools you use are whatever you had created yourself. But this is improving (so fastly that sometimes I wonder how did they work 2 or 3 yrs ago). Most of jobs are not intellectually challenging (as in all banks I guess).

job_title: IT Consultant in Jersey City, NJ
pros: It comes with great pay (Corp to Corp). I  have the pleasure of working with many talented individuals, and it offers flexible work-life balance(depending on the group with which you're assigned).
cons: their internal processes are horrid.  2 weeks to get a computer?  a month+ to get a phone?  There's no real way to track down where a request is in order to chase, it's all in general mailboxes so you never know who should be working on something.  They've changed ticketing systems for datacenter work twice since I've been working here and did not document it or notify anyone.  The systems are so convoluted that they take several tries to submit a simple firewall change as zero documentation exists..

review_title: No longer a premiere financial firm to work in
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Working from home is allowed.
cons: Too much bureaucracy and office politics get in the way of people actually getting work done.  Morale is very low especially with the 'Bad Bank' announcement as people feel unsettled not knowing when they'll be next to be cut.  Too much restructuring going on and the feeling is nothing at Barclays is ever stable.  Lots of budget cuts and as a result hiring is also limited.  Bonus and raise have been horrendous the last few of years.  Only higher ups are getting bonuses which is not fair as it's the doers that get the job done, not management.

review_title: An environment that is stuck to convention - junior Director level utterly resistant to change and improvement.
pros: Compensation is ok and some of the senior management are extremely good.
cons: What senior executives want to achieve and change, is halted by a bureaucratic layer of institutional lethargy and denial.  The junior Director level is overpopulated with individuals who are simply hanging on for a pension.  The Bank is constantly trying to change and evolve, but is continually dragged back by dinosaurs who don't like to be held to account - the culture remains: 'bowler hats and typewriters'.

pros:
1. More autonomy as compared to service industry.
2. Good bonus
3. Barclays care about it's community services and include it in employees appraisal objectives also.
4. Appraisal system is fair
5. Opportunities to contribute are emmense
6. Provides opportunities to switch team / profile internally by Internal Job Portal
7. Barclays advocates a lot for 'Values'
8. It's a brand
cons:
1. Work culture is changing rapidly and moving towards service industry work culture
2. Roles and responsibilities are not clear. 'You touch it, you own it' is the funda here
3. Less recognition
4. Takes a long time for promotion internally (exceptions are always there)
5. Rare onsite opportunities
6. Vendors (service industry partners like Infosys, CG etc.) are given more onsite opportunites
7. Co-ordination challenges between Barclays permanent employees and vendors
8. Dead slow systems and red tapism
9. Extra-ordinary expectations without providing tools and training
10. High work load. Many people work more than half of there weekends in the year

pros: you get staff loans at a discounted rates
cons:
1. Subjective appraisal system: you can be downgraded in your performance because you are introverted. 
2. Nitpicky and irrational bosses who call you in for a performance review within first two weeks on the job because of "not contributing in meetings". 
3. Low salaries contributing to high incidences of staff defrauding customers or engaging in unethical work practices. 
4. Unprincipled work colleagues who gang up and conspire against someone to get rid of them. 
5. Overlapping salaries: some staff in lower grades earn more than staff in higher grades thus demotivating people from getting a promotion.
6. Appalling work conditions at branches: torn carpets, worn out seats, broken down ventilators' claustrophobic back offices.
7. Egotistical management team that looks down on subordinates and suppresses them
8. Exploitation of lead generators (LGs): deprived of travel and call allowance and hence sometimes have to borrow money from the branch manager in order to visit customers

pros: Great environment and work/life balance.   Used to be the top of reward packages but have definitely declined in last five years.
cons: Where to start.  The main issue is that Barclays changes on what sometimes feels like a fortnightly basis and internal empires are constantly being fought, won and lost by execs.  The constant change is never ending and causes so much stress and uncertainty within what can sometimes be a hostile working environment.  If you challenge or speak up, your career has ended...it boasts about values but breaks every one as an organisation.

review_title: Awful, bullying, poor coms, incompetent leaders, dead wood
pros:
Great pay!

If you are a professional and you would like to work in a place with other like-minded professionals to progress your career do not work here.
cons:
Being led my dear old ladies that have been there years that are just interested in the 50k bonus they will be awarded if they employ the right contractors to do the work for them. 

"Leadership team", subtext for privately run cartel ensuring objectives are met to meet bonus requirements.

Institutional bulling from leadership teams by dictation, they don't really care how the work is completed just whether it is going to be on time for them.

Two of the "leadership team" were having an affair and kept leaving work early together for a quick sh%g - both married with children.

The company seems to be obsessed with ramming LGBT values down your throat but then openly bully individuals on there personal appearance - "if the face doesn't fit"

review_title: Higher Apprenticeships offer rapid progression and long-term career opportunities
pros: The organisation believes in and invests in employee development. The Higher Apprenticeships enable employees to gain academic qualifications at the same time as working in a number of roles across the business, setting the apprentice up for a successful career in the business. Balance between role based work and academic work is supported by regular study leave.
cons: As a caveat to the above, progression in the retail bank is limited if you are not part of a training / rapid development programme. By comparison to other HA schemes, pay starts in line with the market rate but does not progress at the same speed as some others.

pros:
Good sales experience 
Engagement with management
Decent holidays
Private healthcare is most certainly a plus, previously through AXA may have changed
Personally lucky enough to have a great team
Absolutely fantastic branch manager
Like in many industries, if you spend 10 years here you can have an okay career. But where can't you have a good career after 10 years?
cons:
Dependent on location - very busy 
Management can often be on power trip
Assistant managers on power trip
Area Directors act as if they're investment banking CEOs.
Management insist sales are not based on targets, but will question why you aren't reaching targets
Assistant managers on power trip
Assistant managers on power trip
Worst assistant managers ever. 
Do not spend more than 12 months in this role, much better opportunities elsewhere

review_title: Great quant shop, cares for its employees
job_title: Research Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: If  you are looking for a fun place to work in San Francisco, this is the place to be. This may be the only firm outside of NYC that has a broad coverage of asset classes (fized income, equities, forex) and geographical regions. The investment process is scientific, there are no superstars and no epiphanies, the ideas are tested and backtested to ensure the economic merit of the decisions.  A spunky new building in the financial district, good technology support and freedom to innovate.
cons: Your day at work starts at 5:30 am or earlier for some folks but then you also scoot off from work early.

pros: BGI is a well known industry name and brings with it a lot of prestige. Its Transition Management group is particulary well regarded. The overall compensation package is good, but by no means industry leading, having said that you are well looked after and when recognition is given the bonus package can be quite substantial.
cons: The organistion as a whole is a victim of its own success, it that it suffers from unnecessary bureacracy, and more often than not your career within the organisation tends to be based on sideways movement rather than upward progression. There is also little chance to make your ideas and opinions heard and communication regarding the corporate strategic goals, barring 'Lyndsey's Blog', is not often forthcoming.

review_title: Baclays is a great place to work at.
pros: Excellent firm culture; most people enjoy working together and achieving common goals; not too much of hierarchy, and easy to speak to these in decision-making positions; and overall, the people team is very good. There are also great benefits; volunteer opportunities; social events. There is gym. Always able to take time off when necessary.
cons: Sometimes too much of unnecessary paper-pushing that delays getting work done. Red tape needs to be reduced to a reasonable level. Management does not always take the time to really know what the subordinates need. Important issues like advancement and growth need to be addressed in more detail. People sometime not sure what they will get from the job down the road.

review_title: Too bad Lehman went bankrupt and Barcap's second rate cuture took over
job_title: M&A Analyst in New York, NY
pros: - Able to do a smooth transition fairly smoothly after Lehman bankruptcy
cons:
- Letting some of Barcap's side management to run areas where Lehman Brothers was clearly a lot better at and therefore Barcap should've let ex Lehman people to run it. 
- Horrible culture, Barcap doesn't understand how a top notch investment bank is run 
- Nobody really cared about Barcap, but when you mention "Ex Lehman" then we get the deals 
- Trying to do everything very cheapl, some top notch Lehman support departments which was essential to us in M&A  were cut in exchange for cheaper Indian outsourcing firms which was a total disaster to get everything done.

review_title: I worked for a subsidiary of Barcap and had a reporting relationship up to Barcap.  This review relates to that.
job_title: Information Technology Manager in Sacramento, CA
pros: The compensation was good.  At a high level - top of the house - they were savvy strategists.  At the front line level workers were competent and cooperative.   Mid and upper level management was lacking.
cons: There was constant turnover and reorganization with Barcap.  We'd establish relationships with technical team members only to find them terminated seemingly at random.  Time after time.  Our direct senior leader was ineffective, only concerned with political issues perhaps out of necessity since survival seemed to be hinged upon political alliances.  Considerable dysfunction was the norm.

review_title: Good rotation program in analyst class for sales and trading but learning ends soon
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: Compensation and benefits package and a foot in the door. Best training program on wall street pre Lehman merger. Was great to start here
cons: Always threatened to get fired. High turnover rate and firing w/o warning. Hassle to take a day off for dr visits and healthcare. No ability to move groups once placed after rotations. Stuck in role and executing trades. No sales experience with clients in person no training for the next level after Yeats Of being in a junior role. Line managers care about themselves and not training their juniors well

job_title: Operations Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Great company to start your career at if you are in the graduate or internship programs. You are grouped together with a number of people around your age, which made the transition into the corporate world a lot easier. The employee networking events were great too, with a wide variety of attendees typically ranging from analysts to VPs.

The company hires people with similar personalities, which is great because you can make friends easily.
cons:
Limited career growth and lack of internal mobility. I found that HR really did nothing if any issues come across. 

They also need to screen managers better. It's pretty much like Russian roulette when you move to a new group, you either get an understanding and supportive manager, or  you get one of the screamers. 

HR should really listen to their employees and work with them rather against them for internal moves.

review_title: If you are early in your career, go somewhere else if possible
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great work and life balance because there is not much work, reason see below.
cons:
Barclays has a culture that doesn't  care about personal growth and employee happiness.  The entire management is plagued with such culture.  The upper management cares about themselves than anything else. Fun fact,  in one of the townhalls CEO came to stage and talked how recent Barclays stock plummet made him lost millions of dollars and vowed to bring the stock back to where it should be. 99.9% of people down there didn't give a **** because they have zero ownership about Barclays.

The end result is the bottom level  of the company structure is filled with incompetent people content with pay and work (or not work for the matter of fact). Everything moves at glacier pace with layers of bureaucracy. 

If you are in early of your career, regardless of your job (trader, IBD, developer, operations), and you want to learn and achieve something, Barclays is not the place for you.

review_title: Not paid enough for the role.
pros: Good training provided at the start for two weeks. The environment can be great if the right management is placed.
cons: The company and promotional opportunities is not as progressive as they put it. There are jobs going but they only hire people they have in mind so you’re literally just applying to get rejected. Had a big management change in April 2019 and since then it’s gone downhill. Employees are not treated fairly and over worked. The staffing is a joke and they don’t have enough staff to cope with the pressures. The job itself is not the paying enough compare to the work employees do and promotion is just promised just so the employee remain in job and carry on working.

review_title: Mediocre learning, you can learn more and get paid more elsewhere.
job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Access to analyst reports was nice, and there's access to some information that you can read. You can print free books offline to read. Also, the job was very easy, no real stress, just a lot of guys around you who are stressed. I finished my work in 1-2 hours every day, spent the rest of the day reading, and still got props for "working late". 

If you are looking for a stable job in technology, go ahead and do this. Innovation, technical awesomeness, satisfaction, cutting edge technology? Look elsewhere.
cons: No real good mentors for learning good coding practices, nobody to help you out on math, most managers I spoke to weren't too smart. This is one of the worse banks for benefits and for knowledge, hence the reason most ppl move out to better banks.

pros: Strong pay for performance ethic albeit that non-tranparent/discretionary bonuses meant you didnt actually know from one year to the next how you'd be paid. Some areas had strong HR leadership and direction. Knows where it wants to go but is too big to get there
cons: Constant management (and therefore agenda) change. Revolving door for good quality people due to personal issues rather than delivery of work. No ethics. Mates rates for bonus levels. Not honesty or integrity around decision making. Strongly hierarchical.

pros: Job Security, brand name - long standing institution. Good clients
cons: Poor quality of leadership/management.  No consistent business strategy - managers/leaders cannot clearly articulate the business vision or strategy.  Lack of accountability from senior management - they do not clearly communicate how they've delivered or failed against their objectives.  Extremely political culture - you will do well if you become your manager's favourite in terms of bonus & performance.  Values are stated but not practised or adhered to - managers at all levels especially at MD levels fail to be a role model.  It appears MD's and D's aren't  held accountable by senior management to deliver on their objectives - deadlines and timlines are constantly pushed out - there is minor consequence if you don't deliver on time. Lower grade employees aren't always respected by senior management.  There is a real issue at line manager levels across the organisation. Culture promotes mediocracy.

review_title: Commercial bank style, more concerned about cutting cost, less concerned about technology innovation.
job_title: Developer in Kwun Tong, Kowloon City
pros: Stable company, large organization, plenty of learning resources, internal mobility. Top executives seem to know what they are doing. The company has been doing good through the financial crisis compared to other investment banks.
cons: Internal IT support is very inefficient, everything take a long time and nobody seem to care. A lot of beauracracy, have to open a HPSC ticket to get anything done across teams. Management is not doing a good job interms of vertical communication. A lot of integration pain is still going on even more than one year after the merge with Lehman Brothers. A lot of politics  and cultural clash between the two sides, and they have lost quite some talents.

review_title: The first year was really good, then things changed.
job_title: Senior Developer in New York, NY
pros:
The building was really nice, The salary was very competitive. Benefits were good.
There were no set hours. I was given work and given a lot of freedom to do it. The system was well designed and there were plenty of smart people. The atmosphere was pretty good.
cons: My boss did not want to be bothered and sometimes would not answer emails. Some of the problems that occurred in the system were really tough to solve and not reproducible and no help was given.  My team and colleagues were friendly but I rarely went out to lunch or after work with them. Typical drones. I was laid off after a year and a half. They have had some rough times and laid off tens of thousands of people. People were really nervous when lay off were happening.

job_title: Head of Digital Content in New York, NY
pros:
People are great and genuinely want to be different. I've found excellent support in my career (I've had 2 promotions in 4 years), and enjoy the work and projects.

The building in Northampton has just finished internal renovations, and has cool break out areas and lots of colaborative space. 

The pay and perks are good, too.
cons: The men's changing rooms are pretty dire. There's far too many people than space allows. It's all well and good promoting cycle to work / lunch runs etc., but improve the facilities. Also lack of gym!

review_title: Good place for college grads and to stay invested for 5 years
pros:
1. Good working environment
2. Less work pressure, hence employees can complete additional studies
3.  Lot of flexibility for women employees
4. Learning opportunities depends on team and regional stakeholders
5. Good place for seasoned  employees wherein they can have good work life balance
6. Good brand to start with for college grads
cons:
1. Would not recommend prospective employees to stay beyond 5 years (at max).
2. Less scope for learning as things move very slow (compare it with any Indian PSU).
3. Quality of work done out of Mumbai location is not at par with other IB's such as MS, CS & DB.
4. Pay is sub par to the extent that even Nomura pays better than Barclays.
5. Nepotism is visibly present. IITians are praised and taken care like god.

review_title: VIP culture, no one cares if an employee is overutilized
pros:
1. Big MNC 
2. If you have good relationship with your manager you can enjoy without doing anywork
cons:
1. Earlier it was BTCI, now it is Barclays global service centre. Only name is changed but everything else remains same
2. Managers enjoy without doing any technical work
3. There is full VIP culture and no open door policy. So if you are joining here please keep in mind do not talk to your AVP's VP's directly about your problems. 
4. No one bothers if a resource is utilized for more than 100%. There is no proper work distribution. 
5. Since manager here are only doing unnecessary things hence they are not involved in any technical tasks. They cannot help you technically

pros: Lovely campus site. Flexibility to work from home if your boss happens to be in London.
cons: Bullshit-ocracy. Bluster, and busyness get you noticed, not delivering anything worthwhile, or doing a good job, just get involveed in as much as possible, make as much noise as you can and deliver nothing. Promotions are dead mans shoes during downsizing. Middle management feel threatened, so unless you're one of them, you'll never get ahead.

job_title: Client Service Analyst in Glasgow, Scotland
pros:
- Supportive & helpful colleagues
- Opportunity to partake in citizenship events
- Ever changing workload
cons:
- Management (BA4's & AVP's) extremely defensive & unapproachable
- Very high attrition rates as visible through staff turnover
-  High levels of favouritism (i.e. ad-hoc holidays being approved,  progression opportunities,  end of year grade being strong or outstanding)
- Colleagues who do the exact same role and get the same workload sitting next to each other with a 6k+ wage difference

pros:
Competitive pay, benefits schemes, fabulous location.
Employability - if you can do it here, you can do it anywhere!
cons: “Job for life” mentality means lots of people who’ve been in the same role for a long time and are more resistant to change than most. Excessive governance and regulation makes delivering work at pace almost impossible.

review_title: Good place to work if you can dominate and not be bullied.
pros: Amount of responsibility given is quite good, and is satisfying. There is a lot of autonomy available if you can take it, and can show that you have the initiative to take things and make them work better.
cons: Lack of respect by senior employees to junior ones. There is a lot of attitude around "I'm a VIP. Everybody else is here only to jump when I say jump". And the worse thing is that lot of jerks do get away with it. There is also a need to suck up to bosses, to have any hopes of making it bigger here.

pros: A cooperative culture. Flexible and family friendly. Big push towards Agile and Lean Working practices. Broad range of flexible benefits.
cons: Some working environments (office spaces) are not very comfortable. This isn't a place to work if you are looking for job security. Strategy changes frequently which can lead to anyone being surplus to requirements. Redundancy benefits are not what they used to be and notice is not paid in lieu so you won't get paid if you move straight into another role.

review_title: Stay away if you can't do mediocrity
pros:
Flexible working
If you have a good team you will get support
Diverse in some parts
cons:
Encourages mediocrity
Bureaucratic, very political and lots of red tape
HR and HRBPs especially only care about senior people and encourage poor treatment of colleagues, HR does not stand up to the business
If you are really clever and dynamic you will suffer here, Barclays is all about pointless process and lack of creativity
Pay is poor, your compensation is a mystery and you are feed none-sense about market mapping yet no one can give you any data or will have a direct conversation
The IB is still treated like the star child even though its contribution to profit is laughable

review_title: Dead-end Job. Thank God I'm out!
pros: Great interview process where Barclays spend a lot of money wining and dining prospective applicants during their assessment centres. Once you've joined Barclays, there are many quality events and socials and decent orientation/ training. Good pay compared with competitors for graduate/ entry level roles. Great Canary Wharf headquarters.
cons: Not very bright people/ colleagues, with many from polytechnic (or similar standard) universities. Very hierarchical management where creativity is stifled. And finally the role was an absolute dead-end job. Don't get into Operations (or Technology or any Back office role for that matter), as you do a lot of menial tasks for average pay with no future career prospects (other than to continue working Back Office).

pros: Everyone you talk to will tell you that the culture at BGI is great.  For the most part, the culture is fair and respectful.  There are not a lot of "investment banking" types walking around the hallways.  If you have a good idea, it will be heard and BGI will give you enough leeway to pursue an idea.
cons: It can be tough to make a lateral move from one group to the next.  Whatever group you're in, you tend to stay in that group for a very long time.  Also, I've heard people say that there are too many PhD types running the business when there should be more MBA types.  Leave the research up to the PhDs and the business management to the MBAs.

review_title: Great staff, let down by poor senior management
pros: Some very knowledgeable colleagues and most people want to do the right thing.  Work-life balance is generally good (and supported) as are staff benefits.  Citizenship agenda supports working with the community.
cons: Constant change in leadership and arrogant assumption that previous structure must have been wrong as it was devised by somebody else means strategy changes with the wind. Heavily political which makes it hard to avoid taking sides (risky due to changing leadership). Culture has changed in recent years to a more American mercenary one. Poor morale with most staff unsure whether they will be employed still by the end of the year.

review_title: The staff are vital and in the branch network so much work and effort goes into ensuring they are well equipped
pros: Benefits offered by the company from share saving schemes- to life assurance. I'm finding it very difficult to find another company that will offer me something similar. The people you work with become your family! You spend so much time with everyone in and outside work. All my managers have been fantastic. Very understand and most importantly trustworthy and honest.
cons: Long working day for managers- other will always get their lunches. Technology glitches get in the way and you are then frontline to customers! Planning is great but so much change can happen and you need adjust and adapt quick!

job_title: Learning And Development Consultant in Bradford, England
pros:
- lots of career opertunties 
-fantastic people
-open and honest culture 
-invited to be yourself and not a false corporate drone 
-strong LBGT values and creating diversity 
-directors are approachable 
-big supporters of mental health and I've had first had experience of this and always being made to feel like it's me first and business second 
-low turn over of staff
-pension, private health, bonuses
cons:
-when moving role your forced to stay in role 12 months which can be negative on the employee and the business if roles turn out not to be right 
-priorities change fast which can result in work and projects being scrapped, it would be nice for input to be acknowledged 
-retail roles involve working longer than contracted hours but the team culture makes up for it

review_title: small company feel but great ambitions
pros:
intelligent people who want to get on with the job in hand 
on the whole there is flexibility and understanding about work life balance 
comp is Ok , but not the best - often its the relationships within the company that keep people
cons:
benefits are not great when compared to some other financial institutions
schism between London and and San  Fran to the point where you do not have a career unless you are in SF. This leads to a one sided view of the world
there is a tendency of some who have been at BGI for a long time to want their way to win out rather than work as part of the team - often very detrimental to the ompany

job_title: Client Reporting in San Francisco, CA
pros: I worked at BGI over 10 years. It was a wonderful place to work. Now has been bought by BlackRock and a much diminished company. It was a fairly flat organization and very innovative, progressive in policy, great benefits and the smartest coworkers one could hope to have. You worked hard, sometimes to the detriment of your personal life, but it was often worth it and there was a real feeling of accomplishment, support of the firm, and camaraderie.
cons: There were glass ceilings and limited opportunities at BGI at times. In some departments, getting ahead was dependent more on who you knew and how you appeared than your actual talent.

pros: Pick up and drop facility available along with one meal in a day., discipline in terms of process adherence is followed as far as quality is concerned there is no two way communication that makes the Job monotonous and boring.
cons: There is enough to earn in terms of incentives however teams don't work together to achieve common goal individualism persist which gives a perception of groupism in between.

pros: good salary, good benefits and very good social life - a lot of team outings - you can find very good friends there
cons:
Working at Barclays as an IT is extremly boring. The expectations at the interviews are high and only few pass it, so they recruit high skilled professionals and then let them do a work that a high school student would be able to cope with.

The Indian support (RTB) teams (both in India or UK) are awful, they hire incompetent juniors - for example for the unix support they hire people who never used the OS.

The meritocracy they advertise all the time doesn't really exist. The politics is the only key and if you want good bonuses, you need to be friend with your boss. The chances for being promoted or moved overseas are close to zero.

review_title: No Consideration for Mental Health - its just lip service
pros: the people! some of your colleagues are amazing and the long timers have an amazing wealth of knowledge. Regular pay and holidays aren't bad once you've been there a while
cons:
Managers that cant manage, they employ their friends and rally the troops against people, if you stand up for yourself you're seen as a trouble maker. No support from line managers, they don't defend you against staff or analysts, you're undermined at every angle. When you defend yourself against the subordinate staff, whatever the 'issue' its ALWAYS your fault. 

Rubbish wages for the expected work levels and a general lack of support and consideration for middle management.

Bullied while off sick with mental health issues caused by work bullying from B6's and B7 - constant barrage of calls at home and when a complaint was made by the health company nurse, it was ignored. I ended up leaving.

review_title: Shadiest business practices I've ever seen
pros: Base pay higher than other call centers
cons: Terrible management, no job security, soul sucking

review_title: Secure job, but not very interesting
pros: Most people I worked with were talented and easy to get along with (those straight out of public accounting firms once qualified). Once you are employed there, it's quite secure (at least at head office location). Compared to public accounting, the hours are tolerable and there was NO weekend working at all within our planning department, so good for work / life balance.
cons: To progress within the bank, it is VERY political and there is generally a lot of bureaucracy. I did not receive encouragement from my line manager regarding future opportunities within the team - basically, unless he leaves, there is nowhere for me to progress, which is a drawback of having a small team and a limited budget for promotions / headcount.

pros:
- You get a bi-weekly paycheck.  
- A few of the employees are good to work with.
cons:
- One of the most political environments that I've worked in. Hard work is punished/taken advantage of by other employees trying to get credit for doing nothing. 

- So much red tape to get anything accomplished. Most times filling out forms or getting approvals takes 2-3 times the amount of time it takes to do the actual work. 

- Wall Street bonuses are non-existent here. Over my tenure I never received a bonus or raise, ever. I got a lot of excuses why it was a down year for the company though.

- Promotions are also non-existent here, even for lower level titles. The process was constantly changing/unclear and nobody seemed to understand how it worked. 

- Unclear company direction due to the multiple fines/lawsuits. 

- Multiple rounds of layoffs.

pros:
Good work-llife balance. 
Better pay as compared to service companies.
Flexible timings. No need to strictly clock 9 hours as in service companies.
Stable and continuous work unlike service companies where you don't know where your next project is going to come from or who will be your next client. Single client who is Barclays.
Encouragement for extra activities such as Community initiatives in addition to work.
Posh facilities such as Breakout area, TVs for watching matches and news even while working (!) and Workspaces.
There will be many vendors like Cognizant, Infosys. So we get a good vendor management experience.
Tech-savvy Bank, so we get work on the latest technologies and methodologies. 
Encouragement for celebrating Fun events.
cons:
Less job stability as compared to service companies, but redundancy happens only at high levels such as director and above.
Single Client , so exposure could be less.
Limited onsite opportunities.

pros: I was treated really well when I started and got the appropriate training from some really supportive people. I found the benefits package to be really good too, especially the private healthcare.
cons: I know this differs across different branches, however I find that the management in my branch is very self centred, I find it very difficult to approach them about things. There is a very toxic atmosphere in the workplace, you can be moved branch very quickly with minimal notice so everyone is treading on eggshells. They have a strong emphasis on development and career progression, however when I have tried to express my willingness to move on, I am met with false promises of help and nobody really seems to care. I used to really enjoy the job but now I find it incredibly boring and generally not enjoyable.

review_title: good place to work if you want to be there for life
pros:
Flexible working in some teams
