Great office - 1 Churchill Place
Go in at the right level and it's a good place to work - you can progress
Graduate scheme people are well thought of in industry
cons:
Lack of growth - Retail Bank is stagnant - and its all about managing a portfolio - no NPD
ITS ALL ABOUT REPORTING - decks, decks, decks, MI, MI, MI, (yawn)
Lack of proffesional people there- too many people who have worked their way up to a B6 level with no ideas, no passion and are just corporate bods
A lot of Americans - by this I mean Americans are brought over on huge relocation packages at B7 level - why not internally develop/promote

review_title: Experience highly dependent on team, very old-school and top heavy
job_title: Junior Trader in New York, NY
pros:
better hours than most US peers
better opportunities for juniors because of high turn over
cons:
Very hard to retain junior talent, graduate either has left or looking to leave, which says a lot about the culture
Very few people is willing to teach, so with minimum training, management expect juniors to perform and work hard lol
No transparency at all and highly hierarchical, you just do what they say
part of the reason we have better hours is they don't pay us as well...
Admittedly good traders are generally bad managers and unpleasant personalities, there are still a couple of good people, key is to get into those teams.

review_title: Local team camaraderie and good business relationship but walls are put up for other teams
job_title: Senior Software Developer in New York, NY
pros:
Very supportive immediate boss/manager.
A pretty family-friendly environment that supports work/life balance pretty well.
Generally strong relationships with business.
New CEO seems to be the right person for the time.
cons:
Infrastructure teams are very difficult to work with.
People openly put distance between themselves and other teams they need to work with.
The interaction with fellow employees in desks nearby is pretty minimal.
Local team interaction can at times be sparse and meetings only called to address fire drills or fires.

pros: I wish I had something positive to say about this bank.  Unfortunately, I do not.  It has been riddled with scandal after scandal and remains only a shell of its former self.  As banks cycle through these sorts of problems on a fairly regular basis, I am sure Barclays will rise again but not for a good long while.
cons: The recruitment was amazing!  Barclays recruited me over the course of 11 months.  It took that long to organization a package that I and my family could live with.  Within 21 days of my coming onboard, the entire management that had recruited me so carefully had all been replaced.  All promises made with no long in effect and I found myself scrambling.  Horrible experience!

review_title: One of the most dysfunctional companies I have seen.
pros: Decent perks, holidays, environment. Barclays does hire some excellent people although retention is an issue. They invest quite heavily in innovation. Pay is competitive.
cons: Infighting between silos. Poor transparency into opportunities - definitely a "who you know" place, not what. People are not treated with respect and the customer is an afterthought. Misogynistic behaviours by senior male leaders make this a poor place for senior women. The way to survive at Barclays is to keep your head down and try not to call attention to yourself.

review_title: Culture needs a lot of work
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Barclays offers competitive base pay and benefits but their bonuses are slim.   You are surrounded by intelligent colleagues who like to hear themselves talk so you will learn a lot.  There is opportunity for travel but budgets for travel and training tend to be tight.
cons: Barclays has a competitive culture, risk averse management and as a subsidiary of UK parent, training and other resources are lacking.  Be prepared to work long hours and have little show for it at the  end of the year.  They are very slow to promote within and the buttoned-down culture offers little by way of diversity of opinion.

pros:
- u can do the work u want. Request for the software u want. Quite independently implement anything new to do ur work.
- most of the projects, it’s good work-life balance.
- facility is excellent.
cons:
- it’s a manager driven company. 
- if ur boss isn’t nice then better change the project or company asap.
- HR do not hold any power they are just dummy.
- selection is mainly reference based or too much nepotism is there.
- promotion or growth also there is too much nepotism.

job_title: Configuration Analyst in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: Friendly colleagues. Steady work. Opportunities to progress into various large organisation office roles without necessarily needing formal qualifications.
cons: Management is frequently subject to change and reorganisation, which can be a barrier to performing well. There is a tendency (stemming from the top) towards short termism and buying into third party software as a solution to basic or cultural issues. There is often poor understanding and documentation of process and business needs.

pros: The internship program here is fantastic, with BarCap running a group of 150+ interns and Barclays Wealth now completing its second round of summer analysts. HR does a great job of balancing on-desk work experience with training sessions, and even roundtable-type discussions with higher management and the CEO.
cons: For interns, the personal experience is pretty much entirely dependent on the team you're assigned to. If luck is on your side, you'll have a great line manager that fosters professional growth and encourages you to ask questions, etc. On the other hand, you could end up with a manager who goes the entire summer without speaking with you and instead asks another entry-level associate to "take care" of you.

review_title: one of the worst periods of my life
pros: some good facilities and up to date technologies
cons: The most vicious culture. Back-stabbing and pathological bullying. i saw a whole team of people hired at a certain level just to be bullied once inside for not fitting the mould. constant shifting priorities and huge change in job roles once inside. it's like they hire you promise you a lot then force you to regress to office junior/tea boy or girl whatever your level hired at until you've proved yourself inside which means sucking up and not at all performance or results orientated. micromanagement of everyone to the point of orwellian nightmare and just a generally nasty place.

pros: Everything depends on a project. If you're on a good project, there are smart people to work with and learn from, good code and interesting technologies used. There are a lot of opportunities to learn business (on the job and training). Good work-life balance, flexible working hours and good salary. Technical training are also provided. Opportunity to change project after one year. Relaxed office environment.
cons: Approving new technologies is hard, approving almost anything is hard. If you're on a bad project the code can be a disaster. Promotion process is quite unclear and often changing. Not many opportunities to travel to different locations.

review_title: Good people and company, suffers from same problems as other IBs
pros: Coworkers are enjoyable to work with, culture is not as cutthroat as some IBs. In certain trading sectors, overall ranking is top 3 and thus there is opportunity to work with some of the best sell-side traders.
cons: Relatively conservative management that will not take huge risks. Less opportunity to progress versus what it was like 5 or 10 years ago. Not as aggressive as other IBs in their desire to be the top player. Suffers from lack of innovation - which is something going on across the street due to increased regulations, etc.

review_title: Bureaucratic, Political, Distracted Organization. No focus on sustainable revenues
pros: After the Libor scandal, at least there was a realization that poor talent with dubious ethical standards had been long tolerated and at times promoted. Great place to hang on with a stable paycheck if you can show you are performing 'citizenship' activities, irrespective of your actual contribution at work.
cons: Post-LIBOR promotion of values was a good PR campaign branding exercise but not much has changed. In fact, the bank has veered off to a misguided path where real innovation is stifled under several layers of bureaucratic red tape. Really talented employees are made to fill out paper work with the implicit understanding that the more paper work they fill out, the better they are likely to be compensated. Meanwhile, management has severely dented technological capability and innovation by under-investing and reducing headcount in any function or department remotely linked to technology.

pros: Career politicians can thrive here. i.e If you would rather go into meetings than be on the front line and agree with your boss you will get paid. If you are a real trader/broker-work somewhere else that will pay you for making money, not making "friends". If you can play this game you can win without actually performing well.
cons: No 360 review so it's hard to be be fairly judged. Some incompetent people make it up the ranks and end up in management positions. These same people give solo reviews and there isn't any input from anyone else. Your bonus/promotion will be decided by an MD who's relying solely on your bosses' input which he/she can easily lie about as no-one else is involved and the MD will be none the wiser. It's a flawed process.

pros: It is better to work for Barclays overseas, rather than in India. In US/UK, the company has a decent brand name, and benefits from a strong local leadership team in the major geographies that it operates in. Conservative in its market posturing, it is doing reasonably well from a financial and strategy points of view.
cons: In India, the main issue for Barclays is terrible leadership. Lack of transparency, ethics, professionalism. Performance appraisal is simply an eye-wash. Ratings and bonus are not determined by (a) the quality of work you do (b) the value you have generated for the company, but by other factors (read nepotism, cronyism, bias). HR best practices and leadership best practices are routinely flouted, because you can get away with the same. There is a tremendous culture of change resistance, innovation simply cannot happen because it will either be stalled because of vested interests, or, because leadership support will not be there. Strategy and management changes too frequently. Inadequate technical training for high end, high skill jobs.

pros: Barclays has talented people across the organization, there are definitely smart players here who understand the market and the business they are in. The place was fairly flexible about time off, and some work life balance.
cons: The place is quietly very political, with different fiefdoms among teams and individuals who are supported and not supported. The lack of success in the investment banking space means the place is shedding people and not paying competitively. Often the true status of things are not expressed until people are shorted on bonuses or let go. The future of the i bank as a major player in the US is really up for grabs

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Too many people & little work - so work life balance is good.
cons:
Too much fat in the organization. Despite rhetoric from the management, they haven't made the hard choices that need to be made to realign the business to the new operating reality in the post-crisis era. 
People at the mid-to-senior levels more interested in "clipping coupons" and making sure the up & coming high performers are pushed out - to protect their own cushy jobs. An MD routinely makes about 5% of total revenue of the desk (not 5% of profits, but 5% of revenues). There are usually 2-3 MDs on a desk. 
Very much a revolving door for senior level management positions in the investment bank. 
Bad morale. At least half of my group will leave if they get a job elsewhere, even with a paycut. 
To move up the hierarchy, one needs to play the politics well. That's all that matters.

pros: Barclays has a well established brand name.  Their image has been hit with several bruises from various legal, and ethical scandals (Libor setting, FX..).  Fortunately, during the past few years they have made a concerted effort to drive a "values" program into its workforce.  They seem to finally be back on track and having outstanding lawsuits put to rest.
cons: As Wall Street firms go through the business cycle you can expect periods of hiring and downsizing.  At Barclays the turnover is significantly higher than their competitors.  They lack long term vision, and go after the "low hanging fruit" opportunities.  These business are usually short lived and they downsize the group right after the market contracts.  Its a company that is involved in many business, but few that are stable and growing.

review_title: 1 Churchill Place, Canary Wharf - Very good place to work
pros:
1) Very good company to work for
2) Good networking facilities
3) Opportunities to learn and grow within the company
cons:
Too many redundancies within the company.
Cutting too much UK jobs.
Senior managers are NOT thinking and realising good staff are the ambassadors of the company and they bring good business to the company, etc.
Shareholder got the priority over everything therefore share price is very high on the agenda.

review_title: Terrible Management and Terrible Team Environment
job_title: Finance Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Decent salary, and decent benefits.  Other than that, I can't really say that there were any other benefits.  Oh, and free coffee in the pantry.
cons: Upper management has no interest (or does not care) about anyone except themselves.  I worked as a P&L analyst and was appalled at the "just get it done and stop bothering me with your questions" attitude of the VPs and Directors on my team.  They turn a blind eye to us slaving away until 9PM, but are the first to leave at 5:30PM and the first to complain about things not getting done in a timely manner the next day.

review_title: It an ok place to work.
pros: Pension. Benefits. Maternity pay is good. When the branch is busy its good but when its not its just boring.
cons:
The branch itself is a very boring place to work. I found a lot of employees that have been there for quite some time found that progression is slow and the only reason they stay is because of the benefits. The branches are quite a "talk behind your back" place to work and there is definitely not a "team" feel.
If you get the right manager then great but like me I didn't which resulted in me handing in my notice and taking a pay cut in another job where I am treated like a person.

review_title: A huge improvement needed to be an employer of choice
pros: Decent benefit package and in theory a wide array of options to move around the company.
cons:
Horrific processes which make no sense and do not seem to be documented - everything moves from one committee to another committee for weeks before the client sees any feedback.

Despite the company saying that performance reviews are not done on a bell curve, they are. It is essentially favouritism of management as to where you get placed independent of your actual achievements.

Clients are on very old systems and platforms and there is a huge amount of inertia to change in case things go wrong. I really feel like the company is being left behind by competitors old and new right now, as it seems more concerned with internal meetings then helping clients.

review_title: Great place to work, until management changed
pros: Pay is good as long as you make bonus every month. Incentive payout is higher than any I've seen in any other call center I've worked with.
cons: Pay is not based on experience like they say, because some people who only had one year experience in a call center, made $2-$3 more than those who had more than 5 years experience. As soon as the new management came in, the whole atmosphere went downhill, and they promise people who don't know what they're doing, and give agents wrong information when assistance is needed. They show lots of favoritism and don't value their employees, and they only care about numbers for the cosmonauts.

review_title: Build your career if you are prepared to slog it out
job_title: Chief of Staff in London, England
pros:
Great opportunities to move into new roles and take on new responsibilities (not necessarily with compensation to recognise this)
Great calibre of people working with you
Global (although that's changing)
cons:
Do not reward very well unless you are at risk of leaving
IT systems are extremely frustrating 
Major cost pressure means there are not enough people to deliver what is needed (and certainly not enough to be proud of the end result each time)

review_title: Just keep it running, innovation not so crucial
job_title: Assistant Vice President, IT in New York, NY
pros: Has good cross-team cooperation. True global investment bank. Relatively new IT infrastructure. Good off-shore IT support. Not a lot of high cost legacy applications.
cons: Overly focusing on cost cutting. Very bureaucratic in back office. A lot of exposure to EU and UK weakness and not as strong as HSBC in Asia.

pros:
- Benefits: 5 weeks leave, meal vouchers (fully paid), up to 60 days of sick leave (fully paid), private polyclinic with better-than-average waiting times for appointments, on-site stretching exercises 2x/week, Czech & English language classes
- Office location: near subway station with a good choice of lunch venues
- Office facilities: foosballs, table tennis, bean bags, free beverages, decently sized kitchens 
- Decent salaries, but not above market as before - attrition would be less otherwise
- Friendly and knowledgeable colleagues (in general), not a toxic environment (at least locally)
- Relaxed dress code for a bank - smart casual
- Paid overtime and on calls (or time off in-lieu)
- Work/life balance is generally very good but depends on team/project. Usually not a problem to work from home or leave for an hour or so if you must be somewhere (e.g. home parcel delivery, visit authorities/bank/dentist) - with some notice ahead of time (common sense, not 5 days in advance or the minute you already leave)
- A lot depends on the project/team: codebase, clients (understanding or very demanding/picky), team leads in other locations, etc. Could be a relatively smooth ride with little stress except a few days a year during major releases OR could be hell with constant stress, late nights due to messy systems and management who chronically overcommit and underdeliver.
cons:
- Processes and bureaucracy - e.g. it takes several weeks to become productive - have a working PC with access rights and software. And this is just one example
- Interaction with other teams (e.g. DBA, IT support, app servers support, other dev teams) - often need to send several chaser emails, otherwise you get ignored. This got progressively worse with time, but you might get lucky and get more responsive people.
- Quarterly mandatory trainings that are 90% irrelevant to IT people, are a waste of everyone's time and are mostly there so that the firm would fulfill the terms of yet another plea agreement with DOJ (or whoever it settled with this time).
- No budget for any real training opportunities - technical or business, besides the basics, but you can get Pluralsight subscription, which is better than nothing.
- Outsourced support to India and Mexico with staff of dubious quality (technical and/or language) and high turnover. Many support people don't know the systems and often don't want to learn. As a result developers on level 2 duty get swamped with issues that should be dealt with by level 1 people. This eats into your deliverables for the sprint.
- Change management - God forbid you must coordinate/deploy changes into production or UAT (yes, testing) environments regularly - the effort to document and push it through could easily exceed the actual change you did many times over. Only to do it 2 more times because team 3 out of 5 didn't approve your change in the system in time because you didn't chase them enough. If you are pure developer and only push code to version control then you're fine and spared of this.
- Tooling - collaboration tools are a mess, ancient IRC-like clone for chat, disparate (and often broken) systems for online meetings and videocalls. 
- Feeling like working in silos, little visibility of other teams and your own contribution, but this is supposedly getting better
- Limited career progression once you reach AVP - it is a "catch all" position where you can find people with anywhere between 3 and 13 years relevant experience.
- No budget for business travel or technical conferences. You can work with teammates daily for years without ever meeting them in person.
- Unless you're promoted, you get about inflation level pay rise for very good performance, otherwise below that, if any.
- Bonuses vary, but rarely exceed one monthly salary, often below that, if any, also they're paid in April for the previous year so they keep you on the hook longer should you decide to abandon ship

pros: The salary and benefits offered are very generous and are very easily accessible to all levels. Internal promotion is relatively simple at lower skill levels and this quickly corresponds to increased wages.
cons: Very slow at change and innovation, the company is very behind in terms of IT systems, banking systems and more importantly at attitude towards the customer. There is a very imminent presence of Senior level slogans that do not materialise in employee eyes. Operations are too widely dispersed, approaching diseconomies of scale.

review_title: Decent package, messed up management with constant reshuffling.
pros:
- Decent package including pension and other benefits
- Good on your CV if you're a graduate
- Relaxed environment with a lot of very smart people!
cons:
- but then there are as many not so smart people...
- IT roles technically not challenging - if like me you come from a engineering / hard-core tech background you will be bored with the role within a year.
- politics, politics and politics
- reminded constantly to be on your best behaviour
- rubbish appraisals process

review_title: Good professional opportunities but the firm is falling behind the leading investment banks.
pros: Global investment bank so it provides opportunities to work across the globe. Good and balanced blend of legacy Barclays and legacy Lehman employees plus new hires since 2008. Good work-life/vacation time.
cons: The lives of the majority of the employees were encumbered by an expensive and time-consuming rebranding and reengineering of the firm's culture that had suffered because of the missteps of a small number of key employees. That lead to lack of focus on producing. Morale is at new lows.

pros: Barclays Capital is still being considered a good name in the street, so it is good to have it on your CV when going to interview somewhere else. And base salaries are still good.
cons: Since Barclays' CEO announced major redundancy plans, including 30% in investment banking until 2016, people stopped working. It is difficult to find a person keen to develop business. The majority spends more time discussing who else is hiring, who is a good headhunter, who will be fired next etc. You feel very low morale.

pros: A competitive pay and very good benefits. I often get positive feedback from colleagues and customers, they acknowledge your skills and experience. Internal jobs available in case you get bored in your current role. I want to highlight the benefits, these are really good, lots of great benefits, support and employee discount.
cons: There is a PD-game every year; just recently noticed management does not really care about what you achieve if they already decided your grade. This is not a great motivation. Same applies for carrier development. If you are looking for a relaxing job, you can get into a very stressing one where always there is a pressure on you to deliver service without any mistake. Making processes even more complicated and our (technical staff) life more difficult in the BAU work.

job_title: Vice President, Marketing in Wilmington, DE
pros: Growth company with entrepreneurial spirit.  Strong management team and flat organization.  Great people to work with. The team is mostly centered in Wilmington, DE so there is a strong face-to-face meeting culture.  It is nice to have the backing of a large bank, but have the feel of a small organization.
cons: As a growth company, there are more goals than people to achieve them.  Barclaycard has been slow to hire to ramp up for growth.  It is currently outside the top 5 issuers within the US, so budgets are smaller than those of the larger organization.

review_title: Alright, if you're in with the 'in crowd'
pros:
Salaries are pretty high for the industry. Variety of work is challenging. Nice surroundings and facilities onsite.
Flexible working arrangements are a bonus
cons:
Once you've blagged your way into the company on a high salary then you can quite easily coast under the radar.
Far too many meetings 
Level of scrutiny over change is cumbersome and counter-productive.
Offshore staff are preconditioned not to think for themselves so working with them can be frustrating.
Opportunity to move up the grade structure is pretty much driven by the need to move across teams.
Team-working is very combative, guarded experts making it difficult to gain knowledge

review_title: Poor policies and work environment for working mothers - Pune EON
pros: Company policies for work life balance but managers take it away
cons:
1. Very rude managers in Pune EON office.
2. Lack respect and understanding for working mothers. Not sure why they hire diversity candidates.
3. Company policies support work life balance but managers dont allow.
4. There are no HR policies or network to check if women are treated well.
5. Directors are famous for being womanisers
6. In start of year managers start mentioning you will get worst rating, way before mid year, leave about end of year. Leaves employee totally demotivated and looking out in start of year itself.
7. Make you work on technology thats not your skillset and expect you to work 12 hours a day.
Overall very stressful environment - why did I join?

review_title: There aren't many satisfied and happy workers here
pros: The remuneration is relatively good and it is a good place to start just for the brand name on your resume.
cons: There is little opportunities for career progression and growth. Management is not interested in grooming talents/leadership from within. There is a lack of direction in terms of leadership. Important changes/news within the firm are not conveyed until the eleventh hour. Politics is rife and employees are treated as pawns of the firm. You are hired, at best, as a well-paid production-line worker. ' Do what you are told and don't question too much' seems to be the way to live if you want to stake out here for long, otherwise, your frustrations will one day kill you. It is no wonder that the turnover rate here is high.

review_title: Very cheap IT and you must be a brown nose to get a promotion
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Normal work hours and they have great benefits. The work is somehow interesting but you cannot  work at home when necessary (unless it is really a needed situation). Barclays name on your resume is a good thing.
cons: Awful company structure, VERY cheap on IT spending, won't provide tech training for employees, too much off-shoring of IT jobs to save money. They are very diversified which is good but some cultural manners from these employers should be banned from the workplace. The IT floors smell like indian food. Can be very bureaucratic and centralized planning. Only if you are a real "brown nose" you will get a promotion or exposure. Promotions not based on merit but rather on networking/contacts.

review_title: Biased and skewed workplace - Barclays Shared Services
pros: If you believe that you can weather out a storm, best place to test yourself.
cons:
Barclays Shared Services is one place where you will find that polishing your manager's apples is what works.

The management is never transparent and has an in your face attitude when confronted and deals with these issues with high handedness. If you do not like it leave but do not expect us to be fair in our dealings with the employees.

Bias in management decision ranging from verbal recognition to reward and recognition, even in sending people to just be a participant at an award ceremony, to sending people onshore in UK is blatant.

You might get a top rating, appreciation from the UK head of businesses, so much so that they do not want anyone else in the team to handle their work and never let you go, but might never get any opportunity just because the management wants you to take crap or leave.

pros: Benefits (such as My Barclays Rewards) are great. Incentives ('Colleague Reward') is terrible, especially if you are part-time.
cons: Management of individual teams are not yet fully on board with the new Values - many (especially Telephony Team Leaders) are too focused on 'Sales'.

job_title: Senior Software Developer in London, England
pros: They pay more than some of the other banks.
cons: The leadership changes its mind about the direction of the company almost weekly. There is no guarantee that your work will ensure that you continue to be employed there. It seems like each month there is a new "townhall" meeting with one of the very senior mgmt people telling us what the new "corporate slogan" is. job_title: Lead Software Engineer in Knutsford, England

review_title: Great people but too much middle management and a lack of internal promotions.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, Senior Software Developer in Wilmington, DE

Good HR process and benefits, flexible hours and ability to work from home where possible.

review_title: Horrible Communication, Hard to escalate issues

review_title: Want to work in a dynamic fast paced environment with excellent career prospects? Then dont work for Barclays !!!!
pros: To use as a stepping stone into a decent company
cons: Salary is very low compared to other local companys ie BNP Paribas, Resolution Assett Management & Smith & Williamson. The only way to progress in this company is if your friends with the management as its jobs for the boys no matter how much knowledge or experience you have.

pros: Overall, the people were great - very willing to help you learn and willing to give real responsibilities to interns.  I liked that the program was rotational so interns maximize their exposure to the bank.

Also, HR is important - they have the final say in who gets summer offers so beware.  BarCap says they are a meritocracy, but this is definitely not the case.

As a large company, they tend to be a little more inclined to consider 'staff' as 'human resources' - something to be relocated and redeployed to fit in with a strategy.

pros:

Benefits
cons:

Forced ranking system that places  hard working staff  into "Does not Meet Objectives" categories to justify the offshore and staff reduction objectives.

Limited to no advancement opportunities

Layoffs managed very poorly and people treated very poorly during the exiting process.
 
Quality staff leave once they get settled seeing the lack of advancement, constant reduction in compensation, long hours and highly political environment.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in London, England
pros:
Okay...first things first - this will now be the 4th bank I have worked for over the years and I've been at Barclays for almost a year. I'll save you some trouble - apart from Goldman Sachs they are all more or less the same. 

Barclays will look good on your CV

Most folks are nice enough to work with (despite being busy all the time) - they're just human. Most won't shout at you or whatever; it's just everyone is so rushed and busy all the time.

Can be hit or miss as it's so large - get an average or above manager and you'll be alright

Pay seems on par with other banks but nothing incredible like the media portray (we can't all be millionaires; most are well paid grunts). haha

Pretty clear senior management considering they have a day job as well (sending out announcements, updating blogs and intranet sites and so on) - although you're obviously not going to know everything. Be realistic.

Good chance to learn on the job (you don't need to have 3 degrees in finance or anything stupid). Just sit, watch, learn and help - you'll soon get it.

Offices on the whole are decent. North Colonnade could do with some updating but it's alright - South Colonnade is very nice with airy open plan offices and lots of light. You get all the tech and equipment most people would need (multiple monitors, etc).
cons:
okay - let's get this out the way first - bonuses. Unless you're one of a lucky few, don't start thinking of mansions, fast cars and so on - it's media hype. Those days are gone for most. Numeration day is a total joke (almost insulting) so unless you're pulling in hundreds of millions for your boss (unlikely) don't think you're on the ticket to success when you get here. Learn lots, work hard and see what happens - but it's not Leonardo DiCaprio wolf of wall street ticket to success stuff. You missed the boat big time on that one.

Crazy working hours. Yes, you get paid well however when you work it out per hour it becomes very average. If you're contract says 9-5 don't honestly expect to work those. I work 8:30am til 6:30pm (middle office) - a lot of my team work longer and we aren't compensated like successful traders / sales people (most old school are long gone).

It's the same everywhere I've been, especially in banks - politics. It's a huge company and people are looking after themselves - it doesn't mean you're going to have a terrible time but managers are so busy looking up pandering to the needs of those above and playing politics with others that what chance to those at the bottom get? Real leadership inspires, nurtures, listens, etc - but most in leadership roles (big and small) are not natural leaders.

With the greatest respect to those in India; stop offshoring Barclays. Seriously, I know you can get 3 Indians or more for the price of 1 in the UK or US but it's about value and not price for what you get. Let's not confuse value and price. Half the company is based out in India by workers utterly confused and inexperienced, not able to think beyond their checklists printed for them. Empty promises, not delivering work, when it is delivered it's all wrong or fudged - ah, I can go on. Seriously, it's easier to get up and work with one person on the other side of the floor.

Some teams can be a bit 'old boys network' but they are rare. It could be much worse - most are normal.

The biggest issue at Barclays investment right now (early 2015) is that it is run by a chap that knows retail banking (CEO Anthony Jenkins). The investment bank is a mere child compared to what it was a few years ago and staff morale is low. It's low because people are heavily overworked due to ruthless job slashing yet the business keeps demanding more and more - there is no more juice to squeeze. I get the feeling the top guys want to turn the overall Barclays group into a retail bank and sell of the investment part eventually - so long as it's providing a good enough return then they'll keep hold. But seriously, the workforce are drained, exhausted and good people leave within just a year.

The bank has tens of thousands of staff. Even those extremely good at the bottom deserving promotion have odds heavily stacked against them because of the numbers game. It's very hard to get noticed when you have so many also wanting to be noticed and seen as 'special'. Don't expect quick promotions, like with most banks (a lot of good timing and luck involved) rather than natural talent and skill.

job_title: Assistant Vice President CIB in London, England

review_title: Great career move, poor life choice

Ability to work abroad and move roles is an added benefit.
cons: Only recently considered to be a top tier investment house. Has grown so quickly that the back office/infrastructure occasionally struggles to keep up.

review_title: Barclays is becoming just another big Credit Card company
pros: You can learn the credit card industry and get exposure to all departments with ease.  Culture is rather relaxed.  Time off is generous.
cons: No raises for anyone in 2 years.  Limited promotions and hiring from outside is common.  I've never had such limited exposure to department heads before.  UK parent is making Sourcing and Risk Tolerance unbearable.  UK parent has a "one template" approach to all their companies.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Many good people still around.  Many pockets of good areas.  Technology isn't too bad.  It seems they don't really fire too much even for incompetence in technology.
cons:
Promotions are skewed against NYK office b/c of Lehman integration as quota exists.
Massive amount of politics that don't work in the best interest of the business.
Not a pay for performance as more a popularity contest as is the promotion process.

review_title: They invested in me and helped me grow
pros: My direct manager when I started there was a great mentor in addition to being a really good person to work for. As I moved around in the company, I found that the line management was really good across the board. I met some great people, was able to work in a highly professional environment, and had decent benefits. I had good opportunities for mobility and advancement and I was able to work in the UK and AsiaPac for short stints to broaden my experience.
cons: Its a very big company, and all the challenges that come with working in a large organization were present. That said, I really enjoyed my time there

review_title: Very lucky experience with my team
pros: The structure of the Finance Graduate Program was ideal for a first job out of school, providing a well-rounded training curriculum and an opportunity to learn about all the different areas within in Finance.  I can say that there was a recognition of the higher-performing graduate analysts, and that they were rewarded with the placements they sought out.
cons: There is a lack of true cohesion among all teams not only inter-departmentally, but also within Finance itself.   Many teams seek to "protect" themselves rather than all constructively work together toward a greater purpose.  Collective morale also took a big blow with all the high, senior-level misdeeds and the associated bad press.

review_title: Never-ending bad news, layoffs = bad morale
pros: Compared to other investment banks, decent work/life balance.
cons:
Since the bank announced last May that the investment bank will be shedding 7000 jobs, the mood has been bad.  Morale is poor.  Annual rankings force each manager to classify 10-20% of their direct reports as "needs improvement".  Anybody that gets this ranking is let go.  In other words, every manager has to let go of people every year.
The number of scandals and regulatory issues Barclays is currently involves with is embarrassing and depressing.
Bonuses were laughable or nonexistent.

pros:
Large bank with opportunities across almost all banking disciplines i.e Investment, Corporate, Wealth, Consumer, Cards etc
Attempts to be progressive
Global footprint
cons:
Confused culture
Poor HR practices some of them downright vindictive
Highly fragmented and tribal organisation
incoherent strategy
lax approach towards employee care
Focus is on meeting targets irrespective of whether they make a difference or not
Oft used/abused political lines are 
1. "it increases the operational risk" - without having to justify or explain how
2. "this is not as per values" - which generally shuts up any dissenters as the next step is probably a disciplinary

review_title: Is it really same Barclays which it used to be few years back?
pros: Flexible work hours, Lots of non technical initiatives and actives
cons: No growth, individual business units are becoming enterprises with bias towards people growth and hiring

job_title: Assistant Vice President, IT in Prague
pros:
Good salaries
Friendly colleagues
Offices in the centre of Prague
Large offer of benefits
cons:
Insanely corporate mind. If you need something, you will spend days filling in forms processed in an other part of the world where no one cares about your problem. If you bother them, they ignore you. Mandatory trainings, company values screaming from everywhere.
Collective apathy spreading throughout the whole development team: Nothing matters, nothing will get better, this won't ever appear in production...
Every project is more or less about the same thing, no real challenges.

review_title: Not a good place to work, especially in middle or back office.
pros: It is well recognized in the street.  With the acquisition of Lehman, the firm has grown significantly.  It has gained good reputation among peers and has agressively gained market shares in a lot of areas. Good place for a starter.
cons: Headquarter is in London.  New York branch is really treated as a branch.  All the decisions are made in London.  The Lehman acquisition is more like a reverse acquisition.  A lot of the 3000 Barclays ppl have lost their job.  Many senior positions are taken by ppl from Lehman.  This company does not award loyal employees.  The longer you stay, the more likely your pay will be screwed.  Bonus is at a very low level as compared to the peers in the street.

review_title: Barclays Capital - Good People, Bad Management
pros: I worked in Production IT - BarCap has good systems, and competent people.
cons: Teams are too lean, and as a result there is no bandwidth to deal with any sudden issues.  People are tired and stressed.  There is a complete lack of training/planning.  BarCap also has a policy of normalisation, so when you get graded you might have gotten a B, but because of the Bell curve that gets marked down to a C.  Middle Management has no idea who works for them; if you are involved in BAU work your invisible.

review_title: R&D sweatshop atmosphere, with no hope of career advancement or credit unless you are with the "in" group
pros: Good pay, good benefits, communication to employees good outside of communication within technical groups; extensive CBT training and overall willingness to provide training to employees
cons: Technology group run by tyrannical mangement, lacking management and leadership skills.  Not enough focus on meeting business requirements and goals, more like building technology for technology sake along the lines of "build it and they will come"...sounds good in theory and baseball perhaps, but not in real life. The conditions in the workplace that are created by the above, make it very difficult for innovation and true alignment with business goals.

review_title: big company bureaucracy, lots of process but good in many other aspects including training, diversity perspective
job_title: Senior Change Manager in Northampton, England
pros: salary for this location, top performers get good bonuses, good for cv, good training, peers good folk to work with, most management ok.
cons: process heavy and hierarchical, no real decision making power at middle let alone junior management level.  Recommendations go a long way up line.  To make significant progress takes much more than standard 35 hours as need buy in from so many people. probably + 10 hours on standard week which can affect work life balance.

pros:
Friendly and helpful staff
Lots of good benefits
* 10% non contrib pension
* Share schemes
* Employee discount
cons: Very fast pace environment, and a lot of pressure to delivery on time.  You have to go and find the answer yourself and there's a lot of "its on the wiki" attitudes in the mobile space.

pros:
Tech savvy.
Future oriented.
Strong focus on implementing the core values.
Supportive environment. 
Flexible working options available.
Benefit package is not bad.
It's a BIG brand! Good for CV.
cons:
There is a lot of training available but as a new starter with no prior experience in the Banking industry I thought there was not enough support for me 'on the job'  as I was expected to serve customers on the desk without having anyone experienced beside me. So, on the job training has scope for improvement. 
Salary and bonus went down significantly since the credit crunch in 2008.

review_title: Great benefits for employees with families
pros: Flexible working patterns, well constructed benefits package (pension plan, discount, cycle to work scheme, car allowance, training etc)
cons: When I used to work there I sometimes did not like that re-structures happened really often, leaving staff feeling a little insecure. The hours were also very long. However,  I now look back to my days in Barclaycard as some of the best in my career. I learnt lots and I loved the flexible working patterns. In general, employees are also very empowered. Great for females and members of minority groups.

review_title: good work life balance, mediocre professional environment - a good place to retire
pros: work life balance is good - many people work from home.
cons:
- talk of big ambitions but lacking the will to break with a "clubby" past and reward/penalize based - on merit
- very political, low levels of trust between senior and middle management
- has talked of becoming international for some time but highly UK centric - would prefer if "they" could be more like "us"
- technology and HR (talent management) are shockingly poor, even for a large organization

review_title: Never join into testing unit if you are not tamilian.
pros: The policies are goid. but they are seldom followed. e.g. it started WFH but only given to manager favourites.
cons:
1) The manager can play with your career. no hearing .
2)  You are hired but given no work and then given bad rating.
3) If you raise a voice to senior management its not heard.
4) People from tamil nadu are favoured.
5) e.g. of mis management. a resource is hired but his role is defined by the employee .. 

Please dont join in the testing of cards unit.. You will regret if not a tamillian

I have many friends from TN. nothing against them. But in professional world such favourisms should not be practised.

review_title: A sinking ship whose managers have lost decency
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: The company offers free coffee and tea.  Colleagues are cooperative in general.  Manager is hardworking as the staff.  The CEO seems to want right ship and create a moral atmosphere after some scandals.
cons: The company is struggling to keep talent because of multiple rounds of layoffs.  Managers have a tough time choosing who to get rid of.  They sometimes make the unsavory choices based on favoritism.  The manager treated his employees with decency only when pressuring them to deliver projects and did not give credit where credit was due after the projects were delivered successfully.  The bank's pay is below average compared to other banks in the i-bank business, to put it generously.

review_title: Cost control is the predominant concern
pros:
People are friendly
People are helpful where possible
cons:
Reducing costs is the dominant driver of decisions. As a result ageing systems and equipment are not improved, redundancy rounds leave fewer people doing more work, high staff turnover means few people are able to explain or justify what was done in the past, obtaining approval for any expenditure is difficult, and compensation is significantly reduced.

Barclays is reducing in size so the environment is one of managing decline.

The effect of this is to increase the time and effort required on process work at the expense of seeking improvements.

pros: I was lucky to have a great boss, but this was rare.
cons:
Felt like HR worked against you, not with you. Recently changed to a vacancy-based promotion process so very difficult to progress in-role, particularly if you work in a small team with no room for new vacancies. They don't bother with exit interviews.

VERY political. People are often unwilling to change. There is a culture of over complicating things and people seem to try and make themselves seem more important/intelligent than they are.

review_title: Not good any more.  Now it sucks your soul
job_title: Assistant Vice President Developer in Prague
pros:
Some good people there
No real stress
Nice office
cons:
The company is in real trouble. Major parts being sold off, loosing money, is being fined for breaking laws every month
It was a good place to work 3 or 4 years ago but not now
Clearly they are making it crappy for people so they leave and saves the company the cost of firing them all
No career opportunities
People leave and no there are no replacements, so get ready to do 3 people's job
The snr mgmt in NY will lie to you about whats going. Read the press to find out the truth (whats reported almost always ends up happening in the end)
You get a really tough interview and then end up on a project editing xml files

pros:
- Innovative
- Open culture
- Reasonably good compensation
- Lots of delivery focused areas
cons:
- Too many layers, actors, players and subjects - politics is inevitable if not synonymous with Barclays
- Senior management is not hands on everyone worries about perception and managing the top rather than building great teams 
- Lets face it, everyone tries to build an empire and the culture is personality driven rather than people driven. People say I work in X Y's world. Every 6 months there is re-org, and the structure never settles down
- If you are not well networked it can get really frustrating 
- Having said that, if you want to work for a bank and in

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: "Nice" people. Never wanted to say anything straightforward enough to let you lose face
cons:
1. Promised Green Card when joining the firm. After getting in, was told to wait until end of first year. At the end of first year, was told the policy changed need to wait until end of second year. At the end of second year, was told that because our department was moved from front desk to risk, need to wait until end of third year. What???
2. After resignation, repayment was asked without HR looking thru the whole case. Once complained, was forwarded to three different department/people none of whom ever look thru the whole case.
3. Incapable manager had to hire a pushy bossy project manager who has little respect for knowledge and effort. Asked in front of everyone if you still want a job.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: High salary, tons of big time exit opportunities, extremely high growth potential in the company and outside as well, sets you up very nicely for a career in finance, guarantees a top MBA program if you choose that route, meet a lot of kids your age out of college / near around college that are very, very bright from some of the best schools in the world and will undoubtedly be incredibly successful moving forward
cons: Very little work life balance. Extremely frustrating work at times. No time to sleep or workout many days; have to cancel many plans, and make work a priority. Live in fear for your job often which is painful especially as an analyst

pros:
You meet so many people and make so many friends, colleagues and customers alike.
Benefits - free eye tests, med insurance and other bits were useful.
Work/Life balance was decent.
cons:
Targets - Or should I say "targets" as it wasnt supposed to be but was, constantly watched, literally standing at my side when using a till, to the point I couldn't open the drawer to deal with the transaction! All about selling something/anything to every customer.
Wages - for the responsibilities we held at Essential Banker level wages should have been higher.
Management - certain people shouldn't be there based on the atmosphere they cause, but nothing will ever be done about it.

pros: Depends on your branch/team. If management is fair then it’s works well, benefits are good,
cons: Always short staffed, never get out on time, you always get one or two lazy ones that don’t pull their weight. There’s always one staff that’s been there for donkeys years that can’t accept change or change or procedure. Dont work in a branch that opens on Saturdays as you end up working more Saturdays then you should as it’s always short staffed. There’s no work life balance, expected to come to work between 8.15am then leave on a good day 5.30pm.

review_title: slow paced, small IT budget, old technology and process orientated
job_title: Assistant Vice President, IT in London, England
pros: Good location and with its slow pace things are pretty relaxed.
cons:
Hard to get to know people, it's a global company and meetings are mostly by phone. Managers don't tend to see the big picture and focus just on their areas. There doesn't seem to be an overall strategy.
Very little or no bonus at all in the IT section, at AVP level anyway.
Only a small pay increase on the additional fixed payment which means no increase in pension payments. Barclays are good at "avoiding" costs in all ways.
IT is behind the times (some boxes still on redhat 3) and budget very small. Not the place to go if you like leading edge technology.
Very process oriented, and pace is slow. A dull place to work.

pros: Great flexible working environment, manage your own hours and just as happy to allow staff to work from home. Lots of access to some great training courses and great opportunity to network across the organisation
cons:
Bureaucracy, matrix management and not enough senior management living the 'values and behaviours'.
Serious hierarchy issues where grade is everything regardless of what is said.

review_title: Technically challenging for all the wrong reasons
job_title: Associate Vice President (Assistant Vice President) in Knutsford, England
pros: Good benefits, free parking , remote working, Nice decor gives a Google-esque feel
cons:
Technical leadership seems to be waiting for a redundancy payout, so therefore have no interest in newer technologies. Poor man management skills seem to be ingrained at all levels.

Management seems very old school with rank trumping technical ability, and technical ability not being considered important in most cases. 

I would find it difficult to recommend Barclays as an employer to anyone who is technically minded, as other companies in the area are far more innovative and supportive, therefore technical roles are filled by those who are drawn to big business rather than techincal innovation.

I can honestly say I cannot see a set of events that would make be consider a role at Barclays.

review_title: The marketing department - Bad culture, big leadership problems, very stressful place
pros: You can have a good work life balance. The brand is strong and important. The work benefits are good and their is great health care, pension, insurance and all that kind of thing.
cons: The senior and middle management are full of politics and are a nightmare to work for. The level of micro management from the very top down to middle management makes it a stressful and very hard place to work. You get almost no support. The values that they talk of, well you can forget that.

job_title: Vice President Compliance in New York, NY
pros: Great, smart and very fair people to work with and for.  Values oriented, diverse and collaborative culture.  Strives for operating efficiencies and mindful/flexible with work-life balance needs and alternatives.
cons: Senior management was filled with redundancies in roles and responsibilities and could have used some trimming or re-allocation of responsibilities.  Physical office space was crummy.  Crowded seating with no privacy or space at all.  Base pay compensation was comparable, but bonuses were low.

review_title: You'll need good game playing skills
job_title: Project Manager Paid As Business Analyst in Knutsford, England
pros: Money was ok plus reasonable share scheme very flexible working very good if you like working from home though your expected to buy your own laptop
cons: Very backwards culture,totally run on game playing all about who you know and if your in London or not. Diversity agenda is not sincere they are focused on getting rewards from media run diversity networks...think careful if diversity is important

review_title: Great company to work for with the opportunity to develop
pros: 5 week holiday, lots of funded training, sick pay , the shift isn't too bad depending where you work, you can be flexible depending on management
cons: -have to carry keys, lots of responsibility but basic pay, you  can often be the one picking up after others mess and don't get treated fairly sometimes due to grade etc  they will always try to get more out of you at no extra cost. No appreciation

review_title: Great company to work for, lots of benefits
pros: Great benefits, flexible working possible , you can work locally if you want to, some managers are very friendly, long sick pay, great share scheme, cheaper barclays products including insurance.
cons: Cuts everywhere, 1 person does 2-3 people jobs, sickness is not managed properly, people are misusing the generous benefit a lot. Booking holiday system isnt fair, same people get always xmas off some never.

review_title: very professional and assertive environment excellent objectives and goals.
job_title: Contact Center Agent in Matola, Maputo Province
pros: the professional  environment, friendly colleagues, diverse cultures team work is always excercised and without it we are nothing.
cons: nothing bad to highlight just individuals with different characters that are unable to mingle and work with other team mates prefer to sabotage others work to elevate professionally

review_title: Great Exit Opportunities, Pay, But Too Much Office Politics
pros:
Terrific compensation packages for 22 year old engineering grads, particularly those working in the quant groups.  Total Pay offered to me was much better than the starting offers from Google, Facebook, Microsoft, etc... Great way to pay off your student loans if you're willing to really work hard and grind and understand the fact that NOBODY comes here to make friends or hold hands with you and that yes, you WILL be arriving at 7AM and working till 10PM on most days. Other days can be worse, especially if you're in Forex capital market trading.  Total Comp for 22--24 year olds across my group was around $140,000.

Again, great way to pay off your student loans if you have some ugly ones.

Better hours, better work/life balance, and better paid than the investment banking division.

Great name to have on resume if you want exit ops.  It's no Goldman, but seeing where many of my friends ended up, it can get you definitely places.

Good access to private investors and clients if you have higher ambitions of leaving finance and moving onto entrepreneurship and tech start ups in the future.

Terrific bathrooms.  Stalls are great for napping in.

Satisfactory coffee.

Sometimes meetings are hilarious and the general atmosphere is more laid back than those at GS, MS, JPM.
cons:
- HORRIBLE HORRIBLE HORRIBLE HORRIBLE OFFICE POLITICS.

- Neverending fear that you can be fired the next day (500+ people fired out of nowhere early 2011, 50+ people fired again a few months later).

- Some reckless colleagues can make extremely risky much less stupid trades that screw things up for everybody.

- Not much transparency in many office affairs, particularly when it comes to handing out bonuses.

- Fear of getting fired any day (as compared to my former classmates working at Goldman, MS, JPM...)

review_title: Great work experience for an entry level hire.
pros: Really talented, smart, ambitious employees contribute to a high functioning organization. Relatively flat hierarchy so plenty of access to senior leadership. Entrepreneurial environment makes for a place you can get experience contributing to a variety of projects.
cons: You can invest 25 hours a day and bring your A+ game and it doesn't feel like enough to get the job done. Work never feels finished and leadership forgets to appreciate your work in any real form/fashion, monetarily or not.

pros: Money is very good, cannot think of anything else sorry
cons: Very very unethical business, management turn a blind eye to irregularities, they prefer to bury things under red tap.  If you raise these issues as a whistle blower you get treated as a criminal.  Best avoid and work for another investment bank or tech firm.  Real shame because they have a few good people, however the management team left over from Mr Diamond is still operating and the new board is no aware

review_title: Company going nowhere, continued poor quality of MDs and senior leadership
pros: VP and Director-level staff are good. Salaries are relatively good.  Good work-life balance. Some good work being done, especially in the behavioural economics arena
cons: Poor control environment, blame culture, second-guessing, passive-aggressive organization, quality of MDs is very poor, senior management is not cohesive. Haven't met a single MD who is an inspirational leader in my 8+ years of working there. Indeed the quality of MDs is so poor that other parts of Barclays joke that "he must have come from Wealth" whenever they come across a poor leader . And more often than not, they are right. Past senior leaders have done untold damage to the franchise. Thankfully they have left, but the present management is incapable of repairing the franchise. Needs to grow fast, or shut down. It is  drag on rest of the Group.

review_title: Good place to work - 1 Churchill Place - Corporate Bank
pros: Mostly good people with good working ethos, positive team atmosphere, no issues with work life balance. Particularly strong Africa network. Relatively strong leadership generally though it does change too often.
cons:
Technology needs advancing, systems and product capability. 

Too many layers in too many processes, with too many jobs going from UK unfortunately having negative impact on turnaround times across all areas. 

Young people who are not from the grad scheme need to have a slice of luck (right place right time) and often be particularly well networked in order to progress.

job_title: Senior Software Developer in New York, NY
pros: Laid back environment, smart people, relatively progressive for a bank when it comes to technology.
cons:
All of the pros varies greatly from group to group, and from position to position.
It's a giant bank, and as such you have a lot of bureaucracy, and an environment where patches of mediocrity thrive. Also the pay is rather sad relatively speaking. No bonuses at all. Which tends to correlate with apathy and mediocrity.
IT is housed in the saddest excuse for an office building at 1301 Ave of the americas. It's a sad building. With a sad staff. It's really very very sad. The building that is. The employees are not sad. But the building is.

pros: The responsibility given is really good, as well as support to develop in terms of additional knowledge (very important when starting out in the career) and guidance. Merit counts, and if you can show that you can handle added responsibility, then the respect obtained is satisfying. Also very supportive when it comes to maintaining a work- personal life balance. Work needs to be done, but it's not done with a slave-driving attitude.
cons: Information is rationed out. Probably a good thing- to be on a need-to-know basis, but can rankle sometimes.

review_title: Lack of consequence for low performance
job_title: Equity Exotic Structurer in London, England
pros:
Good place to hide if you are not  a performer,  no one gets fired.
If you are being poached they pay large guaranteed packaged.
cons:
-- downside is that the generators end up paying for everybody else, as in a socialist society.
-- legacy people have ended up paying for the new people i.e. legacy got underpaid in order to pay for bringing in new people that were overpaid.
-- too many french in senior management, they are invisible and add no value.

review_title: Average Experience for Junior Investment Banker
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: There are many opportunities to work in US and abroad, so if you are interested in a multi-national experience, this company may be a great fit.  I know several investment banking analysts and associates offered temporary or full-time opportunities in London who worked in the US office.
cons: They wear business formal on a daily basis.  All banking floors are designed to feel like a trading floor.  Therefore, until you reach VP level, you work in an environment with little to no privacy, which can be challenging if you are building a complex model and need quiet.  Company generally pays mid to lower end of street.

job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY
pros: There is a lot of flexibility in terms of work schedule. Many people work from home sometimes.  The work is interesting if you get into the right team. Great training programs. Some internal mobility for employees who have been working at the company for a bit of time.
cons: Lack of transparency from upper management. Promotion politics. Lack of compensation for employees who perform above expectations. Lack of ability to retain talent and innovate. Every week, you see a person leave the team or a new contractor being hired onto the team - causes lack of teamwork and overall knowledge of projects.

pros: Great location on the Wilmington Riverfront. Friendly people.
cons: Unorganized, chaotic, unstructured, and reactive environment.  Although several basic frameworks exist, no clearly defined processes or workflows are in place. The organization considers itself an "agile" environment but I think that's more of an excuse, rather than a reality.

review_title: In need of a shake up
pros: Barclays is a large organisation with lots of different business units and scope to move internally. It's a Multinational work environment with a wide breadth of cultures and a good international brand. The work is interesting and challenging and there are some good people trying to do the right thing.
cons: Massive amounts of bureaucracy, politics and wastage in a business that is undergoing significant change. Very difficult to make a tangible change. Different business units often working at cross-purposes although new CEO and ExCo trying to change that.

pros:
Pay
Benefits
They feed you well
Active in the community
cons:
Some of the supervisors/leads are unapproachable 
Training class is in dire need of a computer system that works so you know what to expect when speaking with  customers.
There is no training manual, you are stuck in a class that consist of taking notes.
Hiring staff/supervisor paint you picture of how great is to work there and how supportive everyone is when in reality it's 30% true
When you accept the job, be prepared to be called/hounded daily by recruiting staff to make sure you are still taking the job

review_title: Great company with fantastic opportunity for internal progression.
pros: Hard work gets recognised. Huge opportunity for personal development inclusive of externally recognised qualifications. Large variety of roles and a diverse and inclusive culture.
cons:
Loss of high quality of staff due to lack of competitive pay in comparison to other FIs with local offices. 
Quality of progression can depend on agenda of senior leadership - sometimes clouded by a desire to retain quality staff rather than supporting progression internally. Often leads to great staff looking externally for opportunities due to mismanaged expectations.

pros: You will get good  package if you have good negotiating skills , sufficient leaves,  cab facility
cons: Worst infrastructure,  very old systems , dead slow network, worst IT support, work pressure, cabs never run on time etc

review_title: Brilliant culture, welcoming people, young teams, let down by HR and hiring
pros:
Young teams with welcoming, personable people
Great culture especially in payments and digital teams
Work / life balance positive and available at all levels
Many citizenship opportunities
cons:
Structural changes happen within divisions every 3-6 months, hard to keep up
Regular cost cutting and hiring freezes means little room to progress
Graduates given good programme and rotation for two years to not find permanent roles at the end despite their experience due to cuts

review_title: Ok Place to work, but be prepared for a several rounds of layoff
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
Decent benefits, medical and 401K
Competitive salary compared to other wall street firms
Flexible work hours
Good brand name
Ability to move to Asia or Europe
cons:
Very difficult to get promoted  or get a raise unless you are politically connected or you at the time of hire.
Bureaucracy and frequent management changes
They over-hire and then layoff (non merit related)
 Multiple teams develop the same things in parallel, only for job security
Ones gets dissatisfied soon because growth is limited

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Wilmington, DE
pros:
One of the top pay masters in the Wilmington area
Best benefits in the banking industry
cons: Absolutely no career growth opportunity - everyone understands the pyramid structure for career growth, but literally there is no chance for upward movement beyond AVP.  The Vice Presidents in general are sitting tight, working the least and choking hard working AVPs from getting a chance to move up.  The company needs a shake-up at the upper middle management to get rid of dead wood

review_title: An enjoyable, successful and supportive nine years of service
pros: Pay is good, good support network, flexible benefits, nice people, innovation on ways to learn and communicate, social responsibility is a high priority.  Personal development and work/life balance is actively encouraged.  Very good support for an individual's personal circumstances.
cons: Whilst it is good to work for a large organisation, it is quite difficult to make changes quickly or gather momentum.  Empowerment is actively encouraged but can be difficult to achieve.

review_title: A real grind meant for short term employment
job_title: Credit Analyst in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
1) Open 24 hours so you can choose to work overnight, normal hours, or swing shift
2) You have the opportunity to earn significantly more through bonuses and overtime
3) Your duties are straightforward so no real surprises each day
4) Decent benefits/retirement
5) Decent pay for the work you do
6) They try to cultivate a cool vibe by doing stuff like doing community service and playing games during shifts.
cons:
1) A lot of emphasis on productivity.  Your job is to look at applications and determine if a person is credit worthy and how much they should be lent.  You also take phone calls from customers needing a credit limit increase or a reconsideration on their denied application.  You have to process a certain number of apps/calls each hour and it can be a real grind keeping up with the standards.

2) The hours suck.  You'll most likely have to work 4 days a week for 10 hours.  The extra day off is cool but the 10 hour shifts suck.

3) There's little room for growth.  If you stick around for a while you may get job as a quality review person whose job is to make sure analysts make good lending decisions.  You may also get a manager title but there are few of those jobs available.

4) Short lunches/breaks.  You get two 15 minute breaks and a 30 minute lunch.  I'd rather have an hour lunch and no breaks but maybe that's just me.

5) It's a real grind.  The number of apps/calls you have to work is no joke.  It's a little better if you work night shift as there's less calls which usually take longer to work than apps.  You most likely won't hit productivity standards your first few months there.  Luckily you have a 3 month grace period to get things together.

review_title: Amazing company with great potential for a great career!
pros:
- Great team.
- Great opportunities for personal and career development.
- Varied day to day working. Many different areas in which you are trained on.
- Really great fast paced environment.
- Great benefits as a full time member of staff which make the staff feel valued such as performance related bonus.
- Really enjoyable place to work once you are trained, as there is a lot of knowledge to learn and job fulfilment. 
- A great job for someone who really enjoys making a difference.
- Some of the more senior staff are really supportive.
- Great company ethics concerning female empowerment and morals. A really supportive company for women who want to further their career goals. 
- Great culture day to day with management support if a customer is particularly difficult which is a great aspect of management.
cons:
- Often lots of customer pressure based on you if you are in the banking hall as you are often the first point of call.
- Left feeling overwhelmed and untrained at the beginning of the job - training should be longer and more in-depth. The online training does not prepare you for the job as much as it should and there should be longer practical training to enable best customer service.
- As a temp, there were no benefits including no sick pay or holiday pay.
- Management often place lots of pressure on the front of house staff off the back of MPS customer service calls. We are often told conflicting ideas to approach customer service i.e. We must man Zone A (meet&greet zone) then told after customers say we aren't helping enough to not man Zone A. Told to encourage customers to use Assisted Service Counters, but often getting feedback that as customer service providers we are too pushy/intrusive. The zonal system does not work and needs to be reworked by people who have actually been party to the first line of defence within customer service as they have the best idea of day to day service and know how there banking hall works best.
- MPS system for customer feedback is poor as the questions are open ended and long which results in discrepancies between MPS calls due to differential customer opinion on good customer service. Essential bankers often facing the brunt of this and not getting their good work recognised.
- Management are not pro-active enough and do not show banking hall presence - often showing a begrudging attitude to being asked to cover the banking hall-  therefore it is often condescending to staff to be told how to improve their service as management do not know the day to day running of the banking hall and thus can not devise plans. 
- All staff should be trained on all aspects of the business before progressing as often it leaves the banking hall short as people can not cover the counter and therefore leaves people alone in the banking hall - which is not only dangerous in case of emergency but also reflects poorly on customer service.
- Some staff are on old contracts which is unfair to other members of staff. Staff often got to leave early or not work saturdays because of their old contract - this should be updated to ensure there are enough staff provisions for the whole day - not only part of the day as it forces pressure on the staff who complete the whole day. 
- Management encourage competition between staff which creates an uneasy atmosphere. Praise is often not given on merit - as managers often have their favourites (which is not unique to barclays but should nevertheless be worked upon to ensure all staff feel satisfaction within their job.) Cohesiveness of the team would also improve alongside a healthier working environment if this was fixed and looked at.
- Technology at Barclays is among the best within the banking sector, however often it fails which is not only embarrassing but also reflects poorly on customer service. Barclays should enable all technology is piloted and works well before rolling it out in to all their branches. For example the Kiosk and its software& privacy must be looked at and improved upon to improve customer service. Counter software should be updated and easier to use. iPad's should be able to action prompts and the software should be improved to ensure it doesn't time out constantly which results in poor customer service as often staff take customers out of the counter queue to help them but due to technological error have to place the customer back in to the queue.
-Marketing also needs to be improved upon. Often posters are released with poor wording regarding branch closure or hour reduction which results in unhappy customers. Again, essential bankers face the brunt of this. Marketing should ask essential bankers their opinions or create a poll in some instances - or even take someone on who has had front line experience because the company would benefit from correct wording and knowledge of someone who has dealt with customers on a day to day business.
