During my interactions with other units, I have come across several senior managers who appear to have taken inspiration from him, and have driven performance of their teams. Therefore, the major upside is probably being able to work and get experience from certainly the best of British IB’s, and one of the best globally.  

Provided you are in the right team or business unit, this place is generally a true meritocracy.  There are many MD’s who are still years away from hitting 40.  At the same time, there are several high profile senior MD’s and global heads who were let go, when they failed to continue to deliver.

It certainly is hard work, but having been there for nearly three years, I have never come across anybody saying it is a sweatshop.  You have freedom to manage your work.  The culture is fairly relaxed; and there is great drive and support to recruit, retain and develop talent (something Diamond never fails to reiterate in his quarterly updates); and promote charitable activities.  Women’s networks are very active, and there are several female MD’s; however, their ratio is far from being 1:1.  Staff benefits such as pensions and health insurance are reasonably generous (from my UK experience), and I doubt are available at similar levels at some of the American banks.
cons:
The downsides really depend on the team or business unit you are in.  Overall, there is probably a net upside, given my comments earlier.  However, what I have found is that, in some cases, Diamond has not been so successful in passing down his inspiration and enthusiasm through the leadership ladder.  Generally, front office is devoid of this issue, as I guess it benefits most from his oversight.  However, there are certain pockets in the middle office (where I work), where culture and perspectives are still not quite 21st century; where internal politics and cronyism is a bit too obvious.  Consequently, meritocracy and fair treatment have tended to suffer.  There are highly talented senior managers (in their area of expertise), but with hardly any interpersonal skills and knowledge of people & relationship management.  Their lack of the softer skills have sometimes tended to impact the team fabric.  Occasionally, there are individuals, whose lack of knowledge is far exceeded by the positions and rewards they enjoy.  

If you are unlucky enough to work in such teams, especially in times of a very dry market such as the current ones, where there are not many other jobs on offer, this can have a huge impact on morale.

review_title: Great business & Culture, with some challenges.
pros:
Barclays are a really amazing company to work for, without any doubt.  
For a start - the benefits are fantastic.  You get a generous benefits allowance and can tailor your package to what you want, everything from life, illness and accident insurance to gym membership and bike to work.  
The culture is very relaxed, almost too relaxed at times.  Barclays are normally the last bank to get to an offer when they're in competition against the other banks, and this needs to be remedied.   However, this relaxed culture means I've never been micromanaged.  You're left to do a job, and as long as you're delivering, you'll be left alone and can work as you wish.
The opportunities are there, for sure.  I went from Cashier to VP in 8 years, but you do find the competition intense the higher you get.
cons:
As mentioned above, the floors of head office are filled with exceptional people, and competition for senior roles is intense.  This, however, is what you need to expect, and is universal across the industry.
Having said this however, promotions, in my experience, are very much about the face that fits, and you do find some very unexceptional people moved very quickly up the chain.  The biggest flaw that Barclays have is their interview process for promotions.  The process ONLY takes into account your performance on a rigid, scripted 45 minute competency interview, and not your prior performance in role.  This hasn't been the case at other banks I've worked at, where the highest performers tend to get promoted.  At Barclays, it's all about how good your (often made-up on the spot) examples to these questions are, and it's terrible.

Barclays is still stuck in the old days of banking and they have not realized the value of technological innovation or cheap analyst labor. review_title: BGI - A good job choice, but not a great career choice if you are exceptionally motivated.
pros:
The great and talented people.
The collegial atmosphere. 
Great location for a head office.
Good levels of communication from Blake Grossman.
The new head office building itself.
cons:
The current BGI is one where virtually all roles, outside of sales, have been broken down into extremely narrowly defined categories of tasks.  This is very different from the much smaller firm of only 10 years ago, however, this serves the firm's purpose of maintaining a low cost structure while maximizing the degree of specialization of most people on staff.  Some might say that they are exploiting a production line approach with specialists responsible for adding a trade list here, calling a broker there, generating a client report, etc to create their final product.  Although this is one way to achieve spectacular returns to scale, it leaves many of the rank and file in a situation where their skills are really only valuable to BGI and where one's career can stagnate after a few years on the job.  As a result, if you look around the organization, you will find many very talented people who aren't really being fully utilized to their maximum potential.
At the end of the day, it is more about individual preference - I know many people that remain there that absolutely love BGI and I agree with them on many points.  However, I know just as many that have self selected out and are glad that they are no longer there.  If someone were looking for a reasonably secure, reasonably well paying job, BGI would be an excellent firm to work for.  On the other hand, if one were looking for a place where you would have the opportunity for an interesting career progression, have a broad experience and develop your investment management and business skills, I would recommend looking elsewhere.

You'll have incredible tools from the cutting (but not bleeding) edge of technology and business, plus have the funding to sustain them.  Your group will learn or create the absolute best approaches to your daily obstacles and apply your solutions without the immature drama that prevents so many other businesses from a similar excellence.

review_title: Not a "nice" place to work, but pays well
pros: When I started working there, the firm was very entrepreneurial and grew from a scrappy upstart to a formidable competitor. The smaller size means a closer working relationship with senior colleagues and a better chance to learn more quickly. Not uncommon for top management to know the name of a graduate trainee and take an interest in that person's career development. Base salaries tend to be lower than other banks but bonuses are (were) generous if you perform well.  There are a lot of top bankers that the firm has hired away from competitors and this presents a great opportunity to learn and grow in your career if you get to work with them.
cons: Aggressive atmosphere is encouraged by management, client-stealing and deal-grabbing happen frequently. If the person attempting to steal your clients/deals happens be senior to you, there is very little that you can do.  Also, constant changes - some good, some bad.  My manager/reporting lines changed more than once every year the entire time I was there - this was not unusual.  Moving teams within the firm is extremely difficult - better to leave altogether, as any attempt to move to a different position will be viewed by your manager as an insult.  They would rather see you leave the firm than have a possible negative reflection upon themselves. Therefore very important to know the team before you join - there are as many good teams in the firm as bad ones.  Barclays Group presents a bit of bureaucracy to deal with, but Barcap is largely insulated from this.

pros:
The work is generally challenging, and management tends to be very hands off- no one will be breathing down your neck. There is an energy in the air that the firm wants to be aggressive and push to be the #1 IB, and while I have heard that stuff spouted at other large firms, they are really trying. The benefits and offices are nice, and if you are on the ex-Lehman side it used to be really easy to get promoted, though I can bet that will change as the Barclays side has complained tremendously about this. This may sound trivial, but at 745, but good nearby food options were abundant, and even the cafeteria was great. 

The size of the organization is still manageable, there is significantly less BS in the way to get things done than at other large banks I have been at.
cons:
Lower level and mid level management needs training. Very political environment which can be toxic- network and get in good (kiss ass) with your manager or you WILL be kicked to the curb. The turnover over the last year has been insane. Hire a bunch of people, fire a bunch of people, start all over again. I have seen entire groups gutted, then filled with new hires who now have no idea how anything works. The layoffs seem to be way more politically motivated than performance motivated, but at this point its hard to say they are even political anymore- it seems arbitrary.  

Comp this year was laughable- bonuses hardly exist anymore. Some people got nice raises to compensate, but many did not. 

Times Square is just plain annoying to get to or get around in.

If you have a personality, I would advise you to stay away from certain BU's in Barclays. Also, too much competition between managers to be best. My manager would frequently talk smack about the other team manager yet be all nice to their face, and also tell them things that you have spoken to them about in confidence. Salary is OK, but bonus time they literally move the goal posts to match whatever they want. They need to stick to their objectives and if you deliver, you deserve a reward. review_title: Great for an internship, terrible as a grad / full time
pros:
- Mostly great co-workers. BarCap employees themselves are great although the culture has soured since the Lehmen acquisition.
- Clear promotion opportunities if you're not a graduate.
- Great internship scheme - lots of training and networking events.
- Good technology working groups, some managing directors are very switched on, especially in Equities.
- Reasonable meritocracy for full time hires - although not within cookie cutter graduate positions.
cons:
- Typical of banking, most people are motivated by money and not love of their job.
- Most graduates are on the same salary as new interns - even after having 1-2 years of experience.
- Many graduates get sub optimal placement when joining teams which don't reflect their interests adequately. They are allocated according to 'business need' - but if the wrong part of the business needs a graduate, it can negatively affect your career.
- Graduate scheme training is a waste of time and money for those not in front office. As a technology grad, give us actual technical training. A two day 'beginners Excel' course is not sufficient, particularly for the vast majority of technology grads hired from non-CS courses.
- Internal mobility is a joke. Anecdotally - most people quit and are rehired at a higher salary.
- Since the acquisition of Lehmen's - considerably increased management. When an intern I had 3 managers in between me and the CIO. As a graduate i had 7. What do these guys all do?
- Technology is old, outdated and generally under invested in. They often refuse to spend a few hundred pounds on a workstation dated less than 4 years old (despite salaries being above market for most employees). Bizarre.

pros:
Frontline Branch Staff are great and IT for customers is great. Used to have great morale and team building sessions but now areas are so big, it’s not cost effective to get staff together to gel.
If you love customer service it’s for you. 
Benefits are ok but no better than any other big corporation although they do like to say they are! 
Sharepurchase is great for building up shares in a safe environment and at a discounted price.
cons:
IT for staff is challenging and often fails. 
Some branch managers just use the role to leapfrog to next role so they talk the talk but don’t walk the walk. They don’t care about frontline staff either. 
Promotion is a joke as when any jobs come up, everyone knows who will get the job but they still put people through interviews which are painful to say the least! You get on if :
1. Your face fits with current area management 2. You talk a good talk.
Obsessed with “expectations” but there are no “targets”: performance is all managed through electronically captured Management Information which is frequently proved to be inaccurate but cannot be altered! 
End of year PD ratings are a joke! 
Also obsessed with observing everyone from the tea maker to probably the CEO! (Although the observer frequently has not done the job they are observing)
Constantly looking to cut costs to the extent of reducing photocopying paper down to 2 boxes per month - decided by an administrator who has never worked in a busy branch! 
Don’t expect fantastic financial staff benefits - there are none!

review_title: Good to have on your CV. Read the other reviews and make up your own mind...
pros:
- Great if you love close contact with customers. Most of them will be sincerely grateful when they perceive that you care about them and are trying to help them make the best choices. That is very fulfilling. 

- Decent company benefits and bonus. Nice quarterly and annual ones.

- Good chance to build a career within the company: if the company and job is for you, possibilities of growing are endless. There are plenty of roles, especially in the corporate field.
cons:
- The Moment Banker role is advertised as a purely customer service job but has a strong sales element to it. You will be told that what matters is giving the customer the opportunity and let them then make their own informed choice... but if they don't end up taking  the product you will then be pressured by the management because you done enough of this or that. You will essentially be measured according to hinted-at targets that you officially don't have and that you are not allowed to call by that name. There is no fixed number, but it will always be "more".
Officially the world "sales" is anathema and cannot be mentioned, either with customers or with higher-ups in the business,  but it will be constantly utilized in internal meetings, giving rise to a recurrent cognitive dissonance. 

- The branches I worked in were highly disorganized and there was a certain culture of leniency going on. People just didn't turn up, or they overslept and turned up late, or behaved in a very lazy, unprofessional and juvenile manner and were allowed to just get away with it. The worst they'd get is a slap on their wrist. 
On the other hand, hard-working people with strong values were constantly being monitored and picked up for the slightest inaccuracy. 

-Terrible IT infrastructure. Computers and systems very sluggish and constantly crashing. Sections are full of bugs that stay there for months and months. Designs are very much nonsensical and not user-friendly.

-Senior management severely lacking in many compartments. Colleagues who really cared about helping customers make the best choice were being pressured into leaving the job, colleagues with personal issues (sometimes as serious as mental health) were told to just "man up", openly threatened to be managed out of the job or bullied in staff meetings.... and this coming from a company that prides itself in values such as inclusiveness etc. etc.

Overall, something like 10 out of 16/17 members of staff were leaving or actively looking to leave the job/branch.

review_title: Barclays looking growing footprint in North America
pros:
Barclays is trying to grow its footprint in North America.  They have leading electronic platforms and have not put much effort into selling it globally or regionally until summer of 2007.  In terms of cross selling platforms of Fixed Income, FX, Commodities, FX Options, Money Markets, and Futures the BARX has a very strong offering compared to other banks.  I have reviewed and worked with the top 5 in the last 5 years.  Barx is now pushing from the TOP Mgmt down to drive Emerging Markets Electronically.
Resources and support from all different asset groups are very well coordinated and driven for success....more so than I have witnessed at DB or UBS.  I view it more like a GS.
cons: Old regime fighting change.  The old school traders that are not embracing electronic trading are slowly losing out because their clients are going electronic with or without them.  Second, BARX Upper Management is forcing them to support electronic trading.  They expect the traditional sales guys to be working on cross products and structured products that are more profitable for 80% of their day.  The day to day trades that can be done electronically they want moved over to the BARX platform as it is cheaper for the bank to process those trades electronically and frees up the time of the traditional voice sales coverage to work on structured trades.

pros:
As a student who aims for constant learning, development and new challenging opportunities I thought the Barclays Spring Week Insight was a perfect opportunity to kick start my career since an early stage of university. The process of applying was very straightforward, I really enjoyed the process as it involved a video-interview, in my opinion this recruitment tool is way more effective and personal than a cover letter, as an example. 
Once the Spring Week started, I felt motivated and involved from the first minute and I quickly engaged with the other interns and employees of the firm. I woke up every day looking forward to arriving to the office. I couldn’t’ t wait to get exposure to the Spring Weeks learning and development, providing me with a honest insight into the industry, which for me was vital as it made me know how it really is to work in the financial services industry. Before the Insight Week myself and other interns did not know if we wanted to pursue a career in this industry, however, now I am very sure I want to, and if it wasn’ t for this experience I would still have major doubts about my career and future plans, now I have a clear image of my future role and how I will create a positive impact on the financial services sector.
The supportive environment makes justice to Barclays identity. The help I received from my team created an exceptional working environment that allowed me to feel comfortable sharing my ideas and being myself. Their hospitality and the way in which they value the talent of new generations were both motivating and unique. 
What I really appreciated about Spring Week was how from the first day, interns tried their best to talk to each other aiming to create and develop positive relationships which would not only help them throughout the Spring Week insight but also in life in general, as a point of contact for our future careers but also as friendships. I saw a positive competitiveness, something which is much needed in most organizations as it leads to maximum effort and development of its members but also, it leads to people pushing each other up and collaborating towards the goal achievement of everyone.
During this week, the learning curve was steep, this learning was not only about Barclays and its culture but it led to a deep contact with its functions and its employees by also learning about Barclays clients and how to deal with them. I am very grateful for the vast amount of knowledge I have learnt which will help me in my life and future career 
This experience was unique and life changing. It has improved my life, it has developed my desire to become great, but most importantly it has given me the confidence I know I need to achieve my dreams.
cons: From my short experience with the bank I can not find significant disadvantages. However, there may be disadvantages depending on employee preferences. It is obvious that hours are long and projects are extent. Banking is an industry which requires sacrifice and consistency.  Also, in most cases you will be reporting to senior management, some people dislike this as they would like to be their own boss.

pros:
* Good work/life balance -- family friendly culture in most teams.
* Still some really good people. Former "no dicks" policy still seems to be working.
* A serious player.
cons:
* Highly bureaucratic, diffusion of responsibility, culture which promotes talking over doing.
* Still reeling from multiple scandals.
* Quality of people at same corporate grade highly variable across teams/departments. Incompetent managers can prosper for years without being discovered.
* Lots of time spent on reporting project plans, but plans never stuck to, constantly being "rebased".
* History of making arbitrary rate cuts to contractors.
* The "Values" have received positive press coverage, but employees on the ground hate the implementation and find be told they need to show "Respect" and "Integrity" insulting. Evangelical delivery doesn't help. Little actual buy-in from management e.g interpreting in the context of their businesses, rather just repeat vague marketing material down to employee level.

pros:
I appreciate this isn't possible for every employee in every team at Barclays but I'm fortunate to benefit from Barclays' dynamic working and flexibility. Having that little bit of flex on when I start and finish each day makes me feel less pressured and I'm able to achieve a healthy work-life balance. And actually, I pretty much stick to the same start and finish time each day but just knowing I can flex this makes me really happy to work here. I could hit the wall one afternoon so it makes sense to leave a bit early whereas other days I'm on a roll so don't think anything of staying late; it all evens out over the month. Or I could decide I want to hit a gym class or go for a run; having the opportunity to fit that into my day helps with balancing demands of work and personal and maintaining wellbeing. I've also been able to compress my fortnight into nine days meaning I have a day off every two weeks which I often use for personal development or to progress other areas of my life. 
Also, I'm able to spend some of my time at work on my personal development. whilst some employers could see this as unproductive, my manager understands how personal development ultimately benefits the team, department and company.
Variety is also important to me. I've moved around roles and several sites, exposing me to a lot of colleagues and opportunities.
Barclays' focus on citizenship is a key part of our agenda and it means I've been able to get involved with some really amazing opportunities. This is something my friends are always a bit envious of when they hear what I've been up to!
I've had ups and downs here but from day one I've known how fortunate I am to work for this company so I've stuck at it and been loyal.
cons:
Whilst there is a lot of talk about dynamic working/flexibility etc. I get the impression my area is leading the way on this so I'm probably in a fortunate position to benefit from this. some areas are still micro-managed in comparison to what I have. 
Recruitment process can be a bit clunky.

job_title: Direct Premier Relationship Manager in Liverpool, England
pros: I loved the job, the customers were so interesting to talk to and hear about their lives and professions. Most customers were high earners so a lot of them worked in very specific niche areas of their professions and it was interesting to hear about their specialities. Before working in my last department I had always praise Barclays as an employer, their benefits package is second to none and the wages are really good.
cons: I was in a department called premier direct when I left, I originally started that department as a team leader, when I was interviewed for the job, my understanding of the job role was that I would have a portfolio of high value clients and that my team would manage the clients due to the size of the portfolio, I couldn’t have been more wrong! When I began they put me in new to bank training even though I had been a part of Barclays for 5 years already, it had been a while since my last management position and some management training would have been a lot more beneficial. They also gave me a team that they had taken on as a risk due to the majority of them coming into work from long term unemployment and as such a lot of them were difficult to manage! The job role they were doing was not any kind of relationship building or management. They were on an outbound dialler making sales calls, all the calls were loaded into the dialler based on prompts about lending, mortgages and sometimes savings (although the focused heavily on lending mainly). The people I was managing had no idea what they were targeted against Yet I was expected to put action plans in place when they didn’t get things like mortgages or loans within a 2 week period. In the end I had to take time off and decided this wasn’t the job for me. When I returned I was made a direct premier relationship manager where i would contact the customers to build relationships myself, while this was using the same outbound dialler there was more of a relationship building style to it and not just completely sales. However, on returning I was clear my card was marked and I wasn’t wanted there, I would imagine it was due to having knowledge of the underhand techniques and sales they were driving when as a bank Barclays do not set targets for sales. I soon found myself going through a disciplinary process and when speaking to other people within the department and the union the “offence” I had committed should have been dealt with by no more than a file note. Soon after this was resolved I found myself to be the main suspect of another investigation for a laptop which was stolen 12 months earlier from my car, at the time this was reported to the police and they had seen the damage done to my car from the break in. I was told it was someone within the department who had contacted their special investigations team to raise this with them requesting it was looked into. This I also believe to have been done maliciously and in an attempt to make me feel like i was no longer welcome there, I’ve since decided to leave Barclays as they made it difficult for me to move to another business area.

job_title: PBA Complaint Handler in Poole, England
pros: Great centrally located large offices in Poole, Free parking which would normally cost around £10 day maximum elsewhere around town. Onsite restaurant offering a wide variety of food and drink. Friendly colleagues and overall was a good place to work. Friendly senior management and banter plus team huddles and career options available.
cons: The downside is the high turnover of staff 40 in the last 6 months in the PBA complaint handler role. The job is on the face of it a really good role investigating PBA complaints using inhouse systems. What makes it an impossible atmosphere to work in is the quality control team that check  case handlers work, nothing is black or white only grey area's with everyone in the QC team having a different interpretation of the same thing meaning when marking a handlers case you are normally always wrong with something. The stress caused by it is the problem, if handlers just worked cases had them checked and then completed without the traffic light system of having to get certain green feedbacks or you enter the supervised environment then if you fail to make the grade you are out and this way of carrying on is ongoing the whole time, making for a very stressful job which caused me some discomfort. If the  QC department process was totally reinvented then decent hard working people would stay or not get sacked, too many people passing through and I think it is unique to this department as the rest of Barclays is brilliant.

job_title: Technology Analyst in New York, NY

pros: Great pockets exist with terrific coworkers; talent is recognized with compensation and growth opportunities; good customer access.  Many of these things are features of the industry as a whole.
cons: Talent isn't always highly concentrated; not enough strategic thinking; not enough emphasis placed on introspection. Continued difficulty integrating the commercial and investment banking operations at some level, though much of this is made vastly harder by the changing regulatory regime. Still a fair amount of management shuffling at higher levels.

pros: Best place to work. my line manager was open for ideas and i had the freedom to work according to my terms. provided i achieved what i was hired for. No real pressure from the top management, which is really good as it helps the employees to perform better.
cons: There is no training provided and its expected that the employees hired have learned all the basics about the processes and products.

pros: Good place to work for and friendly environment. Lots of different roles and benefits. Great building and cheap gym. All in all is ok.
cons: Canteen is a little expensive. There is little or no progression. And a lot politics. Also a lot of roles that are talking but not doing.

pros:
Dynamic working helps me get a better work/life balance. 
Everyone has always been friendly.
They are willing to help you develop and advance your career/education.
cons:
They need to sort the parking out. There would be enough space if everybody had some consideration for others.
The dinner menu could do with some simpler options like.  Sausage rolls or the ability to have egg on toast, beans on toast etc.

job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: Certain groups have great cultures, while others aren't great. If you are lucky to get a group that's solid and values its junior employees, you'll have a good experience.
cons: Pay. The pay isn't comparable to other firms given the regulatory overhang. Will see if it manages to overcome this and keep talent from leaving.

review_title: Nice environment but too heavy of a workload
pros: There was freedom to make your own way, if you were base in New York or London then the sky was the limit for you, outside of that you could only go so far without relocating.
cons: The people were nice but the workload was way too heavy and there was little to no support, work hours sometime went 24 hours straight, all of the teams resided in other timezones so scheduling conflicts were the norm.

pros: Allows me to be effective, efficient, and flexible, and to deploy inventive, often outside-the-box ideas, strategies and solutions, in a sustanable, low overhead environment.
cons: I am seeking to acquire a broader experience with an establihed professional firm that values hard work, commitment, an eagerness to learn from others, cooperation and loyalty, along with appreciation of their employees' imagination and originality.

pros: Good pay. Cant think of anything else!
cons: Couldn't organise a coffee stall at church bazaar! System generic and crashes constantly. Customer is definitely NOT the main concern. Lots of upstart clerks thinking they know but dont. Lots of nepotism. This all equals nasty, spyful working environment where THEY do NOT care and definitely do not go the extra mile for staff or customer! Employ someone who can master a simple work timetable. All top show with little sincerity or trust. lots of silly work rules....especially re dress code!*!* Who is in charge....nobody knows!

pros: Mid-tier banking team.   Information technology, office support, graphics are all pretty competent.  Plenty of Parking.   Close to downtown Palo Alto.  Most of the junior bankers are nice people.  Recruits from top schools.
cons: Very long hours.  Training is difficult as that happens in New York.  Top people tend to leave for greener pastures (better banks, buy side, corporates, etc).

pros: Interesting  and challenging work that is relevant within the financial services sector. Colleagues are nice. Office space and facilities are ok.
cons: Way too many employees that are undervalued and underpaid paired with employees that are indifferent to the bank or its success does.

review_title: Great team but salary is very low. I feel cheated!!!
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in London, England
pros: Great team work and very amazing work life balance. My team is very supportive. I love my job and I think it's a great opportunity given me to be who I want to be.
cons: I was paid over £10000 below the market rate for my job role. I feel like I have been cheated or taken for granted.

job_title: Fraud Investigations Analyst in Hamilton, OH
pros: New management in Fraud are making things happen
cons: Old managers suck and they are very unprofessional. They love to micromanage and think they are superior to individuals who are on their level. The main system SUCKS and always lag.

job_title: Omni Specialist Banker in Sunderland, England
pros:
Diverse colleagues and a great focus on the LGBTQ community and the community. 

Generous salary and bonus structure 

Onsite gym
cons:
Awful team leaders who do not follow the "values" the company prides itself on. You've got to be either eye candy for the team leader or a relative of management to progress.

No support for any external issues you may have

job_title: Data Architect in San Francisco, CA
pros: The people I work with are intelligent, hardworking and care about the work they do.  The industry is interesting, always changing and therefore challenging.  Location is great!
cons: There has been a lot of turmoil lately.  Many people are more interested in building personal empires than doing what is best overall for the health of the company.

pros: It's a great culture and good work and life balance.  I also enjoyed the group I worked with.  You're introduced to complex instruments as well.
cons: To be honest, so far I have not noticed any downsides to working at Barclays Capital.  Obviously, there are the certain people who are micromanagers, but that is everywhere.

review_title: A fast growing investment bank with a very comfortable culture.
pros:
Great open culture in the office.
Managers are very approachable.
Encourages work-life balance.
An investment bank growing at a very face pace.
cons:
Team might be too large and individuals might find it hard to "shine".
Constant changes in management decisions and many were made in the last minute.

pros: No doubt, pay is slightly higher than the rest. Good benefits on leaves, medical coverage and etc. Good name to put in CV
cons: Poor middle management as the focus is only to get all the things done, they should also focusing on employee's career advancement, professional growth and work life balance. Well, i guess it's very much depends on who you're working under.

review_title: A great place to work in with a great package.
pros: An organisation full of talented people, who respect and appreciates one another for who they are. One of the least political places to work in within the financial sector.
cons: Some interesting choice of hires for senior management. They are very strong leaders in place, but some choices are far from desirable.

review_title: Not the same as Lehman but could be worse.
pros: Hours are not too bad, pretty decent benefits, the work is interesting, can work at home when necessary.  Lot's of opportunity with all the recent attrition.
cons: Awful comp structure, cheap on IT spending, won't provide tech training for employees, too much off-shoring of IT jobs to save money.  Can be very bureaucratic and centralized planning.

pros:
1) Life work balance is good
2) No overtime required.
3) Employees benefits are really good
4) Management gives ample opportunity to learn.
5) Good number of holidays and paid leaves
cons:
1) Too much process to be be followed to complete simple activities.
2) Organisation is moving towards agile but still stuck with the old SDLC process.
3) Feels like people are getting fired every month. Keeps you on your toes.

review_title: Nice people and supportive on shore partners. All in all a great place to work
pros: Good pay, supportive onshore stakeholders. The average knowledge and experience level to team is high so get to learn a lot from others.Flexibility to work fro  home. Frequent travels in a few teams.
cons: Local management is although only does administrative management but is pretty intrusive and tries to build bureaucracy in processes. Local leadership is focussed more on fun activity then delivering projects

review_title: Too british focused, not enough American Independence
job_title: Assistant Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great reputation, diverse businesses, good on site amenities, sought after place to work at; international mobility options
cons: Very focussed on London supervision, not enough independence for New York office to make their own decisions; too many fines; too much senior management turnover; not an e-verified firm

pros:
Salary on par with banking captives.
Good work culture and timings. WFH is available.
Good focus on learnings.
cons:
Testing Services has become a managed test center with a lot of metrics capturing and documentation that merits a critical review.
Bank is stripping and selling business. Needs some consolidation and positive business news.

job_title: Associate Vice President, Technology in Prague
pros:
- Great level of technical skill
- Friendly people
- Interesting investment banking projects (algo trading, ...)
- You can get promoted to Vice President even as an individual contributor (programmer) without, e.g., leading a team
cons: - It is easier to get a promotion by applying to another team within the company compared to waiting in you current team.

pros: Good company to work for, can work my contracted hours and not be expected to work in excess. Freedom to work from home whenever I like.
cons: No training budget, hiring ban so cannot move internally, leadership churns too often, bank has no clear vision, bonuses in Barclaycard take into account faults of investment bankers (reducing the amount available).

review_title: Challenging but exciting place to work
job_title: Lead Solution Architect in Knutsford, England
pros: Plenty investment , big 4 bank, tend to be 'first' to do things, surrounded by very talented people. Good financial package + benefits. Flexible working is encouraged, Radbroke Hall is a great place to work
cons: Work life balance isn't great, travel is required when you hit a certain level, the pressure is high due to high expectations (is this a con ?). Obsession with 'agile' is tedious

pros:
1. Free transport to office
2. Year end bonus.
3. Free hi speed wifi in office.
4. Good work life balance as work is less compared to service industry.
cons:
1. Lot of internal politics.
2. Lot of people who are there for 5-10 years and reluctant to share any information.
3. Stress on innovation but rarely any support from India management.
4. Frequent changes and alignments as new people come frequently in top management.

pros: The pay is good and I really enjoyed working in the team I started in. This team was broken up as part of restructuring but this is to be expected. .
cons: Went through restructuring whilst I was there which split up the team I was working in. Had few opportunities to move within Barclays and ended up taking a job outside of Barclays. The IT is also ancient.

review_title: Barclays Chennai as compared to Noida is far better a place to work.
pros: There's  growth here is fast; an average of 3yrs and you are promoted to an AVP. Decent Pay, Flat Hierarchy , Friendly work environment, Promotes Internal movement, Good work life balance are the other factors
cons:
Food provided isn't good
Office location (Chennai), isn't the city you wish to be in. Major chunk of the population is South Indian; you might feel sidelined sometimes, if you hail from the North

review_title: If I have to read one more blog... Core Values??
pros: Benefits, bonuses, pay increase & structure, holiday entitlement, appraisals and policies in place to cover progression and promotion. Parking and location.
cons: Superiors willing to further their careers, possible financial gain by taking advantage of those that trusted. Outsourcing to those more interested in quantity rather than quality, profit rather than wellbeing. Inevitable redundancies at a loss to the employee, against agreed contract & terms agreed with Barclay's. Could be you next?

review_title: Human Resources Management should be changed
pros: International team members (multicultural environment)
cons: Management is not experienced enough in Lithuania. Specially in HR, as the company sets high management positions to individuals that do not have any HR background...

pros: Good location, Nice building, Good name thanks to the Barclays Group.
cons: Do not expect meritocracy (better if you are a private banker or a good looking woman). Salaries and bonus are not good and below the job market (if you compare to other big names or other Barclays subsidiaries) ; even corporate titles are not in line with experience or responsibilities. Everything is done to give the bank a good image locally but atmosphere at work is below average for employees and no employment security. No particular advantages to work in a bank (no bank accounts, bad loan conditions, allocations, ....). A lot of actual employees would consider another opportunity in a competitor.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in London, England
pros:
Top group wide leadership team from diverse background. Some of the brightest minds around in HQ. 

Very flexible working conditions (depending on your position): Group CEO actively promotes flexible and remote working, which is must as a company to get maximum productivity from employees.
cons: Progression can be slow at times so if you are driven by quick progression then it may be slightly disappointing.

pros:
Manage your time independently
Work from home
Company Car
Daily Meal Allowance 
Travel Allowance
Work in collaboration with Bank which gives you more opportunities to learn
cons:
Old School 
Closed Environment 
Salary extremely low in comparison to similar positions with other competitors 
Constant pressure to deliver more even if you’re way ahead of your targets 
Little or No appreciation of your achievements

job_title: Global Markets Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Barclays trading floor is just like the trading floor of any other investment bank. If that is where you belong, then Barclays could be a good company to work for.
cons: You do not receive much support as you try to find a desk that is willing to hire you. Network and work those connections to get hired by a desk.

review_title: Used to be a good company before BlackRock took over
job_title: Business Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: When it came to developing software, BGI did a better job than some of the software companies I've worked for.  BGI was trying to put development processes into place which is certainly better than no process.
cons: BGI used to be a great place to work until they were bought out by BlackRock.  BlackRock dragged BGI 5 years back.  Process got dumped out the window.

pros: A lot of very good people who really want the business to succeed. Still a green field in a lot of respects with regards to the equity business.
cons: Influx of "Lehman" culture as all but destroyed collabrative and meritocratic enviroment. Lot of investment undertaken but with very minimal return has meant more than most sell side shops current staff are very nervous of their positions and protect their business potentially to the deprement of the larger Barclays brand.

review_title: Great place to work, good benefits
pros: Good teamwork and career development.  Flexible working and high holiday allowance. Benefits package very generous - pension, share scheme, medical cover
cons: You can be expected to work long hours and over the weekend for no acknowledgement.  There is still a culture that it is who you know which makes a difference rather than what you do.

review_title: Not a bad place but management is more interested in you being at work and the work you actually do.
pros: Good pay, some interesting projects in IT when they let you work on them long enough to contribute something meaningful.
cons: Inflexible hours, no sustained investment in projects, middle management is managing up big time no matter what. Upper management is completely disconnected from the desk.

pros:
-Nice people, atmosphere
-Management approachable and pretty open
-Good front office systems
-Comp is good (quite skewed for different people, though)
-You get lots of opportunities to take on new things if you do well
cons:
-Messy middle/back office : hard to get new clients onboarded etc.
-CEO is cut from different cloth to competitor CEOs and hence his focus is different
-Has become a bit  American in terms of corporate structure/communications
-Sales and trading teams are a bit hit-and-miss ; not good across the board

pros: Well it's a job but nothing like it was even 20 years ago. I left an organisation which I'd worked for for 35 years felling relieved to be out of it.
cons: The bank still maintains a target driven culture that inadvertently encourages bad behaviours across the board. "Bonuses" at the branch / call centre level are unreliable and frankly subjective.

review_title: The most unpleasant place I have ever worked
pros:
The command-and-control style of management has had some wins: the market data infrastructure is better than many peers.

Some very good quality teams in IT/quant
cons: More bullying than I have seen in all my jobs put together. Simply vile. Worst offenders were trading in IRD and Equities. But bad behaviour almost everywhere. Shouting, hounding, nervous breakdowns, you name it. I was an appalled spectator rather than a target but just witnessing things was enough to thoroughly depress me.

review_title: Great people, great place to work
pros:
Really friendly and intelligent people to work with and learn from
Good communication with senior management
Great office environment, innovative, modern, and relaxed
Ability to implement your own ideas
International company

Ability to develop your skills, knowledge, and career 
Flexible work arrangements are possible
cons:
Global processes don't always work locally and can be hard to change

Decision making can take too long

pros:
New start up in the operations business
The finance segment of the bank is expanding for chartered accountants
cons: Chennai city is a difficult one to survive for people outside chennai.But over a period of time you can get used to it as every thing is available in this city

pros: Couldn't ask for a better scenario - a resonant brand, huge consumer and business customer base, and more money than God.

She changed her mind without new information (and often had no reasoning before) and wondered why things weren't done the new way originally. She sowed fear throughout the organization, causing the weakest to in-fight. It was nasty.

pros: People on the front line really want to make a difference for customers and do the right thing. Freedom to move departments (fairly) freely so there's quite a lot of cross dept knowledge.
cons: Top tier management only cares about costs and profit margins. No confidence that they are listening to staff (no matter how often they say they are) who are very knowledgeable. Can be very frustrating.

pros: Friendly work environment. Very professional. High work ethics with some people... Whatever the number of good people still left behind.
cons:
Technology is stuck in time. Still stuck to desktops from 1998. It's a iPad world. Need to upgrade to laptops.

You would find people with some odd hierarchy politics and power hungry egos lingering around in each department.

review_title: Overall good company to work for
pros:
* Passed inflection point, on the way up
* Global brand, good to have in your CV
* Innovation culture
cons:
* New promotion process for Ops & Tech is a step backward and not aligned to industry standard
* Salary in the lower end bracket
* A lot of red-tape, want to be an agile company but being slowed down by numerous red tapes

pros: It is a big brand and has all the trappings of an organisation with large resources. The work conditions, benefits and job content meet the minimum standard of any large bank.
cons: There is absolutely nothing to distinguish the organisation from other organisations. Their policies are never path breaking. In fact, they lag the market in several of these. The organisation is largely impersonal and people come and go without anyone noticing.

pros: environment is very supportive, colleagues work together well and there is a real focus on customer experience.  In general teams work well together and the performance of the business is strong.  Real focus on internal mobility with most roles being open to internal colleagues only that helps supprot career development.
cons: can be a lot of pressure to deliver good results, some restrictions on travel and budgets but this is seen as a short term restriction.

pros: Friendly atmosphere and good culture that embodies the values of the firm and really nice people who are always willing to help out and give advice.
cons: Politics of big organisation makes it hard to get anything done and thus decreases efficiency. The hours can be long and unpredictable but this is compensated for by longer holidays and weekends off.

review_title: All that glitters is not gold
pros:
Compensation is relatively good, work from home on manager's permission.
Free transport. Bonus (if you really get one, there is uncertainty now).
cons:
Only work & go home, work life balance below average, they have stopped giving bonus to 35% of employees recently. No opportunities to travel overseas. No leisure time. Cash eating corrupt cafeteria at EON, you are in trouble if ATMs run OOM.
None of the official processes are transparent.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: They pay you fairly well and give you good benefits. My health insurance is awesome and the employer matching for 401k is very generous.
cons: No work life balance. Management doesn't care if you are there till 2:00, and will only have complaints for you when things go wrong.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: Overall, a good place to work.  They hire some of the brightest people on the street and everyone is striving to get Barcap to be #1 on the street
cons:
Work life balance is limited.
Lots of politics

pros:

-Competitive salaries are offered

pros: Senior Leadership recognize the changing global environment and adjust their strategy to reflect that. Great team environment that encourages you to think out of the box.

Not enough advancement opportunities

review_title: Could Offer Opportunities for the Future
pros: Barclays Capital is a growing firm who is trying to expand its businesses which may in the future lead to growth opportunities.
cons: Barclays Capital is still fairly new to the bulge bracket arena and it may be difficult for them to make significant head-way into the top deals.

review_title: You don't want to work there
job_title: Vice President In NY in New York, NY
pros: Strong name on the street. Good coffee at pantry- green mountain. Good location if you live in Westchester or Connecticut.
cons: Management tries to trick you all the time. Beware of your pay structure. They can cut your salaries without saying it. READ YOUR OFFER LETTER. Whatever they did not PROMISE will not happen. Seriously.  Also beware you need really long notice period before departure.... My own experience... All managers are trying to protect themselves ONLY. If you want to work at this bank, always have an offer on hand for backup.

review_title: Barclaycard US has great people and interesting work.
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Wilmington, DE
pros: Barclaycard US pays well compared to its competitors and gives out 22 days of vacation to new employees. It has a friendly environment and has a lot of fun and interesting events to keep people engaged. Recently we had a ping pong tournament and have a baseball game planned soon.
cons: Right now most employees don't have laptops so we need to print out presentations before we go to meetings instead of just emailing it.

review_title: Good company to work for with some obvious areas of improvement.
pros:
Company reputation, history, good diversity and opportunities for training. Company policies for employee support are also really good.

Employees are highly skilled with a lot of knowledge and expertise in their area of work. The learning experience could also be quite rich depending on the team that you work for.
cons: Work environment is quite bureaucratic and can get highly political. Sometimes you can see personal agendas at play and the work environment could be individualistic.

review_title: People and culture outshine the brand
pros:
Work with extremely motivated and intelligent individuals.
Work on a variety of high-profile transactions
More collegial and supportive than your typical bulge bracket bank
cons:
Significant portion of compensation is deferred, especially for the more senior bankers
Brand doesn't appropriately reflect the quality of the firm

review_title: Not all it is cracked to be....
pros: More informal than the rest of the bank - on the surface.
cons: Extremely hierarchical, and slow-moving (despite what is claimed) with minimal focus on well-being and development. Very political place - like the rest of the bank.

review_title: Doesn't look after its technology staff
job_title: Technology Assistant Vice President in London, England
pros: Depending on the team you are in and the projects that you work on, you can end up working with some very smart people
cons: There is very little effort put in to retaining talented staff. Constant cutting and non replacement of staff puts a lot of extra load on remaining colleagues. This place is not a meritocracy any more.

pros: Good technology investment. The new technologies are used and updated all the time, which is good, especially for the flow business.

pros: Good paymaster, good work-life balance, Change in Barclays Plc managment for good, Bank semingly is on right track with more aggressiveness and work-ethics promoted by senior management. Good for India based captive to grow

pros: There is a great team mentality and I felt like I really learned a lot during my time at Barclays. A good place to start as a graduate looking to start their career.

review_title: Good place to start but get out soon

review_title: Not a bad company to work for if you can navigate its complexity
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Glasgow, Scotland

Pay market or above where performance merits.
FS benefits including non-contrib pension are a bonus.
cons:
Bonus even in good years hovers at around 10% for better than average performers.

job_title: FPGA Design Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, flexible working hours, great technology, chill people. After 9 years in the aerospace industry, this has easily been my favorite job. A lot less "mean nerd" types and way more down to earth people than I was used to.
cons: Large organization, sometimes overly bureaucratic and can be slow to move. Management is changing however; they're getting more technical people in higher level roles, and things are improving.

pros: Good basic pay for those coming into the company + decent holiday and benefits. Generally good working environment and company provides support for personal growth.
cons:
Revolving door and upper management means I see the same strategies regurgitated as new every 5 years. Big company problems like holistic strategy / decisions never being completed leaving half-baked deliveries half-complete aka "Tactical". 
Long term staff underpaid versus new colleagues joining the company. Experience and loyalty not always rewarded.
